address: Avenida Eusebio da Silva Ferreira, Lisbon 1500-313 Portugal
description: The Stadium complex offers entertainment, commerce and leisure. All emotions are allowed at the Benfica Stadium, a venue envisaging numerous possibilities: excitement, leisure, commerce and a glorious and complete show on the pitch. Stadium Tours every day from 10am to 6 pm. (Domestic competitions: there are no Stadium Tours on match days; European Competitions: there are no Stadium Tours on the day before the match and on the match day itself). Benfica Museum It proudly displays Sport Lisboa e Benfica's long and rich history, including a multifunctional room for temporary exhibitions. The Benfica Museum is an area of pure interaction between the fans and the Club's past and present. Commercial Area Located in the Stadium's surroundings, this zone offers an array of services, from traditional restaurants to various kinds of stores. Benfica Official Store Mirroring the Club's dimension and commercial strength, the Official Store confirms the Benfica brand as a triumphant emblem.
name: Estadio do Sport Lisboa e Benfica
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Benfica Stadium Tour and Museum Entrance Ticket
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Private Tour: Lisbon Football Experience - Stadium and Museum Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Benfica Stadium and Museum Private Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Lisbon city tour full day 9 am to 6 pm (private tour)
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Stadium of Benfica Experience and Museum Visiting
photo/caption: Estádio do Sport Lisboa e Benfica
ranking: #26 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #26 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Have completed many stadium tours and this one ranks high in the list. The guide was very knowledgeable and gave us enough time to ask questions and take photographs including with the eagles. We even got a free fridge magnet as free gift when we completed the tour. We included the museum tour in our ticket which as you can expect is impressive with nearly literally hundreds of trophies
reviews/1/text: I visited the stadium whilst in Lisbon for a Sporting match. You can walk all the way around and view the outside of the stadium which looks fantastic. Even better, you can grab a drink in it's restaurant and view the pitch and stands on the inside.
reviews/2/text: Had a great tour of one of the most emblematic stadiums in the world , friendly staff and very helpful, will be back to watch a match.
reviews/3/text: I'm a big football fan, so I decided to visit this stadium, while I was in Lisbon. It was awesome. The stadium is huge and is very beautiful. There's a big Benfica sports team shop, and also an Adidas store with jerseys of football players of Benfica. I think it's a must visit when you're in Lisbon and if you're a big football or sports fan. We also visited the players dressing rooms. I recommend it a lot.
reviews/4/text:
Visited here with friends on a trip to Lisbon in March 2022 as we are big football/soccer fans from the UK.

The stadium is really impressive in size and the friendliness of the staff working there shines through also. There is a really good club store to visit and there is (at the time of visit at least) an Adidas store there also. 

We had a guided tour so could not necessarily explore at our own pace, however the tour guide gave us plenty of time at each part of the tour to take photographs and take in the experience. You get taken from the stands down to the side of the pitch, before walking around the perimeter to see the dugouts. You then go into the tunnel and changing rooms, although due to COVID-19 regulations we could only see the away changing room. 

Amazingly, one of the final parts of the tour was to see the eagles that fly around the stadium on match day. We all felt this was a really unique experience and not something you get to see on your average stadium tour.

We visited the museum after the tour and wow! The museum is massive and not only documents Benfica's sporting achievements throughout history but also tells a lot of the story of Lisbon as a city too.

I would recommend the Estadio Da Luz stadium tour and museum to anybody visiting Lisbon.
reviews/5/text: Absolutely amazing stadium. An absolute party saloon. I love it. With lights on or off... With or without water... Always offer us a beautiful day.
reviews/5/title: It's always a honour to visit this stadium. The "salão de festas" as it's know. Magnificent
reviews/6/text:
I took my 11 year old son on the guided tour of the museum and we were very impressed. Our guide and booking agent were very professional and knowledgable about the history of the club and their enthusiasm and passion helped make this a wonderful experience. The many different displays and interactive technology make this a must do for families who love sport. For me the fan experience was quite special and unique.

Thank you.
reviews/6/title: Wonderful fusion of sport and culture.
reviews/7/text: Tour takes you to the most important parts of the stadium, except for the home locker room since only the team players can stay there. The highlight of the tour is meeting mascots - eagles that can be seen from close. Great addition is museum that you should visit - plan to be there some 3 hours and still you won’t be able to see everything in details.
reviews/8/text: A very nice Stadium , very accessible next to a big mall with a lot of restaurants , parkings and it's the center of one of the most famous football in the world
reviews/9/text: After a disappointing start - we came on the Friday only to discover that although the tours are everyday except game days there were no tours that day until 4pm and this was 10am, we wasted a lot of time as it's a little way out on the metro. We came back Saturday for 9.30 to ensure we got on the first tour at 10am and although it was a mixed language group the guide conducted the tour in English.  We saw models reflecting how different the new stadium is compared to the old one, toured the hole of the inner stadium, the press room, away changing room, area in which the players hang out after the game and saw the 3 eagles. An eagles flies the stadium before every game and we got up close to them. Took photos through out and were never rushed to move on. Afterwards we went to the museum which is huge, there is so much to read. Hundreds of trophies some of which are for other sports. There is a video reflecting the eagle soaring over the city and showing the history of the team and another simulator about the fans. There is a very interesting timeline of world events and another about Lisboa events. There is a huge gift shop and you can get personalised shirts. Outside were some food carts.
reviews/10/text: You should visit the stadium when in Lisbon. If you are lucky enough to see the match, definitely a recommendation. It's not only about the match, it is the whole show before and during the match.
reviews/11/text: Might surprise you but I visited this stadium as an away fan with Portimonense. The stadium is wonderful with  3 tiers. The view was good but it seems that away supporters are treated poorly. The away supporters were located on the top tier in the corner. The area is netted to prevent objects from home supporters hitting away supporters. It just restricts your view. However, the home stewards were excellent, friendly and very helpful especially towards away supporters with mobility issues. This could not be said about the local police. Not sure whether it's a cultural issue but the police looked threatening and intimidating. Plenty of food kiosks and toilets for your visit. As a modern stadium you won't find many better.
reviews/12/text:
Came here for a game of football between Benfica and Portimonense which Benfica won 4 -0.

The stadium is a beautiful stadium and you can begin to feel the atmosphere grow and build in terms of music, the noise from the crowed and the fireworks. It was nice to see the eagle released before kickoff and it flew round the stadium in majestic form.

One of the highlights of the game is a little young man sat behind us with his family who couldn't contain his excitement. He was soo noisy, singing and shouting almost throughout the game. Speaking to him and we both exchanged a hi five.

Overall a very good game of football which I thoroughly enjoyed.
reviews/13/text: I have been ticking off grounds across Europe and this was one I have been wanting to do for ages! It was a wonderful trip, guided across the stadium and solo for the museum. So much history and so much to look at! Was nice to meet the Eagles! We spent well over 3 hours here (we love football so spent a long time reading everything!) so well worth of making a morning of it! We watched the film they were showing and it was totally fascinating. Excellent museum that covered all basis. Very impressed, especially as it was so cheap at 14euros. Well worth the visit!
reviews/14/text: Best activity to do on Portugal! I went there on Christmas holidays and I went to watch a game and I just loved it! It’s really amazing ❤️
reviews/15/text: Had a wonderful visit. Park at the Mall and walk over to the stadium. Many food options in the mall as well. Easy to get in an out despite the Stadium being in the center of the city.
reviews/16/text: Excellent tour. Informative and funny guide. Museum is huge with literally thousands of trophies. Tours are frequent so little waiting around.
reviews/17/text:
A friend recommended this stadium tour and I was pleased I did it ..
It was a drizzly morning ( my only poor weather day of my 4 days there).
Roughly 2 hours .. all over the stadium , with plenty of opportunities to take photos ...
Our guide was excellent ... ( didn’t unfortunately remember his name ) ... I was the only English person in a group of 10, but he took the time to translate everything into English...
For football lovers, it’s recommended.
reviews/18/text:
We did an early morning tour (9:30)- you can book online or buy in the store when they open. 
The tour was about 12-12 people - I think the small tours are great.  Our tour guide was great and because of the small group it went really well. 
We walked the stadium and saw the press room, visiting team locker room and met the team mascots - if you are a fan of the team and the sport then I recommend the tour.  The Museum is also a good part of the whole experience and it pulls the history of the team together - I agree that about 2 hours is what you will need for the tour and museum.
reviews/19/text: The tour was good and well worth the trip out of the center. Make sure you go to Gate 17 as I spent time queueing in the wrong place. The club has a huge history and this comes through very well. My only regret is that I didn't try to get a match ticket for their first game of the season.
subcategory_ranking: #26 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Largo do Monte, Lisbon 1170-253 Portugal
name: Miradouro da Senhora do Monte
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Lisbon: 1-Hour City Tour on a Private Tuk

ranking: #12 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #12 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Amazing view, probably the best one around Lisbon. You can see almost the whole city and the port.:)
reviews/1/text: This was the last observation point I saw in the city, during nighttime. Lovely view from the top, such a nice atmosphere
reviews/2/text: This is the place to go if you want to see Lisbon from above - and in addition it’s good exercise to walk up here (unless you take one of the many tourist carts) - so go, go, go (c:
reviews/2/title: Best miradouro of Lisbon - go, go, go
reviews/3/text: If you want to look out over the City for some impressive viewing, this is one of the best places to go. It's a bit of a hike, but worth it. There is a nice park with refreshments as well.
reviews/4/text: We went here twice during our five days in Lisbon. This was probably my favorite of the miradauros we visited on our trip! Stunning views over the entire city.
reviews/5/text: This viewpoint was my joint favourite of the eight Miradouros that I saw. It is the most expansive one as it takes in Alfama, the river, the 25 de Abril bridge and also distant views of Cristo Rei. The further up you go the better the view and less people too as it's a bit of a trek. However, when you get there it's well worth the steep walk. Not to be missed!
reviews/6/text: One of the best free and easily accessible views of Lisbon. Definitely worth the hike (or tuk tuk if you're lazy).
reviews/7/text: This is one of many viewpoints in Alfama. Although quite a distance from the other viewpoints, it is still very nice. It is also quite popular around sunset. To get there you can take the tram 28 to a nearby stop (R Graca) and walk a few minutes.
reviews/8/text:
The most beautiful place me and my girlfiend visited in Lisbon. The place provides an amazing view. 

We took the tram, after the tram stop the climb is arround 5-10 min to the viewpoint, the climb can be though but it's worth it.
reviews/9/text: Nice spot to rest on our electric bike tour. Pretty lookout of Lisbon with a very relaxed vibe. Not amazing, but enjoyable.
reviews/10/text: Gorgeous view & our favorite of all the lookouts in Lisbon. A must see if youre visiting. Also recommend a pastry at the cart there. Very good!
reviews/11/text: Tuk tuk took us to see the beautiful overview of Lisbon, its inner city, and river front.  Lovely view and a good spot to really get the full feeling of the area.
reviews/12/text:
Senhora do Monte is one of many view points in the Portuguese capital. It's close to St. George castle, atop the Alfama old town.
We were there during a cloudy day, but the views were still amazing. I guess it's best to come before sunset, as this Miradouro is on the eastern side of Lisbon looking towards the 25 April bridge and western part of town.
reviews/13/text: I think it is one of the most beautiful Miradouros in Lisbon. To get there you have to climb a hill however it is worth it. To look out and see Lisbon with its river, the bridge, the Castle, is something exciting! I think it is the perfect place to watch the sunset and have a drink with friends.
reviews/14/text: This is a great viewpoint from which to see Lisbon.  We took and Old Car Tour and drove to this lookout (among other places).  Loved the views, the old tree, etc.
reviews/15/text: You will have a beautiful Lisbon panoramic from this point. In fact, skip the entrance to the castle, walk to this miradouro and you will have the same view without paying.
reviews/16/text: Great views from this lookout and an excellent place to take a break from your walks around.  Take a lot of photos here.
reviews/17/text:
I went at night time for a good view,  based on my teenage advice. 
Some young people sitting around drinking and enjoying the view,  but didn't feel threatened. 
Nice photos.
reviews/18/text: This is the place to come for an expansive view out over the city and its surroundings. There is even a little coffee cart parked at the entrance to the patio where you can take in the city while sipping an espresso.
reviews/19/text: Definitely our favorite of all the miradouros we visited.  A great way to see a couple of the larger hills and get a sweeping view of the city.  Also a cool spot to see the castle from a distance.  It’s a little out of the way but if you happen to be on a tuk tuk, there is a strong likelihood that they will bring you here or you can request it of course.  Showing up here you know it must be a special place are there could be as many as 20 or so tuk tuk’s carting tourists up the hill to get here.  If you’re getting here by other means then check the tram or bus schedules to get as close as you can as it’s a bit of a walk from the heart of Alfama.  It is worth it though.  The view from here will speak for itself.

address: Praca do Imperio Belém, Lisbon 1400-206 Portugal
description: No expense was spared when they built this masterpiece of Manueline and Gothic architecture in 1502, which was inspired by Vasco da Gama who is buried here with other great navigators of the past.
name: Mosteiro dos Jeronimos

reviews/0/text: Church Review: We did not queue in the baking heat and pay to go into the Monastery. Instead, for free, we walked straight into the most beautiful and wonderful Church. It was spectacular. I instantly felt at peace. It was decorated in the most impressive detail.
reviews/1/text: Beautiful architecture and lovely grounds. Long lines so get there early morning or later in afternoon.
reviews/2/text:
We got in day when was first Sunday of month and it was free. We didn’t need this entrance for free, but we were there and wanted to look inside.

Please put some sign in website if it is for free then as well aware to take the ticket where written archeology museum, otherewise like we and others who were standing in the queue 1,5 h and even ask before the security is it really for free - yes! We continue to stand! After 1,5 h in the queue - sorry we and othere just turn away not to visit this important place.
Please put some signs or signs on the queue to avoid such experience for others!
reviews/2/title: Didn’t got inside, cause of organization
reviews/3/text: My daughter and I had timed tickets for 11:00 am on March 28, 2023. We had to wait in line for an hour and 40 minutes passed our allotted time to go in. We were only inside for about 20 minutes. So not worth  it!!! Then came out and waited in line for the chapel for about 10 minutes. The chapel is free and has a short line so I recommend just going there.
reviews/4/text:
Okay - if you’re visiting you need to know the following. There are two entrances. The one to the right is for the monastery church - free to enter. The one to the left is for the monastery. There is a charge and you need to buy tickets in advance. Ticket machines are in the area called Archaeological Museum. You have to use a machine, but it’s straight forward.
Second thing to be aware of is that the mornings seem to be full of yours and school trips. At least queuing for an hour. So, aim to get there after 2pm and the crowds have mostly dispersed. 
The church wasn’t any different to most RC churches, except it contains the tomb of Vasco De Gama. However, the monastery with its two levels of cloisters is absolutely fantastic. So beautiful - the sculpture amazing.
reviews/4/title: Wait til afternoon to miss the crowds
reviews/5/text:
Yes, even with a timed ticket you will wait (but saying that, we arrived about 10-15 minutes early and were in just before our allocated time slot - and that was at what I’m guessing is peak time of 11.30). But the cloisters are simply stunning! Every single pillar or section of carving is unique, and there are SO many of them. We spent about an hour wandering around both levels and took many, many photos. The refectory is also a definite must-see, with its tiled walls.
The church adjacent to the monastery is free to enter and we didn’t have to queue more than a couple of minutes. Inside you will find Vasco da Gama’s tomb and the tomb of the poet de Camões. There are some interesting chapels and windows although it is quite dark inside, but still a look around.
reviews/6/text: The queue was very long but moved at a reasonable speed. Inside the monastery there is a large open square with beautiful covered walkways. It took us about 40 minutes to walk around. We had expected to see more though the building was beautiful. There is a separate queue to visit the church. Overall for €10 it wasn’t bad value but I don’t really see what all the fuss is about
reviews/6/title: Umm pleasant visit but not overwhelming and not worth a long queue
reviews/7/text:
Presumably one of the must-see places, UN World Heritage site. In reality, grandiose architecture but empty inside.  No connection or stories with who used to live here. 
Even with an online ticket for a time slot, be prepared to wait in line a long time (45 min or more on this Wednesday morning).  The neighboring church with Vasco da Gama’s tomb is free but there is another line to get in.  And it’s kind of dark, no connection spiritually or otherwise.
reviews/8/text: Let me start by saying, this site is fantastic and a must see. I would give it 5 stars but for the ticketing process. I showed up 45 minutes early for my timed ticket entry. The line was down the block. I did not enter the monastery until 50 minutes past my designated slot…waiting in line in the hot (my standard) sun. This is not the only place with this problem in Portugal, but it affects my rating of the site. Why have timed tickets if you cant enter at the designated time?
reviews/8/title: Longest wait ever for a ticketed patron
reviews/9/text: We went earl in our visit. It contained the tomb of Vasco de Gama. And the tomb of a poet Luis de Camoes. The church is free for everyone to visit. We saw a flyer for a organ and violin concert and came back for that. It was grand with front row seats. The music sounded grand in the cavernous room. Very lucky to have seen that.
reviews/10/text: Very lovely monastery. A naval museum is attached to the monastery and is well worth the visit.  Models of ships and navigation equipment are on display.
reviews/11/text: Beautiful architecture and history, with several sites nearby, make sure you see the church in front, right line, free, moves quick
reviews/12/text: Although the cloisters were extremely beautiful I was disappointed that we didn’t see anything more of the building apart from the church, which requires a separate queue.
reviews/13/text: Stunning architecture and fantastic space. If you enjoy visiting places such as this, you’ll enjoy the visit. It was a bit tricky to figure out how to get in - so I suggest booking tickets in advance.
reviews/14/text: Yes the monastery is a very beautiful building but when you have to wait for 50 minutes to get in you start to question if you really want to go.We finally got in and spent out 30 minutes inside nothing much really to see came out more queues for the church so decided to go home via the jam packed trams.
reviews/14/title: Lovely building but not worth a 50  minute wait to get in.
reviews/15/text: It is admittedly an incredible building. It is beautiful and it is huge... but as others have said, you stand in line for a very long time to get in. And you are literally in there for 15 minutes. All you see are The Cloisters and there is very little in the way of written information. And then once you leave The Cloisters there is another big long line to see the cathedral. We did not even bother with that. In my mind this was a tourist trap and kind of a waste of time
reviews/16/text:
Warning: unless you buy an advance ticket on line, you will need to go through three lines, one to get your ticket, one to enter the monestary and one to enter the church. Each can take from 30 minutes to an hour. The ticket line is separate from the monestary line and located in the archaeological museum some distance away. 

There are no timed entry except for authorized groups between 9:30 and 10:30. 

Suggestion: buy ticket in advance and show up near closing to avoid long wait for an attraction worth about 45 minutes.
reviews/17/text: The monastery and surrounding area are definitely worth your time to visit.  The trams and buses going there are jam packed and the lines to get into the monastery can be very long so be prepared.
reviews/18/text:
As others have explained, you must buy a ticket either online or at the ticket office (near the back of the line) before you join the line. These paid tickets only give entry to the cloisters, upstairs and downstairs.  Possibly not worth the 50 minute wait for a 15 minute visit. 

There is a different line with no ticket requirements to enter the church only.
reviews/18/title: A long wait for not much
reviews/19/text: Just make sure you have your ticket before you join the queue. The ticket office is some 300m from the monastery entrance. If you are able you can get the ticket online and have it on your phone. A couple behind us in the quue tried this right at the point of entry, took them 15 minutes to get it sorted. Great monument with many photo opertunities.
subcategory_ranking: #5 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Avenida Infante Dom Henrique 1C, Lisbon 1100-053 Portugal
description: One of the biggest squares in Europe, this stylish area in downtown Lisbon often displays beautiful works of art and sculpture, and is a great place for a leisurely stroll.
name: Praca do Comercio (Terreiro do Paco)
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Best of Lisbon Guided Walking Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Highlights & Hidden Gems of Lisbon: Private City Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon: 1-Hour City Tour on a Private Tuk
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Lisbon Revelation Tour
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Bike Tours Lisbon - Center of Lisbon to Belém
ranking: #3 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #3 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Beautiful, grand space! Enjoyed going down to the water's edge. A must-see when in Lisbon. We especially liked the fun atmosphere on Rua Augusta leading into the square (weekend) The arch was spectacular!
reviews/1/text: One of the most beautiful place in Lissabon with so many good restaurants, bar, shops. Nice for walking. I really like it here.
reviews/2/text: Not much to do there except twirl around and see the huge plaza. Check off your tourist list and head to aflama to eat and drink at a cafe.
reviews/3/text: There are lots of squares in Lisbon and all of them are home to some lovely sculptures or fountains. But for sheer size this one is outstanding and also benefits from wonderful views across the waterfront.
reviews/4/text: This is a spectacular square with beautiful statues and buildings right by the waterside in Lisbon. You will see everyone taking pictures, enjoying great views around. A must see in Lisbon!
reviews/4/title: Immense square in the historical center
reviews/5/text: Definitely one to see when in Lisbon - we walked the way along the riverfront from Cais do Sodré, which was a lovely way to approach this large, impressive square. The archway is simply enormous and the whole feel of the square is very attractive and historical. You can get a drink in one of the cafes/bars if you want (we didn’t).
reviews/6/text: Great area for meeting friends and enjoying a walk. Lots of restaurants. Also an area for gathering.
reviews/7/text: Remove the fake drug dealers and it would be lovely, all the way down rua Augusta (even in Avenida de Liberdade) and into the square you are constantly accosted by guys pushing cocaine, weed , hash offering to let you try the product.. mostly they will take the hint if you say no firmly but the odd one keeps pushing and you have to become a bit more aggressive to get rid of them. Sadly a complete blight on an otherwise lovely city with great people and because these dealers mostly only actually sell fake drugs like crushed paracetamol, crushed bay leaves etc the police cannot arrest and charge them with anything. It could be fixed if there was a will to do so , but I guess tourism in Lisbon is not valued very much. I imagine for some this would be a terrifying experience.... Just consider this carefully and be prepared if you decide to visit. Research it for yourself, quick search on Google..
reviews/7/title: Attractive but blighted by the drug dealers harassing you constantly
reviews/8/text: Awesome architecture and Arch of Triumph, equestrian statue and good for people watching, 5 min walk from train and shopping right behind
reviews/9/text: This place is extremely overrated. There is literally nothing to do here. There is a huge statue and an amazingly huge gate. But I would keep it last on my list.
reviews/10/text: The beautiful open air Plaza with the ocean to your back and neoclassical buildings to your front. There are plenty of shops and restaurants on the sides to what even the most discerning of appetites. Sunsets over the water are absolutely gorgeous.
reviews/11/text: Just a great place to be.  I imagine it gets crowded in the summer months.  Could have been improved with a bit more street theatres
reviews/12/text: This was a nice open area with views of the sea. Restaurants surround the square and are open all day. Tram and bus stops are nearby. It's a great spot to sit and relax after walking around the city!
reviews/12/title: Beautiful open area with views of the sea
reviews/13/text: this is a wide open space between the tagas and the historical centre grest place to relax and enjoy the  monuments
reviews/14/text:
Very hot spot for photos. With the arc, statue and the segway into the water and a nice view of the bridge there are a lot of options.

Be prepared for people trying to sell sunglasses, but they arent too bad with harassing.
reviews/15/text: Very pretty square looking out over the river. Plenty of bars and restaurants to choose from. Be careful of the extremely uneven surfaces in and around the area (actually in Lisbon in general) as our friend had a nasty fall, spraining her ankle,  bruising her elbow. Could have been so much more serious if she had of banged her heard or broken something.
reviews/15/title: Pretty Square BUT Keep Your Eyes on the Ground as well as on the buildings
reviews/16/text: Sit eat, drink relax and take in the scenery Right on the shore, so great for the scenery and people watching.
reviews/16/title: Lovely for people watching, but beware beggars and pickpockets.
reviews/17/text:
We went to Lisbon twice in 2021 (April & August) and both times, we went through this square.  It has a beautiful location, right by the water.  I really love the 2 columns & marble steps on the opposite side of the street (not technically part of the square).

There's not much to do in this square but it's still pretty!
reviews/18/text: This is a large open square with several statues and a nearby archway over the road.  Probably a great place to people watch in the summer.
reviews/19/text: The square is very large and lovely.  It's impressive beginning your walk here and then going down the famous Rua Augusta.
subcategory_ranking: #3 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Lisbon 1200-109 Portugal
description:
Home to art galleries and a historic monastery (Convento do Carmo), Bairro Alto is one of the busiest districts of Lisbon after dark. Locals and travelers pack its narrow streets to hang out outside the area’s countless bars. Try ginjinha, a local liqueur, as you listen to live fado music. During the day, you can stroll through the neighborhood's narrow streets and check out the quaint boutiques and cafes. 

To get to Bairro Alto, take the eye-catching Glória Funicular at Liberdade Avenue. It’ll drop you off at the São Pedro de Alcântara viewpoint, where you'll get commanding views of the city. 

– Tripadvisor

ranking_subcategory: #4 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Hilly terrain and good for keeping fit. Lots of curious neighborhoods in this area. You need good sneakers to climb these hills and plan to get in good shape while touring Lisbon.
reviews/0/title: Hilly and steep climbing to this high neighborhood. Great views at top.
reviews/1/text: Bairro Alto is somewhat nocturnal in so much as it enjoys a fairly mundane existence during the day before coming fully alive at night.  It is most definitely one of Lisbon's most vibrant nightlife areas.  It is home to chic boutiques, enticing bistros, bars and clubs.  There is a great ambience about the place and people appear to go from bar to bar.  Although lively by nature, it would appear to be safe and there is generally a police presence on Lisbon's busiest streets at night.  If nightlife is your thing then you could do worse than sample the joys of Bairro Alto.
reviews/2/text: The hills are no joke, but it's an absolutely beautiful part of the city! I love the tiled walls, the colors, the balconies with flower pots, and views all the way out to the river. Plus the street cars!
reviews/3/text: This is a great neighbourhood to wander about to get a feel for atmosphere in Lisbon! We were so impressed by the beautiful architecture of many of the buildings, often covered in the gorgeous local tiles. It’s also a good place to find somewhere to eat/drink or to take photos of historic trams as the no24 runs this way and isn’t as busy as the other lines.
reviews/4/text: Our hotel was in this area. Very busy. Lots of stores and squares that have subway access. The train station is close by.  Also due to the wide avenue, there are demonstrations in this area as well. We witnessed a huge teachers strike.
reviews/5/text: If you like good food and want to be in the heart of the city, this is the place.  Check out the Time Out Market where there are at least 20 restaurants under one roof.
reviews/5/title: Great restaurants and plenty to see
reviews/6/text: It seems there is a bar / pub for everyone here. It's a great vibe, and I wish we had found it sooner. Some bars are cash only and expensive, which is a shame, but we still had lots of fun.
reviews/6/title: The most fun neighbourhood in Lisbon
reviews/7/text: It was not really geared up for middle age couples and its very hilly. I would personally avoid it unless you have a specific restaurant or bar to viist.
reviews/8/text:
Cool little area! Word of warning for the out of shape or people who can't move well, this area is hilly AF. 

Another word of warning if anyone is staying on some of these streets, a lot of bars and noise can be heard in certain areas!

All that aside, a perfect location to see the sites of the city, not far from metro and Time Out to go to other places.
reviews/9/text: Definitely worth taking a walk to this gorgeous part of town.  Unfortunately it was pouring rain when we were there but that didn't spoil the beauty!
reviews/10/text: This is a steep street but it is totally worth it.  A fun way to see the city and the views are totally worth it.
reviews/11/text: Wasn't interested in the nightlife but enjoyed a wander in the afternoon and found some nice little streets and views. Preferred Alfama for walking and exploring and phototaking.
reviews/12/text: We stayed at this wonderful hotel for 5 nights.  When we checked in early the suite wasn’t ready so we decided to have lunch upstairs on the outdoor terrace.  Our wait person was Ines and she was terrific. We subsequently met her almost every morning at breakfast. She gave us helpful suggestions about restaurants, fado shows and other things to do in Lisbon.  The young ladies at the Concierge were also extremely helpful.  We enjoyed seeing Inez’ smiling face first thing in the morning.  The staff went all out including the doormen and the front desk.  It was a wonderful experience.
reviews/13/text: Exploring this neighborhood was my favorite thing to do while in Lisboa. Such an unique area in all of European capital cities.
reviews/14/text: Beautiful streets with characteristic stone patterns in the sidewalks.  The people are friendly and there are lots of cute shops all over the place.
reviews/15/text:
We stayed at the Casa Das Janelas com vista and it was truly wonderful. A smallish boutique hotel  in Barrio Alto with beautifully eclectic interior design details. The downstairs large room does feel like your living room with open high end kitchen, lovely morning breakfast, honor bar, comfortable seating and lovely light. 

The most important part is the staff - friendly and knowledgeable, we were fortunate to speak with some of them while enjoying an evening whisky...we learned so much about Lisbon and enjoyed the time immensely. 

The view from our room was magical, and we will be staying at Casa Das Janelas again!
reviews/16/text: This historic district stands on one of the hills of Lisbon and is characterized by narrow and regular streets along which it is a pleasure to stroll. You cannot visit Lisbon without going to Alfama and Bairro Alto, it would be a visit that completely cut the history, folklore and liveliness of this city. In addition to walking along the streets that climb up this area, you can get to Bairro Alto by taking the fun, historic and often very crowded tram 28 or the Ascensor da Bica, a vintage funicular railway line about 250 m long that goes up from Rua de S. Paulo to Largo Calhariz or even using the Elevador da Gloria, a vintage funicular tramway. Using one of these historic vehicles represents an ideal introduction to the environment that you are going to visit and where, in addition to the pleasure of walking and stopping in some places, stand out the church of San Rocco, with its eight very richly decorated chapels, and the Miradouro Sao Pedro de Alcantara, from which you can enjoy a suggestive view of the Castelo de S. Jorge. Bairro Alto is no doubt one of the most interesting areas of Lisbon.
reviews/17/text:
“If you are looking for trouble - you came to the right place…”

Bairro Alto is one of Lisbon’s liveliest hood with dozens of bars, fado clubs, tattoo joints … happy hour is never far away.

In addition here are many very picturesque photo ops. Go, go, go.
reviews/17/title: In Bairro Alto, happy hour is never far away
reviews/18/text:
Excellent walking experience to learn the history, culture and architecture.
You need to be in relatively good shape due to the nature of the streets and different levels.
Comfortable walking footwear is a must
reviews/19/text: You go thru this neighborhood when you take the Tram. s hillside elevation. Bars , clubs , restaurants, and fado houses line the narrow alleys and streets.

address: Esplanada D. Carlos I Doca dos Olivais, Lisbon 1990-005 Portugal
animal_welfare_tag/msg_body: Click below for expert advice on animal welfare in tourism.
description:
Oceanário de Lisboa is one of the largest aquariums in Europe featuring over 15,000 marine creatures from 450 species. It is centered around one main central tank and several smaller habitats spread over two floors, and showcases both terrestrial and marine ecosystems. You can even spend a night here and sleep with sharks. The building 'floats' in a bay off Parque de Nacoes in eastern Lisbon—you can walk to the oceanarium via a walkway across the water. 

This attraction is a popular stop on hop-on hop-off bus tours in Lisbon which includes audio guides in several languages. 

– Tripadvisor

reviews/0/text:
In doors and nice if it's your first time in an aquarium.  Was very crowded, hard to watch, dark and a bit smelly. No supervising staff at site - a kid vomited and no one cleaned it. Little place to rest. Expensive. 
Had better experience at the Boston and the Jerusalem aquariums.  
But the kids enjoyed it, the store is lovely, there are water fountains you can play at outside for free.
reviews/0/title: Not the best, but if you never went to an aquarium it's ok
reviews/1/text: A four sided aquarium with four different climates, each with their own under water section, accessible from the downstairs area, with large windows into each tank, the center tank has many different kinds of fish, rays, and even sharks. Definitely worth a visit!
reviews/2/text: We had a wonderful time in Oceanário de Lisboa. It's very well organized and couldn't be more happy with this visit. I recommend arriving early in the morning as it can get very busy.
reviews/3/text: One of the best acquariums i have visited.we really enjoyed our visit.beautiful place to spend 2 hours.excellent experience
reviews/4/text: This is a great place to learn ocean biodiversities. although the place is not that big compared to the one in Singapore, it’s a nice place to visit. The cable car outside is a must try for a great view. Very recommended to bring your children here to learn about ocean biodiversity and environment. I love to see the cute otters and garden eel!
reviews/4/title: A nice place to learn about ocean biodiversities!
reviews/5/text: A fantastic way to spend a half-day in Lisbon. Utterly stunning! The aquarium is split into different sections with underwater and above water life.
reviews/6/text:
Visited the aquarium as it was listed a some of the top things to do whilst in Lisbon and I can see why. 
Could sit a watch the main tank for hours with the different species of fish, sharks & coral. 
Plenty of posts around to tell you information on each species. I was dubious about the otters, penguins being in a captive space but they explained the conservation and reasons why they were captive and helped put my mind at ease a little. 
Spent around 3 hours here which is a lot more than we thought. But you just find yourself standing and watching in silence for ages.
reviews/7/text: We spent over 5 hours at the oceanarium. The level of detail  showed a true commitment to conservation of our natural world. The huge water tank was mesmerising and very relaxing. The range of colour in the sea anemone was staggering and the sea otters were so endearing. Fabulous day. Worth every euro!
reviews/8/text: We schedule the visit for our children as it was their 1st time in such a large aquarium! Although you have to spend at least 2-3 hours we left full of memorable images and wide smiles in our children's face.
reviews/9/text: It was great! So beautiful, clean and animals are well looked after. Would recommend for everyone🤩 no matter what age. Februar was quiet and not so busy at all. Nice weather 19 degrees outside.
reviews/10/text: This experience was so unique and family friendly. A must see if going to Lisbon with toddlers and family. Conservation is tied through the whole experience.
reviews/11/text: This was a bit of an Uber ride from our hotel, but worth it.  The building is striking.  The exhibits/tanks flow nicely - lots and lots of huge tanks filled with all types of sea life.  It's a bit dark inside as you wend your way through the aquarium.  Big, bright gift shop and dining area at the end.  There's a cable car add-on we skipped that would most likely appeal to families with kids.  Worth spending a few hours here. Great photo/video opps!
reviews/12/text: The aquarium was mostly one large tank with multiple viewpoints around it, and a few other exhibits.  It was good for my two year old though, but if you don't need something kid friendly I would skip it.
reviews/12/title: Good for kids, but not as impressive as all the hype
reviews/13/text: The aquarium is one of the most beautiful designed aquarium I’ve been too. Anyone can enjoy it. The aquarium is located about 35 min from the city center. Meter taxi cost about £10.
reviews/14/text: This was the first time my girlfriend, who's in love with the sea got to contact with an oceanarium. It was a fantastic experience for both of us. The atmosphere inside is wonderful and so is the restaurant and the giftshop! Well worth the visit.
reviews/14/title: Beautiful place to go and have contact with nature
reviews/15/text: Excellent experience at the Oceanario. Absolutely recommended. A lot of different species of fishes.
reviews/16/text: Great visit for a rainy day.  The cafeteria food was excellent and well priced.  You can spend several hours here.  Very accessible by public transit.  Lots of security staff to make sure you don't do anything you're not supposed to.  It would be better if these people interacted with tourists to talk about the exhibits.  It would be better for both parties.
reviews/17/text: If you like to watch sea-life, this is the place for you. Everything from sea anemones to 3 metre-long sharks, lots of tropical species and interesting information/interactive areas and there is a strong message of climate change, how this is affecting the oceans, what effect it is having on fish and invertebrates around the world and what measures are being taken by scientists and conservationists to protect species. There is a huge central tank and windows at ground and upper level where you can watch the big fish glide past. It's a very calming experience. The fish must be well fed as I didn't witness any predatory activity in the 2 hours I spent there. Sea birds, seals and otters are also there and are close enough to touch, not that I would advise that. It was a quiet time when I went so I got the space to see more than I probably would have on a busy day. From central Lisbon, take the blue line (linha azul) on the Metro to Sta. Apolonia, then cross the road and take a 728 bus to the Oceanarium. There are shops and diners, so give yourself enough time to enjoy the experience fully.
reviews/18/text: Justin was our waiter and he was our amazing waiter !  I really thought that his energy was really good and he was very helpful when it came to choosing our food and everything!
reviews/19/text: On a very wet and windy day this was a great choice to visit, it is amazing to wander around and marvel at the stunning displays, there is so much to see and admire about the way the sea is presented. Also take time to sit and watch some of the videos that are playing explaining the work that the Oceanario is doing to protect our seas and its inhabitants.

reviews/0/text:
Amazing collection, beautiful location.
Spent 2 hours exploring it, and loved it. Lovely Cafe with a gardening a nice shop. Not expensive- and we recommend using an Uber to get there.
reviews/0/title: Magnificent! A must visit museum in Lisbon
reviews/1/text:
The museum has breathtaking displays of tiles and their history. A great collection unfortunately house in a building falling apart. The entrance is super cheap (5 Euros). It is not easily accessible, best to go by Uber. 
The staff who work at the museum are very whiling to answer more technical questions, very professional individuals, with the exception of the very rude security chap who "guards" the entrance of the gift shop! (give someone a uniform and you may unleash pure ego)
reviews/2/text: Tile museum was one of the highlights of our Lisbon trip.  The murals were huge and full of colorful tile. The convent setting was also beautiful. It’s a little out of way relative to the usual Lisbon highlights but it was 4 euro Bolt ride from Rossio.  The tiles were extraordinary in their beauty.  The collection is extensive.  The guilded altars also impressive.  Not to be missed!
reviews/3/text: So much fun learning the history of the beautiful Portuguese tile.  Highly recommend a visit!  We did the self tour and had no problem following the exhibits
reviews/4/text: Sure it's not a cathedral or palace or castle- but visit, and give yourself a few hours to enjoy. You may think you see plenty of tiles everywhere in the city but here are the best. The museum is located along the river and we walked from the Metro stop to the museum, not knowing ahead it was a rundown area with encampments of people living in tents and under tarps. So take the bus (not subway) which stops right in front of the museum. It has a nice inner courtyard with a restaurant. We recommend this as a must-see.
reviews/5/text: Ignore the snooty reviews saying this museum is not worth visiting. It is SO worth a visit. We got lost hiking up from the metro station, but even with that hiccup, found the museum to be incredible. The tilework, of course, is the star, but the church in which it is located is equally spectacular, and the museum is expansive. I wish we could have stayed longer in order to really take it all in. Definitely worth going to, and frankly good enough to warrant another visit to Lisbon!
reviews/6/text:
If your time  visiting  Lisboa is limited,  the Tile Museum might not be a "must-see". But if you are going to be in town for more than a few days, the museum is well worth a visit for 2 hours.
The official app for the museum did not my download. That was very frustrating, as I really wanted to learn about the tiles on display. They also ran out of English brochures.
Just  a few tiles had placards next to them with explanations in English, so understanding where the tiles were originally installed was lacking.
The tiles on display are beautiful, the craftsmanship beyond belief.
The top floor was most interesting to me, as more "modern" tiles were on display. Also on the top floor were tiles that showed the skyline of Lisboa before the earthquake toppled the city.
The museum is easily reach via a public bus, no need to drive here.
The gift shop had some really neat modern themed tiles. Unfortunately I did not buy one, wish I had.
reviews/6/title: Portugal is known for tiles, so visit the museum if times allows.
reviews/7/text:
We drove here and parked on a random side street (R. Me. Deus), right before the museum was due to open, and walked up to the entrance.  Much of that street has parking on it (I think free but I'm forgetting) but it does fill up quickly with other museum people. We didn't use the bus but there's a bus stop almost immediately outside the museum.  There's a slight bend in the road and once you're past that, almost to the bridge, there's a metal gate opening on your left and you go through that to get to the entrance of the museum.  A fairly large line formed behind us after we got to the door so we weren't the only ones on a random Tuesday in April who decided to go!

Granted, we had 2 toddlers with us so we weren't stopping to read too much or admire too long but we were in and out in about an hour.  There is so much more than just tiles on a wall - whole large almost Church-like adorned rooms.

In my notes for this place, I had this marked as a 'maybe' to go to and after having been there, I'd still place it in that category for future goers.  It's the only tile museum in the world (do we really need more than one?) but given that Portugal is so well-known for their tiles, it seems logical that Lisbon would have this museum.  It felt criminal to NOT go see it while we were there since we may never be back.  Only being €5/ea, price isn't a huge motivating reason not to go.  I have noted they open at 10am (which was consistent when we we got in) and closes at 6pm, Tuesday-Sunday.

Apparently the top thing to see here is on the top floor - the 74ft panel showing the Lisbon skyline before the 1755 earthquake.  We thought it was really cool! Not our favorite room but pretty close!

I rated this a 4/5 because for a tile museum, it is amazing.  It's just not a must-do for Lisbon and therefore, I docked 1 star.
reviews/7/title: Squarely on the "Maybe" List for Lisbon
reviews/8/text: Take bus #728 from Cais de Sodré, watch for the Lidl supermarket sign on left, get off and walk up past Lidl. Our favorite museum of three days up in Lisboa.  An ancient convent repurposed as an amazing and evocative museu.
reviews/9/text: Not a must-see, sorry Trip Advisor. Some of the conserved tile segments are, indeed, beautiful and worth seeing. But the museum experience is so diminished by: 1) it closes at lunchtime but the industrial neighborhood is in the outskirts of town so there is nowhere for visitors to have lunch , relax, etc. You have to plan your trip around the staff lunch, amazing since they need to attract more visitors and revenue, not turn people away. Literally, when we visited, they ushered hundreds of people out at 1 pm, presumably so the staff could eat lunch, To make matters worse, the sign at the entrance and several on-line sites indicate the museum stays open and doesn't close. We only learned of the closing when guards alerted us. 2) the physical facility is in decline - bathroom hand dryers, faucets, audio APP, etc. don't work, 3) the on-site cafe is disappointing, a few sandwiches and expresso, and the adjacent garden is shaded for summer sun but in off-season is just gloomy. The museum could be so special, a genuine international gem. Instead, it seems to be spiraling downward do to lack of funds and inertia.
reviews/10/text: Some lovely tiles on display in a lovely building. If you are keen on the tiles used traditional architecture certainly a great place to visit, albeit difficult to locate as not well signposted (and the several locals didn’t seem to know where it was either.
reviews/10/title: Great but not easy to find
reviews/11/text: LOVED this museum.  It's incredible the number of displays of historical tiles they have here.  Just gorgeous.
reviews/12/text: Fascinating history of tile production in Lisbon, along with so many excellent examples of tile work. Also has a floor dedicated to the young people keeping this proud tradition alive and evolving. Absolutely a must-see!
reviews/13/text:
We made it a point to visit the tile museum while visiting Lisbon. Tile is an important aesthetic in Portugal and the museum was highly rated. On the plus side, there were some very impressive displays of tiles. The highlight of the museum is the panorama of Lisbon done in old tiles. It was fun locating places we had visited on the ‘map’. I think the museum is absolutely worth the effort to visit – but there are a few things I wanted to see but didn’t: There was almost nothing on how tiles are made, nothing about the progression of colors available and which chemicals were needed to make the colors, and very little on the early blue and white tiles. The gift shop has a surprising dearth of tiles to purchase.

The museum isn’t really near anything. But when you are there, you are a very quick walk from the Bordalo II Monkey and just a little bit further to the Bordalo II Frog.
reviews/14/text: Walking to the museum there is little signage and we expected the building's exterior to be in a better state of repair, but don't let this dissuade you from visiting. A 5€ ticket let's you gain access to multiple rooms and floors highlighting the evolution of tile work in Lisbon including a panorama of the city itself. There's also a complete gilded chapel and reliquary that shares the building. I was hoping to have more displays on the Moorish influence of the art form, but this was perhaps captured in some of the non-translated descriptions. There was a large Christian influence. We noticed a conservator in a small workshop and we're also slightly disappointed we couldn't find more information on azulejo restoration. The café is as beautiful as the exhibits, and we enjoyed lattés and a slice of carrot cake. There's a draft from the courtyard (housing a number of small garden beds and peculiar pigeons) so be sure to close the doors behind you when deciding to enjoy time outside. The gift shop and chapel are closed briefly between noon and 2pm so be sure to plan accordingly. The gift shop had a number of beautiful things and even books in English! I would return in a heartbeat.
reviews/15/text: Absolutely stunning! So much to see and learn. We loved this. An old convent , now a museum.  Exceptional building, tiles and staff. The chapel is jaw dropping.
reviews/16/text: This is a wonderful museum. We absolutely adored it, the tiles are incredible and there is so much history in this place. Big recommendation!
reviews/17/text:
It was easy getting to the National Tile Museum from the Santa Apolonia cruise ship port because bus 759 stops at the bus stop, Cais Lingueta, which is directly opposite this port, and also stops at the National Tile Museum.  This route took about 7 minutes. The entrance to the museum is at the side of the church (see google maps). I stayed for 1 ½ hours. Note the hours for the Museum as they are not continuously open during the day. There is a covered, shady courtyard café for sandwiches (2E), coffee (1E), pastries, and a gift shop which didn’t have any inexpensive tiles (under 5E) to buy as souvenirs. 
 
Inside the museum, the tiles were displayed on walls on 2 floors. The tiles had bilingual labels including English which included the year and location where the tile had been placed. An information board briefly explained the history of Portuguese tiles -  the designs used in Islamic and European motifs, where they were used, and the preferred colors.  A display case showed the steps in creating and coloring the tiles. The tiles on display ranged from single tiles to 2x2, 4x4, etc., to wall/carpet tiles framed with a frieze/frame. While the Islamic inspired tiles had interesting geometric designs, the ones with European inspired motifs caught my attention with their landscape and daily life scenes. One of the carpet tiles using a European motif showed the wedding of a chicken with the chicken in the carriage being driven by animal coachman. What a laugh! Of course, the church wanted wall tile carpets with religious scenes and these too were on display. The amount of tiles on display was staggering! There was also a short documentary video on the history of Portuguese tiles showing many insitu. 

 From the 2nd story there was a balcony that allowed visitors to view the interiors of the church, Igreja Madre Deus, and then after actually enter the church. It was eye candy! Not only were the lower portions of the walls tiled with religious scenes, above those tiles and, even, the ceiling was covered in gilt framed paintings. Gilt details abounded around the altar. It was great to see the wall tiles insitu.

The entrance fee was a reasonable 2.50E for seniors. This was a memorable visit to see such a variety of tile collected in one building.
reviews/17/title: Splendid array of tiles plus a chance to see them insitu in the church
reviews/18/text:
We had a fabulous morning at the tile museum, it was a very wet and stormy day so a perfect place to escape the rain! The fact it’s in a old monastery just made it even more spectacular.

We were a bit disappointed there were no English guides left (we were able to work some stuff out using the French pamphlet! I tried to download the audio guide but there was no Wi-Fi and it was very slow on my 5G so I gave up (someone else told me they managed to do it and weren’t impressed). 

The cafe was quite small, but had good coffee and fresh orange amongst the yummy cakes! The shop was good, but the staff were a bit grumpy!
reviews/18/title: A really well sized museum filled with gorgeous tiles!
reviews/19/text: I throughly enjoyed this museum. The tiles themselves were gorgeous, and the church embellishment was eye-popping. It was also interesting to learn about how the tile-making process changes through the centuries. With so many tiles on buildings all over Lisbon, this museum gave me more appreciation for what I was seeing every day.  It’s a little off the beaten path relative to other tourist-oriented sites, but it’s worth it.  It has a nice cafe so you can recharge. I wish it had a bigger gift shop if you can believe it! They didn’t have a postcard of my favorite tile piece. Anyway, go!
subcategory_ranking: #24 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Lisbon Portugal
description: Wonderful sights delight walkers at every turn in this culturally rich and charming part of Lisbon, which through its architecture reminds visitors of its Visigothic roots, Arabic influence and fishing port heritage.
name: Alfama

ranking: #1 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #1 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Old and kinda interesting, but this part of town is way overrated. There are nicer places to see in Lisbon.
reviews/1/text: Walked through this charming neighbourhood on a guided tour. Later, stopped at a restaurant for lunch. Also had a sip of homemade sour cherry liquor (liquor de Ginga) from a stall set up in front of a home. There are many things to see (e.g. the photo exhibit mounted on walls of people in the neighbourhood community); had a unique experience walking through this historic neighbourhood.
reviews/2/text: For such an atmospheric city, Alfama is perhaps the most atmospheric quarter of all.   Set on steep hills, it offers endless perspectives of steps, alleys and byways.  It's mostly pedestrian but at times an ancient tram rumbles by.   Every so often a narrow street breaks out into lovely views (miradouras) of the city.  Best tackled in dry weather however because the cobbled lanes could be slippery.
reviews/3/text: Meander at your leisure and see the views and eat and drink local foods. Lots of tourists here but it is a cute neighborhood.
reviews/3/title: cute neighborhood with a lot of eateries
reviews/4/text: Alfama is one of the oldest districts of Lisbon and it is a must in anyone's itinerary.  The streets are steep and not for the fainthearted but a visit is well worth the effort.  There is a plentiful choice of cafes and souvenir shops along the route to  the Sao Jorge Castle.  This particular castle dates back to the eleventh century and there are spectacular views of the city from its walls.  There are peacocks in the grounds of the castle and they certainly make it a colourful occasion.  In many senses this is the real Lisbon.  Lisbon Cathedral is also en route.
reviews/5/text: We had a great time walking around Alfama district ! We were recommended to explore this part of the city and we couldn't ask for more. Original is the best word to describe Alfama !
reviews/6/text: A wonderful way to spend a few hours wandering streets, views and tasting . Talk with wonderful shop owners and examine lovely old tiles
reviews/7/text: Alfama is the most beautiful quaint neighborhood in Lisbon. Its  colorful buildings decorated with beautiful tiles and sometimes graffiti, its small art shops, cafes are all not to be missed seeing. We loved the Azulejo by NUNES! They have several shops and it is a great place to buy gifts and souvenirs. Highly recommended!
reviews/8/text: Narrow streets,many local restaurants.so much to see .This is the most beautiful part of lisbon with alot of history.
reviews/9/text: Anyone who knows the area will know that it is hilly and this hotel is perched a good way up the slope. So it is not for people with mobility issues or those who struggle with a bit of a climb. The staff were outstanding and could not be more helpful. Anyone familiar with my previous reviews will know that I have a quirky thing about soft poached eggs and this place excels at them. Great breakfast, excellent dinner and great location.
reviews/9/title: Not for those with mobility issues
reviews/10/text: A must for visitors to the city. Clearly built to stop the progress of enemies attacking from the sea.
reviews/11/text: Full of history, interesting shops, restaurants and architecture, this neighborhood is not to be missed!
reviews/11/title: One of the best Neighborhoods to Visit in Lisbon
reviews/12/text: beautiful architecture and buildings,  it is a very difficult area to walk around but it is worth it more great views of the area
reviews/13/text: Go with a chook chook, panoramic views, excellent guide (pink chook chook lady - excellent English and knowledge).
reviews/14/text: We loved staying in and wandering through Alfama and found wonderful coffee/pastry shops and restaurants in our wanderings.  While not a great place for those who have mobility issues, you don't need to be in top shape if you just take your time.
reviews/14/title: Wonderful "old world" Portugal with great restaurants
reviews/15/text: Much to see and do, but beware beggars and pickpockets. Great for food and local culture, with so much to like.
reviews/16/text: Lovely old part of Lisbon, narrow quaint streets full of authentic restaurants. Lovely views overlooking parts of Lisbon,
reviews/16/title: Stunning old part of Lisbon with quaint narrow streets and authentic restaurants
reviews/17/text:
Narrow & steep charming streets, if you love hiking, brace yourself 😊 There are many local restaurants in these streets of Alfama. I mostly travelled through most of attractions city centre walking. If you do not like walking or unable to walk for whatever reason, there are alternatives. There is an option of tram, however keep in mind it’s busy most of the time. They say February is off season but i found it busy. I didn’t take the tram as i found it really jam packed. Another alternative is Tuk Tuk. 
I would highly recommend the Sao Jorge Castle and the spots around the castle from where you can view the whole city. It is mesmerizing. Some of the best spots to take pictures!
reviews/18/text: Favourite part of my Lisbon visit... So many little scenes and moments that capture your attention and make you happy. Some lovely streets and views over the city.
reviews/19/text: Historic walkable area with many interesting twists and turns, great views. Bring comfortable shoes and expect a lot of hills.
subcategory_ranking: #1 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Avenida de Berna 45A, Lisbon 1067-001 Portugal
description: With works ranging from Antiquity to the early 20th century, the Founder’s Collection comprises more than six thousand pieces gathered throughout Calouste Sarkis Gulbenkian’s life, including Egyptian Art, Greco-Roman Art, Islamic Arts, Painting, Sculpture and European Decorative Arts. Works by great masters such as Rubens, Rembrandt, Turner, Degas and René Lalique’s largest set of jewels are just a few examples of what can be found in one of the best private collections in the world. Besides the Founder’s Collection, the Calouste Gulbenkian Museum is also comprised by the Modern Collection, which features the largest and most complete collection of modern and contemporary Portuguese Art. The Calouste Gulbenkian Museum is surrounded by one of the most emblematic modern gardens in Portugal, open all year. The Museum offers a wide range of facilities to improve the visitor’s experience: three cafeterias overlooking the Garden, a museum shop, free cloackroom service and free Wi-Fi.
name: Calouste Gulbenkian Museum
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Gulbenkian Museum & Surroundings Private Tour With Locals
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Lisbon Hop-On Hop-Off Tour: 48-Hour in Belém & Modern Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon All-in-One Hop-On Hop-Off Bus and Tram Tour with River Cruise
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Lisbon Self-Guided Audio Tour
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Lisbon: Book A Local Host For 6 Hours
ranking: #14 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #14 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: The Art Museum in Lisbon is a collection collected by entrepreneur Galust Gulbenkian. It was opened in 1969. About 1000 exhibits: Rubens, Rembrandt, Turner, Monet, Degas, Rodin. Ancient Egyptian and Mesopotamian monuments, antique ceramics and numismatics, furniture collection... I recommend it.
reviews/1/text: What a wonderful surprise this museum was. A right gem. Discount entry with our bus/tram/metro. Room after room of the most exquisite colection. This man new what to colect. Best to go on the bus the metro was tricky
reviews/2/text:
We visited the Calouste Gulbenkian Museum on a chilly February day. It was a great choice for an afternoon. The museum is housed in a fabulous modernist building designed by the Portuguese architects- Ruy d’ Athouguia, ALberto Pessoa and Pedro Cid. The building sits on a beautifully landscaped 7.5 hectare urban site a few subway stops from the center of Lisbon. The campus is a serene escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. 

The collection is the personal collection of the benefactor Calouste Gulbenkian. It spans time from Egyptian art through the Impressionist period with a focus on Islamic art. The Islamic section is particularly notable for the huge windows that allow the natural surroundings of the site to complement the art. In addition to the main collection is there is a fabulous Lalique room. Gulbenkian was, apparently, the largest single collector of Lalique items.

Downstairs is a nice cafeteria style eating area that also opens onto the landscaped surroundings. 

We loved it.
reviews/2/title: Excellent blend of landscape, art and architecture
reviews/3/text: Definitely worth the admission price.  I was there with a friend and we  will return we make it  back to Lisbon.  So much to see and extremely well curated.  Loved the Lalique - small but beautiful collection. Amazing Islamic art. If you want to do it in bite-sized pieces, if you're here for an extended stay ,then go on a Sunday after 2.00pm (I think - please check) and it's free entry to the main museum.  One unusual aspect is that they don't mind you taking pics. Highly recommended.
reviews/4/text:
This is a gem in Lisbon that can be enjoyed equally by the art aficionados and anyone with a keen eye and a modicum of intellectual curiosity!

At €10 it is also a great bargain!

The collection is amazing!  One of the great things is it is not so large you are overwhelmed. The size of the Museum as well as the display of the pieces makes it easy to see a vast area of world history and culture. If you appreciate “nice” things you’ll love this place. 

Don’t skip this thinking “I’ve been to the Louvre or another well known place”. This distills multiple buildings and floors into an easy to absorb and appreciate feast!

Get there….
reviews/5/text: This museum was not on my Lisbon must see list, but it was recommended by my boyfriend's brother. It hosts the vast art and artifacts collections of the business man Calouste Gulbenkian. It was such a surprising experience seening exhibits from different cultures, from the West to the East. The museum also has a cafeteria, where you can take a good lunch after seing the museum.
reviews/6/text: Deservedly acclaimed as one of Europe's finest private museums, the Gulbenkian offers visitors a carefully curated tour of world civilizations, laid out in a series of beautifully arranged rooms that span the length of the equally impressive modernist building. Every item, be it a Grecian ceramic or a Central Asian textile, is a masterpiece. Though admirably selective in its displays, the museum still offers quite a lot to see, and seeing everything can prove exhausting, so it's recommended to focus on areas of particular interest, or limit oneself to any of the rotating special exhibitions. There's a cafe meant to provide a respite, but until new management makes ordering and serving more efficient, best to avoid it.
reviews/7/text: Very nice museum, beautifully organized, and lovingly displayed artefacts. The René Lalique gallery alone is well worth the price of admission. Friendly staff, nice gift shop.
reviews/8/text: Awesome and surprisingly good display of artefacts - lots of good material set out in a useful way that it can be appreciated without being overwhelming
reviews/9/text:
Every piece in this museum was bought by Calouste Gulbenkian. 
This was his personal collection left by his estate after his death, so the fact that tickets cost 10 euro is a bit much.
Still the curators did a good job, there was even a special exhibit of just Egyptian artifacts to visit
reviews/9/title: Amazing museum, go when its free
reviews/10/text: We arrived here in the late afternoon (4pm), there was a handful of people. The ticket normally cost 10€, but they have discount for people under 30 and over 60 so it cost half of the price (we are student under 30). The exposition was  alluring - there were plenty of historical and artistic utensils, carpets, jewelry, coins, painting and statues. This place was really agreeable although they were closing kind of soon (6pm), so we had to rush our visit because of the closing.
reviews/11/text: Well curated collection, especially Islamic art and textiles.  The decorative arts on display were outstanding. We arrived late in the day and so didn't spend as much time as I would have liked. I was grateful that it was easy to call a cab from the location as it is a bit out of the way.
reviews/12/text:
This is a wonderful museum. We were there on a weekday morning. While the personal collection by Calouste Gelbenkian is stunning the grounds and gardens outside are delightful. We enjoyed watching the people of Lisbon picnic, play with their children and lovers talking quietly.

Gelbenkian was an Amenian-British businessman who organized the exploration and export of Middle Eastern Oil. He became one of the richest men in the world in the early 20th century. He collected beautiful art works in Syria, Iraq ,Turkey  and the Far East then added European art to his holdings including works of Rembrandt, Rubens and the furniture of French 17th-18th century royalty.

About 1,000 pieces are on display inside the museum, he left over 6,000 pieces to the collection.
reviews/13/text: Certainly, the best museum we have ever visited. The collections were quite outstanding. Amazing what  Guilbenkian was able to collect for the world to see
reviews/14/text: Gulbenkian had a deep pocket and seemed to be able to acquire the best of the best in some areas of the decorative arts. This is not an "exhibition" but a museum displaying the personal tastes and collection of one individual. There is nothing curated about it beyond assembling related items in the same space. So we have paintings around some of the walls, hanging textiles, wonderful large rugs on elevated platforms on the floor, a collection of unusual silver, ceramics from different parts of the world, a room devoted to the work of Rene Lalique  and so on. Each subject collection is not particularly large, but there are some truly wonderful objects on display in each collection. This is my preferred style of museum: there is a lot to see but it is in easily digested bites. My only criticism is that most of the display notices are wholly inadequate giving little more than a date and a name. We spent a really enjoyable two hours at the museum and finished at the cafe/restaurant which offers a reasonable selection of food and drink  with tables both inside and outside.
reviews/14/title: A smallish museum with some outstanding quality exhibits
reviews/15/text:
With a background in the arts, Gulbenkian has always been a name I'm familiar with, so of course this was always going to be on my Lisbon agenda. 

The building is quite spectacular, and is probably the biggest highlight. The gardens; clearly once cherished now feel a bit run down and shabby. It's great that the grounds are free, and lots of local families were enjoying the space, which was nice. 

The collection itself, being of someone's distinct personal tastes and a product of trends they lived through, is a bit hit & miss. It's certainly eclectic, so there'll be something for everyone, but as an exhibition it just doesn't quite click together. 

A good place to escape the crowds and have a slow meander round. The staff however weren't hugely welcoming and were more interested chatting amongst themselves than helping visitors. 

Evidently the cafe is good, but the queue was obscenely long, so we gave it a miss.
reviews/15/title: A very personal collection...and a bit hit & miss.
reviews/16/text: Very eclectic and intresting collrction- great combination of east and west art .  Great coffe and park nearby. Dont miss it.
reviews/16/title: One of the best meusiums in the wrold
reviews/17/text: Spent about 4-5 hours here, which included eating at the cafe, taking pictures of just about everything, and a walk around the garden. The app is terrible; just read the descriptions on the app, instead of listening to them (seems like most don't load correctly). The modern museum is currently closed. Restaurant was okay. Definitely some beautiful pieces of art worth seeing.
reviews/18/text: This was our favourite place to visit in Lisbon, and incredibly inexpensive (5 euro entry for pensioners). There is wonderful art from Roman, Greek, China Japan and Europe including wonderful paintings, furniture, tiles and the 'jewel in the crown' a fabulous collection of Lalique.
reviews/19/text: There is so much to see here and enjoy - from ancient Egypt to 20th Century masterpieces. My wife and I spent the best part of a day in the museum including an excellent lunch in their restaurant (very reasonably priced).
reviews/19/title: If you are interested in art - don't miss this
subcategory_ranking: #14 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Largo do Carmo, 1200-092, Lisbon 1200-092 Portugal
description: The Carmo Archaeological Museum is situated in the ruins of the old Church of Santa Maria do Carmo, founded in 1389 by D. Nuno Alvares Pereira. This church was known as one of the most beautiful Gothic temples in Lisbon until the earthquake of 1755, which caused serious damage to the building and destroyed almost all of its religious-artistic contents. Its re-construction began in an experimental Gothic style in 1756 and stopped in 1834, when the religious orders were abolished in Portugal. In 1863, royal architect, Joaquim Possidonio da Silva, founded the Portuguese Civil Architects Association. About one year later, in 1864, the Carmo Archaeological Museum was installed there for the storage and display of important sculptures from old ruined buildings. Curing the 19th, 20th and 21st centuries. the museum houses a collection which dates from Pre-History to the present day and shows the way people have thought and felt in different areas of culture throughout the ages.
name: Carmo Archaeological Museum
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Be a local in Lisbon - Private Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Mon Ami Burguês - Lisbon City Tour by Tuk Tuk
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon Self-Guided Audio Tour
