ranking: #45 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #45 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Such a striking landmark right in the middle of the city. Being inside the ruined structure is very moving as you can see the destruction caused by the earthquake. The museum is interesting and the short film worth watching as it describes the history of the monastery and its place in the city’s history
reviews/1/text:
When we went in April 2022, it was a Thursday around 11:30am and while not empty, it was definitely not even 1/5 full.  Tickets were €5/adult and our not-quite-2 year old twins were free.  They are closed Sundays and the hours vary slightly depending upon the time of year.  Most people recommend less than an hour here so we budgeted 45 minutes and that was about perfect.  Just enough time to get inside, run around, read some of the signage, pet some kitties and take off.

This was on our must-do list for Lisbon once I was done researching but it certainly was not something I had heard about prior to doing any research.  We saw a lady doing some sweeping and my daughter was super interested in it.  The lady was so sweet to her as my daughter tried to help her sweep.  We saw a kitty lounging in the sunlight, taking in all the pets that people offered.  They have fake grass laid out, which is pretty smart, given the number of people and the ability (or non-ability) to maintain it there. There are a few mirrors leaning against the columns (maybe for helping take fun pictures??) that seemed impractical and dangerous.  While we didn't go at night time, there are a number of lights on the ground for uplighting and we could see this beautifully lit up at night from our hotel room.

The slightly irritating thing about this place is that you are told it's stroller friendly but that's only once you're inside the church.  To get inside, even down to the ticket counter, there are a set of steps.  I literally do not know if there's any other way to get down to the ticket counter (which is at the entrance to the church) other than to go down there half-moon shaped steps.  So we had to carry our stroller down those.  Then there is theoretically a wheelchair lift to go from where you get your tickets into the church but with just a stroller, we're not going to use it.  So, again, we lifted our stroller down the stairs to get into the church.
reviews/2/text: We walked by the museum one day and I’m so glad we stopped in! A great experience for all ages, we had a 4 year old, 6 year old and adults ranging in age. Kids were free, adults only €5. There is an indoor area with a wide range of artifacts including a mummy and several tombs. It’s not so large it takes all day, but there are a few rooms with a variety of things to check out, The outside area is beautiful! The ruins are really fun to see for adults and kids and make for some great pictures. There is also a resident cat who roams the grounds. I would definitely recommend as a quick stop in Central Lisbon. Walk around the outside as well, and find the quick and easy bridge to the viewing platform of the Santa Justa lift. (Much better than the line to take it up!)
reviews/3/text: Very interesting place to visit, even if you dont like history. The ruins are amazing, and within them, there are various antiquities from the area and beyond. There is a inside part which even more artifacts from tombs to mummies to carving of stones etc. Do not miss the cinematic experience at the end. That is very well done, done in native tongue and English. The graphics and the story are really top notch, with the pictures being fitted perfectly within the large wall.
reviews/4/text: We really liked this museum - lots to see but not overwhelming.  Five rooms take you from about 2500BC to much more recent history, with just about everything labeled in English.  The old church was mostly destroyed in the earthquake of 1755 so it is especially interesting to see the ruins. Some restoration work is going on now but still well worth visiting.
reviews/5/text: Only 5 Euros to get in - worth it. Gorgeous architectural details on the building and artifacts they’ve preserved. Some of the rooms contain gorgeous tile work showing the end of Jesus’ life. Great quiet place to spend some time in the middle of the hustle and bustle downtown.
reviews/6/text: Ruins and gothic architecture lovers will enjoy this site. It’s a bit underwhelming for me. Apart from the  outer structure, I wasn’t too impressed. The artefacts were not much. It’s not free with the “Lisbon card” you only get 20% off. (€1)
reviews/7/text:
Destroyed in the Lisbon earthquake, only the roof collapsed leaving all the walls intact 
There is a museum attached which contains an eclectic collection of items salvaged from the church and excavations from the site
There is a light show of an evening that our guide said was quite spectacular
reviews/8/text: unique building (or what's left of it) they did a wonderful job preserving/restoring this site. There's a small museum behind the gates with glass floors where you can see a bit of the old structure. The courtyard is converted into a bar/restaurant with nice views of the city
reviews/9/text: great place to visit.One of the places i liked the most in Lisbon.Very affordable price and interesting. Beautiful surrounding, somehow gives u very piece full  feeling. if u will visit watch the sound and visual installation they show. ( other countries would charge extra probably)
reviews/10/text: If you enjoy gothic architecture and art, this is the place to go. While the convent was destroyed by a fire in the 1770s, they had done a great job in preserving the artifacts and facade of the convent. It is a small museum but you can easily spend almost an hour here! :)
reviews/11/text: They've taken the ruins of an old church and turned it into a home for a very impressive collection of relics from all over Portugal. Very interesting and worth the line outside to visit. They also hold theater performances in the main area of the church--would be a very spectacular place to see a show.
reviews/12/text:
This is a ruined church with a tragic story. It was full of worshippers on November the first, 1755 when an earthquake struck Lisbon and the roof fell in on everybody. Little wonder, the city kept the ruins as a memorial. I think to fully appreciate and "feel" the place, you need to know the back story. It's incredibly sad.
What you find today is the remains of the medieval church with many of the arches still intact but otherwise the sky right above you. I love walking around it and it's very photographic.
It's got popular with tourists so the queues have got longer and getting those intimate shots with nobody in the background has got harder. But still very much worth a visit.
reviews/13/text: The beautiful framework that remains here after a past earthquake is a lovely place to gaze upon. The museum itself is a strange compilation, but keep in mind that is a collection of objects that were saved when the religious institutions of Portugal were dissolved. I struggled a bit with the overt display of the Peruvian mummies as well as the other prehistoric South American artifacts, as their provenance may be suspect.
reviews/14/text: If you love ruins and a great historical story, this is a great site to visit. As such a person, I'm glad I went! You can easily spend less than an hour here. Just beware of the strange inside exhibit; I'm not really sure why there were gruesome Peruvian mummies there? I was just taken aback, but some visitors were visibly shocked and upset by these.
reviews/14/title: Great visit for someone who loves ruins!
reviews/15/text:
The old ruins are worth a visit during the day. There isn't too much to see but for the price, its worth stopping in for 30 to 45 minutes if you're in the area.

What is worth a visit is their evening presentation light show inside the church. This only runs Wednesday to Saturday nights and starts at 9.30pm and lasts for about an hour. It's beautifully done. Ask for a stool when you enter as it's a long time to stand or to sit on the floor.
reviews/16/text: It is perhaps a little smaller than I had thought before going, but it was interesting. The video about the history was good and if you’re into architecture I think some of the finds were quite important
reviews/17/text: Numerous hills or take a cab. I did not visit during the day but at night, Lisbon under the stars.  Packed with a lot of people. Projection show that was more artistic than a wow, bang. Educational and artistic. Come with a seat/chair. I thought the entire roof would be projected back on but only the walls. Took a minute to leave because of the amount of people.
reviews/18/text: One of the best museum experiences in Lisbon. Come and see what remains of one of the great religious structures pre-earthquake and come see some special treasures.  History and art.  And then have a coffee in the square outside.
reviews/19/text:
Carmo Archaeological Museum is one of the top tourist attraction at the center of Lisbon.  The entrance fee is 4 Euro.

The site and the museum is a church ruin which was destroyed during the 1755 earthquake.  The ceiling of the church collapsed but the structure of the church is still there.  

There is not a lot of description of the display so I have no clue of most of the items there.  Nevertheless it is a nice visit and I learned a little bit more about Lisbon and Portugal.

There is a washroom / toilet in the building.
reviews/19/title: Kind of small but good to visit
subcategory_ranking: #45 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Lisbon Portugal
description: This is the fashionable shopping district in Lisbon.
name: Chiado
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Best of Lisbon Guided Walking Tour

ranking: #28 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #28 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text:
We have just returned from a two night stay in Lisbon en route to a stay with friends further south.
We thoroughly enjoyed our stay in this beautiful and interesting city.
Lisbon is a very walkable city albeit with some challenging inclines. You must explore the Alfama district but be prepared to get lost then be enthralled by views over the city below.  
We used the Metro and Main Line Train to visit Belem but otherwise walked everywhere, covering 12miles in the day. The history and viewing the heritage sites are well worth the exercise.
There are many excellent cafes, bars and restaurants all reasonably priced. We had a memorably delicious evening meal at the famous Sao Bento steak restaurant. Go there if you can.
Can't wait to go back.
reviews/0/title: A beautiful, interesting and walkable city.
reviews/1/text:
Amazing city , friendly people most of them.
Cheaper price than other cities in europe , very good transportation so you can go every where  by metro or bus or train & delicious food especially seafood.
reviews/2/text: One of my favorite neighborhoods in the city. Lot of shopping and restaurants around. The block was so alive! With locals and tourists
reviews/3/text:
Chiado is one of Lisbon’s many picturesque hoods that will keep the camera in your smartphone busy.

Fine old squares, beautiful buildings, humming trams, aristocratic people and tramps…

Skip one of the other major sights of the city and spend an hour or two walking around in cool Chiado.
reviews/3/title: Cool Chiado - your smartphone will have to do overtime
reviews/4/text: This is a very nice area. Didn't spend much time in it (no time to shop), but we stopped for coffee and admired the architecture and monuments (especially Praça Luís de Camões that separates Chiado from Bairro Alto).
reviews/4/title: Beautiful, with plenty to see and do.
reviews/5/text: Part of our walk. Nice area but least favorite of things we saw and experienced in Lisbon. Right down the hill from the Bairro area.  Natural area to see on your stroll.
reviews/6/text: The picture here appears to be of Praca Luis de Camoes, which seems to be the heart of Chiado.  We rented an apartment right on this square...Chiado seems to be the heart of Lisbon's activity...restaurants and shops around every corner and close to everything--the famous 28 Tram car runs right through the square.  Be prepared to walk up and down hills on cobblestones and if you drive the  streets are cobblestone.  If you stay elsewhere you are not seeing the heartbeat of the city.
reviews/7/text: Lots of restaurants and high end shopping. Walk the streets up the hills too for views. The old elevator looks like something from Budapest. I bought clothes from Mango right next to it and got the same views on the 4th floor. No cost , no waiting in lines.
reviews/7/title: Mango Clothing Store Next to Santa Justa elevator has same views
reviews/8/text: This is a cool neighborhood in Lisbon. There are a lot of shops, especially the more high end ones. It's also famous for nightlife where people really spend time on the street around the bars.
reviews/9/text:
Chiado is a very lively neighborhood, set on the first western hill from the central Commercio square, but before the Barrio Alto district.
The area boosts with shops, from ordinary to very elegant and unusual, tons of bars and restaurants and a lot of interesting street performers.
I'd advise coming around dusk as it gets more lively after the day heat.
reviews/10/text: This is another Lisbon area that many might disagree but it is marginal in my view, somewhat run down, dirty and to a certain extent seedy.  i would have hated to visit before the "renovation".
reviews/11/text: Shopping, tourist attractions, restaurants, coffee shops, nightlife and more!  Busy and fun.  Lively and lot's to do.  Has a great atmosphere with lot's of character.  Just be careful in isolated roads late at night or early morning.  There are some sketchy characters around.  I was offered drugs a few times in the middle of the day!  Fine otherwise.
reviews/12/text: Wonderful neighborhood full of high end shopping, lots of food and bars and some splendid architecture.  It is in the middle of a lot of the attractions of the city and has its own Metro station.  We once rented an apartment here.
reviews/13/text: Old cafes and bookstores, elegant shops, theaters and historic buildings make Chiado in Lisbon one of the most popular neighborhoods in the Portuguese capital. Classic and modern at the same time, Chiado was home to many famous Portuguese artists in the early 20th century, so there are plenty of reasons to visit, or even choose a place to live, if you're moving to Lisbon.
reviews/14/text: A neighborhood of Lisbon that dates back to the 1700's. Very lively at night with shops and restaurants open.  This is also where you find Livraria Bertrand and Café A Brasileira.
reviews/15/text: We stayed at the periphery of the Chiado district and enjoyed walking around the narrow streets and the shopping streets. Lots of stores, including high end ones, bars and restaurants, antique stores, book stores and second  hand book stores. There is an upscale shopping center - Amazens Chiado - with about 50 shops and a large FNAC store, the Santa Justa lift. Praca do Comercio is on the southern side. Two of the best if not THE best restaurants of Lisbon - Alma and Belcanto - are also in this area.
reviews/16/text: This section of Lisbon seemed pretty upscale, with lots of restaurants, cafes, and shopping.  It seems pretty modern relative to other areas of Lisbon we saw. It has a multistory shopping mall. It's a nice place to walk around. We ate dinner at one of the restaurants.  The Carmo Convent and Santa Justa Lift overlook the area, and the Praca do Comercio is on the southern side.
reviews/17/text: I stayed in Chiado during a resent trip to Lisbon.  Its quieter than Lisbon proper, historic and beautiful.  I was traveling alone and felt perfectly safe.  Chiado was a great find!
reviews/18/text: A great neighbourhood to stay in in Lisbon. There are a mixture of shops, bars and restaurants. This is a lively place full of all sorts of surprises.
reviews/19/text: There are bad smelling buskers here. There are people on high. The things that are contraband in other countries are consumed by so many people in this square.

reviews/0/text: It was really beautiful, worth every penny. Every furniture, and decoration elements are original!!!
reviews/1/text: Unbelievable pretty: When the royal family left, they left all their belongings there, so you get a really authentic picture. The staff and especially our guide were extremly friendly and gave the most interesting tour. 10/10 would recommend! ☺️
reviews/2/text: A really great experience. The palace had original and interesting artifacts and the size of the place is perfect for a visit of an hour or two. Also the staff was very friendly, professional and knowledgeable about the palaces history. Would definetly recommend for anyone interested in Portugese history or a love for beautiful and elegant things. Also the pricing was very on point as the ticket price for students was only 2.5e.
reviews/2/title: A unique viewpoint to Portugese history for a good price
reviews/3/text: Really amazing experience. A must see when you are visiting Lisbon. It’s a unique situation to see a palace in such well condition. 5/5
reviews/4/text: Very good.Excellent. I recommend it to others. The people working there are nice. We will go here another time
reviews/5/text: It was a great experience! Very pleasent visit to one of the most beautiful venues in Lisbon. Great place for family visits!
reviews/6/text: Must see attraction in Lisbon, where one can immerse themself into the royal life of the Portuguese dynasties. A hidden gem inside the Ajuda district, which also offers excellent view on the city from another angle. Relatively cheap ticket for 5euros, which is totally worth it!
reviews/7/text: Very well kept palace, the most beautiful I’ve seen in Europe, with the chambers and the furniture all o their original form and places. Totally recommend visiting!
reviews/7/title: Most beautiful and well maintained palace
reviews/8/text: Must see if you are in Lisbon. Amazingly decorated rooms, I have never seen something like that before. The full price ticket is only 5 euro.
reviews/9/text: It was very pleasant to have visited this palace. This place is a hidden gem! It presents us about 40 rooms where you can find excelent colections of ceramics, glass, textiles, furniture, painting, sculpture etc.. It feels as if kings and princes still live there (they lived there in the 19th c.). From furniture to small objects, everything is still in place. For those who like to visit houses, architecture and decorative arts, don't miss it!
reviews/10/text: Could easily be described as the Versailles of Lisbon. Mind-blowing décor from the moment you enter. Silk wall-coverings, Meissen & Wedgewood porcelain, beautifully inlaid flooring in every room. Docents very informative and very helpful.
reviews/11/text: I went here with my husband and three children (17-22). We all had a great experience. The rooms were fully furnished and had descriptions in Português and English. The docents were friendly and kept you going in the right direction. I found the one upstairs, by the Asian artifacts, to be very knowledgeable about the family line and general history. She was delightful to talk to.  The artistry, architecture and the furnishings were beautiful and really gives you a sense of how royalty lived.
reviews/12/text: Very opulent, rich dive into the surroundings of the last monarchs of Portugal, but it gets to be a bit much after awhile.   It is quite big, and what is on exhibit is not the whole building. We were told there are no guided tours but the rooms have good descriptions.  The staff was pretty aloof and not helpful.  It's also a bit out of the way so it's good to know the public transit system as taxis are hard to come by.
reviews/13/text:
We visited both the reasonably priced Palace d'Ajuda (2.50E seniors) and the more pricey Royal Treasury Museum (7.50E) which had newly opened in one of the wings of the Palace. Each has its own entrance from the central courtyard. We used bus 760 to get here as it has a most convenient stop right in front of the palace entrance.  I rated the Palace d'Ajuda around 3 1/2 to 4 stars, while the Royal Treasury would deserve 5 stars.

We used 1 hour visiting the many different rooms in the palace. We had seen similar rooms with similar decor in other palaces.  For example, rooms included the expected Throne Room, Reception rooms, State dining room, and the royal apartments with bedrooms, music and sitting rooms, dining table set for the family, a billiards room, and an austere family Chapel. Each room had a bilingual sign with English which provided information about the room and special objects in it.

  The public rooms looked very regal with red velvet drapery, woven Belgium wall rugs, silk wall coverings, gilt architectural details, royal portraits hung on the walls, lovely ceiling paintings, and sparkling lit chandeliers with oversized Ming type vases in many rooms. In the private palace rooms, one room had decorative Meissen porcelain around the backs of chairs, around the frame of a standing mirror, and around candle holders on a tall stand. As we got to the end of 1 wing, the rooms began to look a bit "worn"/uncared for with ripped upholstery on a chair, and shredding silk wall coverings in one corner. The staff keep the shutters over the windows to keep the light out. WC is at the exit only. 

Across the courtyard, is the entrance to the Royal Treasury Museum. Read my review in Tripadvisor for that attraction under, “Museu Do Tesouro Real”. The display of jewels and silver was excellent. Entrance fee was 7.50E; we stayed for ½ hour to view this display. 

The palace has no garden as it is surrounded by streets. However, there is samll garden almost across the street from the Royal Treasury Museum. It is the Jardim Botanical d'Ajuda. Entrance is around 2E. Something else to see while at the Palace d'Ajuda.  

It took us about 30 minutes to reach the palace from Comercio Square using bus 760. The palace is not central, more in the Belem area.
reviews/13/title: Typical 19C palace rooms.  Royal Treasury Museum located in the Palace was excellent
reviews/14/text:
Built in 1802 as the Royal residences where the royals lived in the 18th & 19th centuries. It is now used by the President of Portugal for official functions and is a museum.

The rooms, furniture, tapestries, and pictures are amazing.
reviews/15/text:
I love this kind of palaces 
Specially in Europe 
Spectacular sceneries
Furnitures , decorations , curtains 
Here I was so happy but little bit worry 
Some areas needs renovations in emergency 
Best way to support the history and arts is to come and visit 
Let s go
reviews/16/text: We visited this Palace and were impressed by the beauty of the Royal Apartments. This exhibit clearly shows how similar the Portuguese Monarchy lived in comparison to the English, Danish, and French Monarchies. To our surprise this museum was also practically empty on a Saturday afternoon with beautiful weather. Entry fee is only €5.00 per person and tickets can be purchase online or on site. Credit cards are accepted.  Plan for no less than an hour to go through the exhibit. We spent 2 hours there.
reviews/17/text: Nice activity. Plan 1.5-2 hours. Was not at all crowded. Make sure you plan another 1.5 hrs visiting the Royal Treasures Museum on the premises (but separate tickets).
reviews/18/text: This is a beautiful white walled palace with has many arches and windows to it's facade. It comprises of two large turrets at each end of it's very wide frontage with the middle arch leading to some exquisite figurines, and then into a courtyard with a beautifully decorative design on it's floor.
reviews/19/text:
Having been to Belem Tower and Jeronimos Monastery it was just a short (and cheap) taxi ride to use our Lisboa card here.  From the outside the building is grand but not different enough to make it stand out.  It's only once you get inside and go from room to room where you see the impressive ceilings and the lavish furnishings and paintings in every room that you realise it is well worth the visit.

You can easily see everything in an hour, even though when we went there were covid pathways laid out to guide you from room to room and the place was pretty much desserted. 

As with most places in Lisbon, if you have the time, they are well worth the visit and the Palace of Ayuda should be high on your list.
subcategory_ranking: #16 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Panteao Nacional Campo de Santa Clara, Lisbon 1100-471 Portugal
address_obj/street1: Panteao Nacional Campo de Santa Clara
description: The construction of the church of Saint Engracia – currently the National Pantheon of Portugal - began towards the end of the 16th century and was only completed in the 20th century. This 400-year delay originated the proverb “Obras de Santa Engracia” meaning any work that never ends. A unique testimony to Portuguese Baroque art the National Pantheon stands on a hill overlooking the river Tagus being an icon of Lisbon’s cityscape. From its terrace you can have a majestic view of the city and its river. On the inside the Pantheon houses the remains of some of the most distinguished personalities of the country.
name: Panteao Nacional

reviews/0/text: Great architecture, Pantheon, Dome, climb to the top for some of the best pictures of Lisboa, highly recommend and another great church just above.
reviews/1/text:
This was our first touristic stop in Lisbon.  We found a few miradouros and took some pictures, but view from the rooftop of Panteao Nacional was the one I still remember the most.  
I looked down the center of the ground floor from the top only to find myself too thrilled of height!  The railing is definitely lower than I am used to in the US.  The building was well preserved to honor those resting in peace, but I was worried about smaller children (or even myself) who could fall from the top floor.  With a Lisboa Card, admission is free.
reviews/2/text: Beautiful building and tombs, great views from the terrace (over 170 stairs, be warned), but the experience was decidedly underwhelming. (Only *one* toilet for everyone to use - not a pleasant surprise, and it smelled to high heaven.)
reviews/3/text: Beautiful building! Please take the time to visit, you won't regret it. A little bit of history, beautiful architecture and design, incredible 360 view from the top.  The view alone is worth it. Sit up there for a while and enjoy the air. Keep in mind, there are a lot of stairs and it is colder/windy at the top so take the time to snap some pics on each floor if you need the rest and maybe bring a scarf or sweater.
reviews/4/text: Imposing building containing the tombs of some of the greatest Portuguese citizens, some good, great and some not so good. Take time to walk up to the roof for some fabulous view across the city.
reviews/5/text: This is a very beautiful site. Some illustrious Portuguese citizens are buried here. The views from the top of the building are most rewarding and the climb is not very hard. Prepare to spend 60 to 90 minutes here depending on how busy it is. We went on a Sunday afternoon and it was practically empty. The staff is very friendly and helpful. One can purchase tickets onsite with cash or credit card.
reviews/6/text: This is a beautiful looking white stone palace with grand steps that lead up to it's door. You can get multiple photos from all angles as you can walk all the way around it's concourse. It has a large dome feature to the top front with four large pillars to it's entrance. There are various different figurines that adorn it's doorway too.
reviews/7/text: Very nice and impressive structure. Student discount, which was nice. I did not feel like it is an absolute must see, but if you are in the area you should check it out.
reviews/8/text:
Unfortunately as we arrived there were signs up saying there was an event at the Pantheon which judging by the group outside was a concert of some description.

The building is set in a square and towers over the surrounding buildings and is visible from all over the city.

A shame we didn't get to see the inside or the view from the top but still worth the brief visit with the flea market in the surrounding streets adding to the experience.
reviews/8/title: Beautiful from outside, but closed for an event
reviews/9/text:
The National Pantheon is set beneath the historic Alfama hill, on the opposite slope from downtown. It's huge classic Baroque dome is visible from many parts of Lisbon.
The Pantheon is in fact the Church of Santa Engratia which was started as early as 16c by orders of Princess Maria, daughter of King Manuel.
However, it was finished only in 20 c and saw a very turbulent history - the first Church collapsed, then the main architect of the second Church died leaving it unfinished, then it was converted into barracks and arms factory when religion was banned in 19c. Finally it was finished in early 20c becoming a National Pantheon.
Famous figures of Portugal modern history are buried here, whose tombs you can visit in side rooms, while historic figures from discoveries period have their cenotaphs here in the main hall, but are buried elsewhere.
Interiors are really amazing, very rich all in marble.
Do climb the Dome - great views of those interiors from above, and then exit outside on the terrace to admire Lisbon and Tagus river views.
reviews/10/text:
Whilst this is an imposing building and impressive in its size, there isn't much inside. The caskets do not contain the relics of people like Vasco da Gamma, but are recognition of their contributions to Portugal with their bodies being buried elsewhere.

It's 187 steps up to the cupola but the height of the balustrade means you don't get too many good photo opportunities from there. Still worth the walk up if you're able to do so.

If you're in the area, you might as well stop in but I wouldn't go out of your way to come here.
reviews/11/text: We stopped by here on our last day in Lisbon, and it costs 4 euros each to get in as an adult. There are many famous Portuguese people buried here with lots of historical information to read. The views from the top are spectacular but if you are afraid of heights note it’s a one way system down once at the very top, to get back down you have to walk around part of the inner dome
reviews/12/text: Wasn’t expecting too much, but actually found it incredible. Looking down from the top of the dome was scary but very cool, and the views from the roof were also incredible. Interesting information about its history as well. Wish the exhibition on the Paris and Lisbon pantheons was in English as well!
reviews/13/text: Incredible!! even if  you're not interested in architecture (which is a beautiful feat in itself), the view you get from the balcony is incredible! I stood outside and audibly said wow as I stared in awe. Definitely take the time to check it out!
reviews/14/text:
We planned to go to Feira da Ladra, National Pantheon, St Vincent Church, St George Castle and Lisbon Cathedral on a single day.  It didn't work on one day :)

We came to National Pantheon after we visited the flea market.  The entrance fee was 5 Euro.  It is a bit expensive as I thought it was a church and it should be free of charge.  It is no longer used as a worship place.  Nevertheless it is worthwhile to see the interior and go to the terrace to see the city.  You are not allowed to take picture until you pay the entrance fee.  

The interior of the building is stunning with lots of amazing design and stone work.  The floor the building is made of stone / marble.  It has a symmetrical design and many people put their smart phones on the center of the floor to take pictures.  We were the same.

We climbed a lot of stairs to the gallery and tried to walk around to see the interior.  However, my knees felt weak because of the height. I walked about 1/3 around the circle and had to give up.  We walked around the terrace several times for the panoramic view of the city.  It is worth every penny of the entrance fee.
reviews/14/title: Amazing building and wonderful view from the terrace
reviews/15/text:
This was an unexpected and really impressive sight! Don‘t miss it!
I especially liked the hight of the ceiling and the balcony under the roof. It was so high that I actually felt a bit dizzy looking down. Amazing. You can also go out and roof therase amd
enjoy the view arround the dome.
Excellent and entertaining. Small entrance fee, credit cards accepted. Perfect.
reviews/15/title: Wowed by the hight of it inside!
reviews/16/text: This was better than expected.  Really beautiful building.  The detail and the architecture are stunning.  Well kept.  The entrance level mainly houses the tombs of great figures in Portuguese history.  You can then climb to the top.  There are different levels.  The climb up is easy and as the levels are split, it really isn't that bad at all.  The views on the top were beautiful on a sunny Saturday morning.  What made me laugh was how many toilets there were in the building!  Many people were just climbing up to see the views.  Yes this was stunning but go and see the tombs as well.  This is an important part of the visit and appreciate the building.  I was in there for around fifty minutes.
reviews/17/text: Lots of impressive marble, and if you can stand the climb, an interesting perspective of the building from up on top.  Centotaphs of very famous people.  The big impressive building on the hill.
reviews/17/title: Big Marble Building on the Hill
reviews/18/text: A gorgeous building and beautiful architecture inside. A fabulous viewpoint and photo spot at the top too. Was definitely worth the €4 entry!
reviews/19/text:
Basically a national monument for people of interest.  Building is interesting for a short while.

Lots of other interesting things to do besides this

description: This suspension bridge across the Tagus River has the longest central span in Europe, at 1.5 miles. It also looks quite a bit like San Francisco's famed "Golden Gate Bridge," though this one was named after the revolution.

reviews/0/text: The roads are pretty bad on the bridge but the views are beautiful. I find it better to enjoy the views from the Cristo Rei mõuntain, Algama or from the Maat Museum area. You don't especially have to go ON the bridge.
reviews/1/text: We drove this bridge a few times back and forth to Lisbon and my friend's family's town. The views from it are truly beautiful.
reviews/2/text: Stunning structure seen from afar, cars travel on the top level and trains on the bottom, no access for pedestrians.
reviews/3/text:
Extremely impressive bridge - you can get fantastic close up views from the Cristo Rei viewing area (free).
Cars on the top level, trains on the bottom.
It would be great to walk or cycle like the Golden Gate - maybe Lisbon might introduce that one day.
reviews/3/title: Fantastic view from the free Cristo Rei viewing area.
reviews/4/text: Not a lot of point in visiting the site as you get a better view from a distance. Particularly impressive to sail under on a river cruise.
reviews/5/text: One of the best bridges I have seen, highly recommend the views from Sanctuary of Christ the King. Great structure.
reviews/6/text: This isn't something you would go out of your way to visit. However, it's vastness is such that it can be seen from almost anywhere along the promenade and makes for great photos along the river.
reviews/7/text:
Viewing the April 25th Bridge from the heart of Lisbon’s waterfront area was a real treat, especially as the sun rose early in the crisp, summer morning. Immediately upon seeing it, I drew comparisons to its “cousin” across the pond, the Golden Gate Bridge—not to start a competition, but this one sure makes its mark. The extent and progression of human design and engineering capabilities…man. Remarkable.

Driving across the bridge or not, it’s a must to view this marvel of design when in Lisbon.
reviews/8/text:
Yes, you can't ignore the similarity with the famous SF bridge - huge span with two huge pillars, very high to let big ships pass under and pretty long connecting Lisbon and its southern suburb of Almada. Also the color is similar - this one little darker red than SF's orange.
The bridge dates back to 20c '60s, being renamed after the Revolution overthrowing Salazar dictator's regime.
While this was my third time in Lisbon, it was the first time I drove over it when heading towards the Cristo Rei statue - no tolls southbound, but tolls northbound when returning to Lisbon.
reviews/9/text: We've crossed this big bridge by train, walked under it several times, traveled under by train and car, but the best way to see it was by sailboat on the river.  It is very high up and noisy because of the train traffic.  Looks very much like the Golden Gate Bridge in California.
reviews/10/text: Stunning structure.  As other reviewers have mentioned, looks like the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco.  Do a boat cruise which should take you under the bridge.  The architecture is phenomenal!  You can really hear the cars passing by on top as you look up towards the bridge and the sky.  I got some fabulous photographs.  Really cool.
reviews/10/title: Do a cruise to see the bridge close up.
reviews/11/text:
The 25 de Abril Bridge is based in part on two San Francisco Bay Area bridges. Its paint is the same International Orange color as the famous Golden Gate Bridge, and its design is similar to that of the San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge.

If you going to the Belem are to see the church or the tower,  you can't miss this reddish,  long metal bridge. 

C U AROUND
reviews/12/text: At the Belem Quarter , you’ll enjoy the view of this enormous bridge, which was inspired by the Golden Gate Bridge of San Francisco. You’ll do a double take, as it does have similar features.
reviews/12/title: Twin bridge of the Golden Gate Bridge
reviews/13/text: Head over to the corpus Christie statue to see the true magnificence of this bridge and the view over Lisbon.
reviews/13/title: Portugal’s answer to the Golden Gate Bridge
reviews/14/text: Lovely bridge (twince of Golden Gate). IT is lovely to see it from distance and to drive on it . Driving I would surprisingly recommend  a rush hour - Drive on the Right Lane and You will have more time to enjoy the views
reviews/14/title: To look from distance and to drive on the bridge
reviews/15/text: Spanning the Tagus River, this suspension bridge was inaugurated in 1966 as the Salazar Bridge. Originally named for then Prime Minister Antonio Salazar, it was later renamed in 1977 to the 25th of April Bridge in honor of the revolution that overthrew Salazar’s dictatorship. The bridge managed to find its way into many of my photos. The best view is from the top of the Christo Rei statue (driving here means you’ll get to ride across the bridge too). We were surprised to get a glimpse of the bridge (and the Christo Rei monument) from our plane window when we flew into Lisbon. Note that traffic can get backed up around the bridge, especially during rush hour.
reviews/16/text: Some San Francisco Feeling in Europe. A very nice Bridge and whoever Likes the golden Gate will also Like this one. IT Covers Cars and train
reviews/17/text: Golden Gate Bridge bridge in Lisbon ? Really has the same look and feel. It’s 1.5 miles long and named Revolution. Recommended
reviews/17/title: Golden Gate Bridge bridge in Lisbon ?
reviews/18/text:
We walked from Praca do Commercio along the waterfront promenade late one afternoon and joined the throng of people who were all gathering, waiting for the sun to set behind the bridge. People brought their drinks and perched wherever there was space on the wall beside the water. It was quite lovely.
The bridge was completed in 1966 and, at 3.2km, it's still the longest suspension bridge in Europe. It took 3,000 workers but it was completed 6 months earlier than expected. It’s not a pedestrian bridge and, with the exception of an annual half-marathon, you can only cross the bridge by car or train. 
It is named after the  Carnation Revolution of 25 April 1974, a military coup, with widespread popular support overthrew the dictator and paved the way for a democratic Portugal. Almost no shots were fired and in a spontaneous and wonderful twist, people started giving soldiers carnations to celebrate the end of the dictatorship. They pinned them on their uniforms and stuck them in the muzzles of their guns. Quite a remarkable thing and must have been an amazing sight.
reviews/18/title: Watching the Sun Set Behind the Bridge
reviews/19/text: Very impressive and massive bridge, visible from far far away, a true Lisbon landmark! The bridge actually has 2 levels, the top one is for regular traffic, and below for trains

reviews/0/text: Very modern and lively neighborhood. Lot of hotels, restaurants around. You got the casino, Vasco da gama shopping mall and Oriente station
reviews/1/text: Formerly the site of Expo 98 this has now become a leisure complex with many restaurants and bars plus entertainment complexes. The cable car is a nice ride and gives a good view of Europe's longest bridge.
reviews/2/text:
The Nations park is a new neighborhood of Portugal capital in the northeast by the Tagus river. It was built for the World Expo 1998 and is easy reachable from downtown by bus, subway or car.
I'd advise planning at least half a day (with transportation) to visit the area highlights:
- Oceanario Lisboa (one of world's best aquariums, see that review),
- Telecabine Lisboa (scenic cable car ride along the Tagus),
- Science museum,
- Vasco de Gama shopping mall (huge) and bridge (one of the longest).
reviews/3/text:
We came to Parque das Nacoes on a Thursday afternoon.  The area was not busy at all.  It is a nice and modern area in Lisbon, which has a huge contrast from the old historic vide of Alfama.  

The previous Expo site can be easily accessed with metro red-line, train or bus.  It is also next to the Vasco de Gamma Mall and Oceanarium.

We  walked along the Tagus River and enjoy looking at the Expo site and world flags.  We also took a cable car to see the river and the area from a different angle.  It was such an enjoyable visit.
reviews/4/text: Popular place on the weekend as there are things to do for families like the big aquarium.  Also nice walks along the riverfront, views of the big bridge.  The unusual modern architecture is an attraction.  Huge train station here, as well as the Metro.
reviews/5/text: It is a good place and Part of the City. A modern contrast to the historic City Center. But somehow It feels replaceble and could bei Part of Most Others cities
reviews/6/text: The old part of Lisbon is much interesting. This is new part. The architecture is not that interesting. Visit old Lisbon.
reviews/7/text: A lovely little strip of land along the Tagus river.  It is wonderful to walk around the Parque das Nacoes at any time of the year.  It also looked like a great spot to go on a lunch break. If you are looking for a nice spot for a stroll, This is that place.
reviews/8/text: A lot of concrete to be honest but the seaside makes walking along the Parque worth it. Planting little more green won't be bad but you'll be able to find a few spots with shadow to rest or drink your coffee.
reviews/9/text: Dom Bacalhau restaurant (cod fish restaurant ) have a best localization in Lisbon city. (Parque das Nações) Find all the Diferente ways to make the dish with cod fish. This Traditional Portuguese food is delicious.. With the green wine (Alvarinho) it is unique. Have fun
reviews/9/title: Pls find D. Bacalhau restaurant in Lisbon. Parque das nações.
reviews/10/text: The place where you see modern skyscrapers,  glass buildings and small squares with modern art. You could have a nice walk near waterfront.
reviews/11/text:
A large group of buildings, art, and shops etc along the walk from the Nations Plaza ( small display of country flags) to oceanarium and beyond. We took the tram on site for the view and for the novelty and then walked by mistake way past the Oceanarium to the end of,the walk where the car dealerships started. The Oceanarium is directly outside the tram stop! 
My friend thought it wasn’t worth the time but so I enjoyed the art and ambience. Could be skipped for sure! We did not go into the oceanarium.
reviews/12/text: A more modern area of Lisbon, a former Expo site. Great place to walk by the water. Take the opportunity to visit the oceanarium and go on a cable car ride. Some nice restaurants are in the area as well.
reviews/13/text: Great park with all the world flags and their description below. Also nice cat sculpture and beautiful views to appreciate. Worth visiting.
reviews/14/text:
Lisbon is the Best city for visitors.in that moment. 
Old Town mixed with the New Town. And
Parque das Nações.. Is a unforgettable visit. near the Tejo River.. you find everything.. Shops. Restaurants. Bars.. Parks.. You can also crossing.. all the time.. you can do everything..
reviews/14/title: Visit Lisbon.. and don't forget Parque das Nações..it is The best.new place. in Lisbon.
reviews/15/text: This area is a nice contrast from the small and crowded streets of central Lisbon. It is much more spread out, and there is a nice wide pedestrian walkway next to the river. We stayed at a nearby hotel and enjoyed the relative quiet and nearness to the airport and train station.
reviews/15/title: Nice place to stroll and spread out
reviews/16/text: Lots to do at this park: aquarium, restaurants, walking. Nice for a last day in Lisbon if you're lodging at the airport and don't want to go downtown.
reviews/17/text:
We called in for lunch to have a break from the Web Summit and I’m so glad we did. 
The owner recommended us to try the house specialty pork cheek and oxtail, they were awesome. 
Highly recommend visiting here if you’re in the area and especially if you’re attending the Web Summit.
reviews/18/text: After spending three days in the old center of Lisbon, we spent our last half-day near Parque das Nacoes because our hotel would be close to the airport for an early morning flight. It is a busy and fun area with modern office buildings, a Calatrava-designed train station and other attractions. There are many restaurants in the area and opportunities for strolling and people-watching.
reviews/18/title: Busy Former Expo Site is now the Modern Face of Lisbon
reviews/19/text:
We had a hotel close to the airport booked on our last night and decided to spend the evening before our morning flight out of Lisbon at Parque das Nações. It was a quick taxi ride there and back from our hotel. There is a fair amount to do here, although we did not find it as enjoyable as other sites we had seen in Portugal.
Cable cars (gondola ride)
Oceanarium
Science museum
Vasco de Gama Shopping centre
Orient train station 
Vasco de Gama tower
Flags of Expo 98 participating nations
Urban art
Lots of restaurants
I wouldn't come out here in the middle of your trip to Lisbon, unless you came on a Monday when many sites/museums are closed, or you did it the last evening of your trip like we did.
reviews/19/title: Visit the evening before flight out
subcategory_ranking: #61 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Praca do Imperio, Lisbon 1449-003 Portugal
description: Located in Belém, the Museu Coleção Berardo is The Most Visited Museum in Portugal and is the Main Modern and Contemporary Art Museum in Lisbon, with 6 Major Exhibitions on view. Open every day, from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. (last entrance: 6:30 p.m.) Admission Ticket (adult): 5€, discounts available. Free on Saturdays, all day. Houses the Berardo Collection of Modern and Contemporary Art, together with temporary exhibits. The permanent collection of the museum presents the major art movements of the 20th century - Cubism, Dadaism, Constructivism, De Stijl, Surrealism, Post-war Figuration, CoBrA, Abstract Expressionism, Kinetic and Op Art, Nouveau Réalisme, British Pop Art, American Pop Art, among others, presenting works from artists like Mondrian, Picasso, Duchamp, Andy Warhol, Jackson Polock, Louise Bourgeois, Alexander Calder, Salvador Dalí, Francis Bacon, Balthus, Lucio Fontana, Yves Klein, Pistoletto, Bill Viola, Andreas Gursky, Frank Stella, among others. A must-see in Lisbon!
name: Museu Colecao Berardo
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Museu Coleção Berardo Admission Ticket
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Lisbon Self-Guided Audio Tour
photo/caption: Andy Warhol, Judy Garland,1979. Coleção Berardo. #AndyWarhol #MuseuBerardo
ranking: #22 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #22 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: This private collection has been converted to a major museum in the Belem area.  Fancy new building with a good food venue.  Nice views of the river.  And lots of valuable modern art.
reviews/1/text: If in Belem to see the monastery and the tower, stop at this contemporary arts museum to see the excellent permanent collection, as well as the temporary shows. Uncrowded and huge.
reviews/2/text: This museum is very new and the result of a huge donation from a very rich international guy with a questionable past.  I was recommended by good friends and we enjoyed our time here.  Nice cafe outside for a place to eat and drink.  Interesting collection.  In Belem.
reviews/3/text:
If you're into modern and contemporary art, this is worth a visit. It's a well laid out museum and not cluttered. You'll fine works by Picasso, Pollock, Warhol, Dali and Lichtenstein as well as other 20th century artists.

You'll probably only need an hour here.
reviews/4/text: I didn't expect it, but it was so fantastic experience! Museum is great, exhibitions are really interesting! We had a great time in this musium and will visit it in the future!
reviews/5/text: This is a brand new and very large art museum with all the contemporary artists you know and lots of masterpieces.  Large and beautiful display space, never feels crowded.  Beautiful garden with sculpture and views of Belem.  Good food venues.
reviews/6/text:
An impressive and beautifully designed modern art museum in Lisbon , located near the Torre de Belem , a bit far from downtown Lisbon .
Highly recommended for museum lovers
reviews/7/text: We were impressed with the collection and the curation - this is a fantastic museum for anyone, even if you are not really into art.  It's a fantastic introduction to modern art - with excellent descriptions of the history of constructivism, dadaism, surrealism, ...and so on.  Really enjoyable and worth visiting.
reviews/8/text: This is a lovely collection of post 1900 art that anyone who appreciates a good museum should visit while in Lisbon. The facility and presentation of the works was world class ! Cafes and shops complement the attraction.
reviews/9/text: If you are interested in visit contemporaneous art, this place is for you! Stunning pieces of art from the best painters and sculptures of the world, this museum is a must to add to your list.
reviews/10/text: Was kind of a spontaneous stop at this museum and we were really happy we entered this place... very interesting expositions and some world famous items from artists such as Andy Warhol or Picasso..
reviews/11/text: I find that modern art galleries tend to be hit or miss, but  Museu Colecao Berardo is definitely a hit.  I would recommend anyone visiting Lisbon to go here.  The entrance fee was €5, with a 50% discount for over 65s and under 18s.
reviews/12/text: This gallery has some incredible pieces that really inspired my final year at art college! So glad I came, and really want to return!
reviews/13/text: My favorite museum of contemporary art in Lisbon! Place by it’s self is amazing architectural place, other then that every exhibition curated in a such sophisticated way, with delicacy, taste and incredible artists. Thank you Berardo for giving us the opportunity to keep up with contemporary art world in a such beautiful way ❤️
reviews/14/text: We didn't enter in any exhibition, we just hang out to see the building, and we were surprised, it's interesting visiting. The architecture is worth visiting, there's a garden, a miradouro, some exoctic plants and free toilet! =D
reviews/15/text:
3 tours in 3 days: Belem with Beatrice, Centre with Yuri and Alfama with Maggie. All good, informative. More experienced guides seem to pace the walks well, give good info about major sites and point out interesting things along the way. I’m sure if we took the same tour over with different guides we would learn new things. 

Beatrice was the newest and it was apparent. She ran long, dragged on and though she was eager, she was not the exuberant performer that most guides seem to be - it wasn’t her style. Yuri & Maggie were balls of energy and eager to educate & entertain. I’d go again. We paid €10 pp and that seemed to be what others did. It’s worth the risk. We didn’t leave any of them early.
reviews/15/title: Take Lisboa free walking tours of Lisbon
reviews/16/text: Always a requirement to state I’m not an art aficionado by any means. I didn’t really know the significance of a lot of what was in the gallery initially. However, the exhibits are very well labelled and quite aesthetically interesting even without a critical eye. Besides, the girlfriend did an art degree so a few of the core pieces she’d actually studied were clearly highlights that I got some free additional info on. Turns out the soup can is a big deal!
reviews/16/title: Surprisingly enjoyable with a nod to modern history too
reviews/17/text: A well organized museum with a good flow and elaborate description of each era of art. Although there are no seats provided, I personally don’t feel the need to sit down... Every room has it’s own experience and you’ll definitely want to go on to the next one !
reviews/18/text: Amazing! I’ll come back for sure! Lovely open market just outside the museum... if you visit the tower (Belem), it’s just across the street, and on Tuesdays it’s free!
reviews/19/text: A lot of  rich guys collect art - some rich guys both love & collect art - the Berardo Collection is a labor of love beautifully curated. This is an absolute can’t miss and ranks among the best anywhere

offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Lisbon Shopping Tour

ranking_subcategory: #49 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: The huge shopping centre is easy to reach by public transport. It offers everything your heart desires. You can linger in it for hours.
reviews/0/title: A shopping centre like one wishes
reviews/1/text:
I am not a mall person, but i ended up here 3x during my weeks stay.
The food court alone is a reason to go, never have i seen the lunch hour taken so seriously, deliciously or wallet friendly. When a steak, fries and salad fresh made is the same price as Mcdonalds, taco bell or pizza hut, also available, you have a budget foodies dream.
There is also a HUGE contente, one of the major supermarkets, that is essentiality a wal-mart in this location. Toys, cloths, major liquor section, prepared food and 2 bakeries. I had an apartment and shopped for the week here.
Shopping wise, the usual primark, toys r us, book and electronic stores. Connected to the train its a good way to spend 2-3 hours on a rainy day
reviews/1/title: Foodie on a budget dream place
reviews/2/text: Lot of fake comments everywhere.  It is a huge and very nice mall, but prices are ridiculously high.  I am in the middle of black Friday days and prices are as high as usual in France or Italy. Sales are a joke here. That's why shops are empty and neither foreigners nor locals buy.
reviews/3/text: Went to this shopping centre last weekend. Lots to see and do . Easy wonder for hours in it. We got to food hall and fancied some KFC. Well what fun that turned out to be . Such level of incompetence i have never seen. We done per order screen. Got our ticket to pay. Queued to pay for our order. 2 customers in front of us. 5 staff behind 2 till. One for per order and One for direct order.  Took nearly 15 minutes for us to get to the till. After pre ordering we  still had to go trough each item with a member of staff before we got to pay. Was supposed to be a simple tasty large tender meal and 2 side extras and dip with meal. Payed for all . Queued another 10 minutes to receive our meal. Went upstairs to get seated to realise the order was wrong. The tender turned out to be wings and thighs and no dip with the meal. The only thing correct with the meal was the chips and the empty drinks cup. On returning to the till with the receipt got a long blank look off a member of staff who when lookin
reviews/4/text:
We had a great day out at the Centro Colombo.  It is easy to find.  There is plenty of parking available and access is easy.  A beautifully designed shopping centre.  I would recommend going to the information desk and asking for a map of the centre.  There is a centre hub where a lot of the "designer" shops cn be found and then arms go off in all directions from there.  Lots of shops and an excellent variety of shops.  Many of the staff in the shops were extremely pleasant and helpful and special kudo's to the gentleman serving in the Clarke's shoe store - he was brilliant and extremely helpful, thank you.  Great food hall with plenty of seating and food for every sort of taste including those with dietary restrictions.  

For those with mobility issues and require use of a wheelchair or mobility scooter.  Most of this shopping centre is accessible.  There are elevators.  There are a few shops I could not get into with a mobility scooter because there was simply not enough room.  Also, two of the bathrooms I went to did not have a wheelchair accessible bathroom and I had to try three different bathroom areas before I found one but even that was not particularly easy to get my mobility scooter in and out of.  This is the main reason for the 4 stars, for a centre of this size, access should have been much easier.
reviews/4/title: Excellent Shopping Centre - Great day (or two), out.
reviews/5/text: Lots of shopping options with a great food court. Easy to spend a few hours here. Good variety of stores and great pricing too. Easy to access by metro (blue line)
reviews/6/text:
We stayed at Carnide when we were in Lisbon.  Colombo Mall is a few mins walk from our apartment and we went there many times.  You can access the mall with metro blue line at Military College/Luz.

There is a huge supermarket Continente in the mall where we bought what we needed.  Price was good (compared to Canadian price).  The food court is on the third level.  There are some chain fast food - KFC, McDonald's, Taco Bell.  You can also get authentic Portuguese food, e.g. Pateo.  

Most of the shops are fashion related.  I found some bargains at Sportzone, C&A and Zara.  

The mall is in a residential area and not close to the tourist hotspots.  However, it is worthwhile to visit.
reviews/6/title: Colombo Mall - Nice and Huge with good price
reviews/7/text:
Depends where you come from, for example,  prices are much lower in the states. 
However,  the food court provide lots of eaterie options. 
And there is huge grocery story at basement level called content where they have unresistable discount on port wine.
Parking is not free.
C U AROUND
reviews/7/title: No price bargains, I went for food court and the big grocery store Continent.
reviews/8/text: I guess for shopaholics this place must be heaven. For me, it is overstocked, overpriced, and oversized. Just plain boring. Nothing uniquely Portuguese about this place at all - other than the Portuguese signs.
reviews/9/text: We visit this mall in Mar. 2020 and loved it. Great food court. You’ll need a few hours to explore it all. Well worth the visit. We took Uber from waterfront Lisbon. It was convenient and cost effective.
reviews/10/text: Excellent shopping mall - you need about 4 hours to see everything .Great range of Restaurants too, which were not too expensive
reviews/11/text: Large shopping center with 3 floors of dozens of local stores and international brands. You can find here almost everything . Opening hours are long and the food stalls run almost until midnight.There's a Metro station here of the Blue Line that comes from the town center.
reviews/12/text: we were  very short of time. so we had to be very efficient  which is not the case for the local clients. queing at primark took us a long time but  prices were quite   unexpensive quality of products  good coffee shops restos etc well  varied.  security/ information personel hardly understand english. continente supermarket  with lot of cashes was very good but quite basic and not having  portugueses delicacies. at the final we suceeded in   matching our purposes in  the  afforded time
reviews/12/title: all main  reknown shops too busy on saturdays  english hardly spoken
reviews/13/text: Massive mall, if you cant find it there you will not find it anywhere.  Difficult to navigate your way around at first but once you understand the layout you will find everything you need.  Good selection of restaurants  in the food court.   Found a nice cellphone store that was able to to a cellphone repair within an hour.
reviews/14/text: Huge shopping mall, with those usual brands, plenty of food set up, have a huge supermarket, also convenient transport location, can last your visit for hours, its one of the biggest mall in Lisbon. I would recommend to pay a visit to appreciate what the shopping mall is like in Lisbon
reviews/15/text:
Many brands , huge mall , been there for 6 or 7 hours .. lol
Fair normal prices , sales - depands on the brand.
reviews/16/text:
just reviewing food offered, large variety /very good quality and good prices.
space offered can be inside the restaurants or take out to consume in food courts.  large food court spaces but spread out on many sections in one floor.
reviews/17/text: Lots of nice shops, lots of places to eat, relaxed atmosphere, metro station nearby, Estadio do Luz next door
reviews/18/text: Huge and nice shopping mall. Has all the shops you may search for. Large area in the food court diversity in food choice. Sure we will go again
reviews/19/text:
During our recent visit at Lisbon, we have visited Colombo Shopping center three times. 
  This center contains a lot of fancy modern shops, including leading
shopping nets: H&M, C&A and Primark. 
The assortment of restaurants allows finding of tasty eating place for virtually everyone.
The center is located on Metro blue line so the access to it is convenient.
reviews/19/title: Several visits at Colombo Shopping center

address: Rua Rodrigues de Faria 103, Lisbon 1300-501 Portugal
description:
Once an old industrial textile complex, LX Factory is now home to Lisbon’s trendiest restaurants, bars, and shops. Located beneath the Ponte de 25 Abril Bridge, the revitalized hotspot resembles a village where you can walk down cobbled streets and admire the street art adorning the walls of old warehouses. Here, you can dine in a former industrial canteen, shop at a multi-story bookstore, watch artists at work in their ateliers and studios, catch a live performance or exhibition, and more.

On the weekend, stop by the open-air flea market which sells everything from handmade jewelry to vintage clothing. – Tripadvisor

reviews/0/text:
A wonderful place full of places to eat and shops to explore. 
If the water permits you must go for a drink on the roof top bar.
reviews/1/text: This is a really fun and unique area with some great shops and lots of tasty food. We visited Belém in the morning and the factory in the afternoon - the schedule worked out really nicely!
reviews/2/text: If you're looking for a great place to spend an afternoon, I highly recommend checking out this area. Lot of options for lunch and walk around. Very enjoyable experience!
reviews/3/text: Nice to visit. Although I expected a little bit more concept stores and designers. Very nice vibe. And if you're a vegetarian, the sardine store has to veggie alternatives. How cool is that?
reviews/3/title: Very nice to spend some hours
reviews/4/text: Really fun spot to wander around and grab lunch. So many places to choose from. We ended up at a peri peri chicken place that was so tasty. Wandered around the shops. Be sure to go upstairs too. Funky old building.
reviews/5/text: This was a great place to walk around and we had awesome food at the Mexican restaurant. I only wish we had more time! I would definitely suggest this over the time out market if you have to choose.
reviews/5/title: Great spot with plenty of food options!
reviews/6/text:
We went to LX Factory last Sunday. There was a market with lots of stalls food, handmade items etc was really nice and lots of restaurant choices too.
I would recommend  going if your nearby on a sunday
reviews/7/text:
We visited Lisbon this week and decided to stop by LX Factory during our stay. Having read mixed reviews we weren’t sure what to expect but honestly, we had a lovely visit. 

The place itself is a bit out of the way - lots of recommendations of how to get there via metro and tram etc but we found a Bolt was the cheapest and easiest option by far. We did get the tram back into town afterwards - mainly for the experience - but the Bolt on the way there was actually cheaper, €5.96 from Saldanha to LX Factory and took about 20 mins. 

LX Factory is filled with independent shops and food places - there is a Main Street and then if you go inside the building itself you’ll find more independent businesses upstairs to peruse, as well as some round the back off the Main Street.

We had brunch at Cafe Nino, the cutest little breakfast spot run by the friendliest lady (the matcha pancakes are a must!) then went exploring. There are bookshops, tinned fish shops, some beautiful ceramic shops, jewellery and clothing, lots of foodie places. We loved it actually, the sun was shining so perfect weather to wander - we spent a good 2-3 hours there. 

LX Factory is worth a visit as part of your day; it was quiet when we first arrived around 11am and was bustling by the time we left with people drinking in the bars, doing some shopping, having a wander round. 

Definitely a good little spot to visit if you have the time - good weather is a must!
reviews/7/title: Lovely spot to see when visiting Lisbon
reviews/8/text: My husband and I stopped by LX Factory a couple of hours before a dinner reservation. It was worth a stop since we were in the area. There were many interesting looking eateries and shops, but bc it was a little late in the day, we missed out on a lot of shops. I don’t know that we would have found it as worthwhile if we went to the area just to visit.
reviews/9/text: Cool area and some nice shops and bars but smaller than it looks definitely worth going but you wouldn’t spend all day here
reviews/10/text:
Brilliant place, full of quirky shops and cafés.

I was lucky enough to pick up a lovely vintage cape, my fiance was thrilled to get some vinyl in the bookshop that he's been looking for.

It is quite hard to find from the train station and the underpass is a little 'interesting' but the place is worth the effort to get there.
reviews/11/text: While on a tuk tuk Eco Electric Day tour of Lisbon we mentioned to our tour guide that we had a free day on Sunday with nothing planned. We asked him what he’d recommend! Thank goodness we asked as this was truly an incredible day, such a fun place full of artisan shops, unique shops, great restaurants ..  such a fun vibe too! LX Factory is open all week but only on Sundays do they have this added open market with different booths and vendors. Some very unique ideas, ceramics, jewelry ,  artwork and tshirts not typical of the souvenir shirts that you will find everywhere. The Sunday market opens at 10am and it’s best to be there just before it opens, before it may get crowded! It’s such a great time! Highly recommend visiting. So happy we didn’t miss it!
reviews/11/title: A FUN Market Day Not to be missed
reviews/12/text: This lively and trendy spot is home to Lisbon's best bookstore, Ler Devagar, and abounds with restaurants and boho shops. It's still very much a work in progress, with plenty of unoccupied space; graffiti reaches a high level on the old warehouse walls, though not everything can exactly be considered "street art." A bit more variety in both merchandise and cuisine are definitely called for, but as a social magnet it pulses with life, especially after the sun goes down.
reviews/13/text:
Went here on off the beaten track tour and decided to go back for coffee and cake at brigaderios 

I am sure this place would be buzzing at night just need to Uber or arrange transport there and back as a bit out of town the axe throwing looked like it would be fun
reviews/14/text: Stopped by after an already busy day, I wish I had more time. I will definitely go back to do some more shopping. Lots of cute stores and fun restaurants. We had a bite to eat at one of the restaurants Pura, it was ok. I’ll definitely do some research to find a better place to eat next time and perhaps a map of stores so I don’t miss anything.
reviews/15/text: This spot was disappointing in that the quality of shopping and food was mediocre, It was overpriced and under performed in quality.  But it is an easy entry point to learn what is available at real Lisbon restos and craft locations.
reviews/15/title: Only if you have time to burn.
reviews/16/text:
On the 25th of December, we walked 1 hour in the rain from Baixa - just to find the gate to LX Factory closed. What to do? Walk back again, of course. We were soaked.

Located in the shadow of a massive concrete highway bridge LX Factory seems picturesque the industrial way that modern artists adore.

By the way, you don’t have to walk all the way. We saw tram 15E passing by.
reviews/16/title: Check opening hours before showing up
reviews/17/text: LX Factory is a nice contemporary slash hipster social spot. The repurposing of old industrial space into multiple restaurants, shops, bookstores etc is always cool to see what a little creativity and teamwork can do. Depending on what you’re looking for you can probably find it at LX. Nice date and hangout spot every once in a while.
reviews/18/text:
Super place too walk around and relax.
Have a beer ore a glas of vine in one of alot of resturangs. Alot of things too look at usch as art and more.
reviews/19/text: A friend recommended visiting LX factory so I went there on a rainy day. Apart from a few cute shops and obviously the bookshop with the bicycle (Les Devagar, which is a wonderful place) it is purely commercial and quite run down around the edges. Some interesting murals and a good place to hide from the rain. I ordered hot chocolate at a small café but left after 25 minutes since they were overwhelmed with two hands full of customers. public toilet was chained locked. I wouldn't recommend making your way here.
reviews/19/title: Option for a rainy day if you have nothing else to do.

ranking: #23 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #23 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Lots of space to wander around and take in the views across the city, and plenty of walls and things to rest on if you want to stop a while. Lovely in the sunshine.
reviews/1/text: Wonderful view of the view of the city,  castle, bridge, hills, and water. This smaller plaza is shaded and high above Lisbon. If you want to take great pictures of Lisbon and its main castle,  this is the spot. It's just a beautiful area to observe all of Lisbon.
reviews/1/title: Great View of the City and Castle
reviews/2/text: This was my first miradouro visited and it was so beautiful. You can see all the Alfama neighborhood. Perfect spot to hang out, take pictures
reviews/3/text: This is a fantastic viewpoint to see more of Alfama but due to it's angle it also takes in the vast 25 de Abril bridge that you can see rising high above the river and then entering into the city. This was my joint top Mirodouro of the eight that I saw. Breathtaking!
reviews/4/text: This must surely be one of the finest views in Lisbon, although it is currently partially marred by the presence of a very large crane. The building works are apparently here to construct a funicular which will allow better access to the viewpoint. The railings at the edge of the viewpoint get quite crowded at sunset, so get here with time to snag your spot at the front.
reviews/5/text: This is one of many viewpoints in Alfama. From this one you can get a good view of the castle as well as the river. A nice stop while in Alfama.
reviews/6/text: Beautiful views of the city of Lisbon! Walking around the area below, we stumbled upon the stairs leading up to this area by the church.   You can take a funicular; however, why when you find some stairs that no one else is walking up…lol.  After a long walk up these stairs, we emerged right by a little park with a fountain beside the church. Going around to the side of the church, there was a little outdoor cafe where we got a glass of wine and a bite to each while admiring the panoramic view of Lisbon.  (Esplanada Igrejada Graçia is the outdoor cafe) Afterwards, we walked around the church and park the other way and found another road leading straight up.  You must walk up this way for more beautiful panoramic views of Lisbon and if you are lucky, there will be wonderful street musicians playing guitar. Sit down on one of the benches, listen to the live music, and enjoy the beauty of the city!  ( You will also see a large beautiful paining of flowers in a terracotta pot on the side of a building on your way up this other area).
reviews/7/text:
One of better view points in Lisbon. It's set in the historic Alfama district (hill) in vicinity of the famous St. George castle. 
I suggest coming before sunset to observe it from here with great views of entire Lisbon and Tagus river. Views from here are almost the same as from nearby St. George castle, but you pay nothing here.
reviews/8/text: This is one of many lookouts over the city of Lisbon and the Douro River known as Miradouros. At Miradouro da Graça (Portuguese for Grace Viewpoint), you’ll find far fewer tourists than the wildly popular Miradouro das Portas do Sol, with more locals than outsiders and even a small bar and patio. From this vantage point, you’ll have a great view of Lisbon. As an added bonus, you can walk through the gorgeous Church of Our Lady of Grace next to this Miradouro, the namesake for the lookout.
reviews/9/text:
One of the best spots in lisbon to enjoy the views, Sagres and the vibe of Lisboa! 

Easy to reach by Tram28, and definitely worth a visit during sunset!
reviews/10/text: Lovely viewpoint of the city. Only requires a quick stop so plan for twenty minutes max but definitely don't skip over this place during your visit to Lisbon.
reviews/11/text: The views here are terrific of the city below and of the castle.  It is a good place to stop and rest and to take a bunch of photos.
reviews/12/text: There is a bar right there which is helpful. Views out to then”San Francisco” bridge and the St. George castle. Really great view of the city. See photos.
reviews/13/text:
Drop into the church and light a candle while you view the old interior.
In front of the “Graça” the square offers a view over the city and the Castelo São Jorge.
reviews/13/title: See the city and the castle from this elevated view point.
reviews/14/text: The better place is Miradouro da Nossa. This place is overrated. The views are ok. Better views from Miradouro da Nossa.
reviews/15/text: Another spectacular viewpoint, there are so many dotted around town (Lisbon is built on seven hills after all!), but this one is in my personal top three... especially good view of the castle (up on yet another hill, you guessed it right!)... there's also a beautiful church here
reviews/16/text: This is one of many viewing platforms around the city with as expected great views - a good place to while away the time, lazing around, reading, dozing, drinking, chatting or all four!
reviews/17/text: The Miradouro da Graca viewpoint is one of the most popular viewpoints in Lisbon. This viewpoint is located on the border Graca and Alfama districts. It is a popular meeting place for students, young people and couples in love, all thanks to its view of Lisbon's historic center, the Baixa district and the Tagus River. At the Miradouro de Graca , you can find a kiosk serving hot and cold drinks, and a dozen tables and benches, all surrounded by  trees that cast shade .There is also the imposing church of Igreja da Graca here.  A great place for any  traveler. At the same time, after getting there, you can admire the beautiful views as well as regenerate before further walks. It is worth taking photos here, to make the memories stay longer. Beautiful place. Although it is popularly called the Graca viewpoint - Miradouro da Graca - its official name is Miradouro Sophia de Mello Breyner Andresen. It is named after the famous Portuguese writer.
reviews/18/text: Our first place to visit in Lisbon. It has a fantastic view. Lisbon is so pretty from up here. Take your time to enjoy the view.
reviews/19/text: Unfortunately another trap tourist. Service poor as it can be. Better views near by. Do not go there.
