ranking_subcategory: #65 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Beautiful and huge place! The grass and hedges could do with a trim but otherwise a lovely place to go for a walk and breathe in some fresh air.
reviews/0/title: Lovely place to go for a walk
reviews/1/text: Wow! This is an amazing green area, but if you’re heading south to north, be prepared for a steep climb. At the top are some lovely restaurants with great views and the whole area is tree lined and spectacular
reviews/2/text: Well worth a stroll in the park. Don't miss the "estufa fría" and "estufa quente" cold (open) and hot (enclosed) greenhouses. The view from the top of the mall looking out to the Tejo River is amazing.
reviews/2/title: Beautiful and unexpected park in the middle of the city.
reviews/3/text:
I didn't have this on our list of places to go for Lisbon but once we were there, my husband convinced me that we should go.

It's a bit north of the rest of the must-see sights of Lisbon, though at the end of the main shopping avenue and therefore, not an impossible stop.  The walk up is obviously not the most flat but the view at the top is pretty.  Our kids loved running around the big open areas and getting out some energy.

At the very top is a pretty water feature and a great view of the city!  This is definitely not a must-see spot in Lisbon but if you're in the area and have kids that need to get out some energy, this is a great place to do so.
reviews/4/text: This park would not be on my “To Do” list when visiting Lisbon. The park is an uninteresting green city space with a zig zag line of clipped boxwood hedges running in the middle of its grassy area and along its sides, keeping people out of this grassy area. On either side is a patterned cobblestone sidewalk, lined with trees and a couple of benches. The view is at the top end of the park which is on a hill. It would be an uphill walk from the Pombal Statue and probably not a comfortable one on a hot day. Fortunately, our tour bus stopped at the top of the park where the attraction is  – the free viewpoint. Even at ground level, visitors can see directly down the grassy area to the tall city buildings around the Pombal Statue and, then, out towards the Tagus River and beyond it to the other side. Up on the observation deck of the skinny tower called, the Monument to the 25th April Revolution, the view over the tree tops would include the Castello Jorge. Beside the tall skinny tower is a fountain, that I am sure has some symbolic meaning, but it is ugly because it looks as if it is still in the construction stage. The huge Portuguese flag behind the fountain is only an impressive sight on a breezy day.  Interestingly, the park was named after the British king, King Edward VII, who visited the park in 1903. Our guide said that in October a Book Fair is held in the park. For shoppers, focus instead on the many blocks of designer shops along the Ave. da Liberdade.
reviews/4/title: See the city view for free at the top of the park. The view, at ground level, is OK.
reviews/5/text: Large well maintained park which if you walk to the top it gives you magnificent view across the city, if you wander into the side of the park were the trees are you may be lucky to spot a Parakeet or two.
reviews/6/text: Good views of old town. Grounds need a bit of upkeep with some weeding and hedge trimming this would be amazing. Not too crowded mid week.
reviews/6/title: Great view of the city! Easy to get to walking.
reviews/7/text: We could se there hour by hour and could not get tired, we even visited this park 2 times on our trip. Maybe there is not much to do, but view was breathtaking, there were not so many people, a lot of dogs playing. I would recommend going down the street, there is a lot of shops and cafes.
reviews/8/text: Lovely park, well maintained, climbing up the hill from the Marquis de Pombal Square. At the top end there is a magnificent view of Lisbon down to the River Tagus.
reviews/9/text: I was staying in the area on my visit, so I took the opportunity to visit the park to catch the sunrise. Unfortunately, there was some sort of event or festival going on and a lot of the park had been covered with marketing, etc for the event and festivals. I was hoping to get some pictures of the park as I had seen on various blogs and websites, but the marketing really ruined any picture as well as a good composition.
reviews/9/title: Park covered with marketing content from a festival
reviews/10/text:
This park named after the famous English king is set north from the big Marquis de Pombal square with his monument.
But, to enjoy the park you must walk up to its northern edge and terrace from where are magnificent views of manicured lawns, downtown Lisbon and Tagus river.
reviews/11/text:
On approach along Avenida de Liberdade, the park didn’t seem like much, just a brilliant green mirage ahead of us with numerous pathways and a very steep uphill walk. But when you reach the pinnacle and look back at Lisbon, you’ll see why this climb is worth every bit of effort!

It’s my favorite viewpoint in the city, even above the famed Miradouro das Portas do Sol. if you visit on the right day, the world’s largest Portuguese flag will be flown at the top (northern) end of the park. Redesigned in 1945, the space covers 64 acres (26 hectares) in the middle of the city and is named for an English king. The Carlos Lopes Pavilion, leftover from the 1922 expo, can be found near the top as well.
reviews/12/text:
This monument is at the north end (upper) of the park and overlooks the Avenida Libertad to the Rio Tejo. On a bright day the view is excellent.
The monument itself commemorates the 1974 Carnation Revolution, when Portugal overthrew the fascist regime to become a democracy and end its colonial period.
reviews/13/text: This is a beautiful park between the Monument to the 25 Avril and the Statue of the Marquis of Pombal.  It is a beautiful walk with great views.
reviews/14/text: Lovely, clean, manicured park that's perfect for a morning job or walk. If you go to the northwestern end, you can stand in the center and look down all the way to the sea - a lovely view. It's in fact where the first photo on this TripAdvisor page for this was taken.
reviews/15/text: Beautifully yet simply laid out park at the northers end of the Avenida de Libertade.Wide pathways and a selection of features including statues. Somewhere to come when the bustle of the shopping areasgets too much. The gentle walk uphillleads you to an area where there aregreat views of the city down to the River Tagus. Recommended
reviews/15/title: A haven from the bustle of the centre of thecity
reviews/16/text: We were here several times on our hop-on bus and enjoyed the expansive views of the city.  Some substantial neighborhoods around.  It's a big park, lots of green space, on the hill.
reviews/17/text: Beautiful clean park, even better greenhouse! There is a greenhouse on the property that is huge and beautiful. I’ve never seen so many plants in my life. It smells like wisteria and roses inside. Absolutely stunning, it’s the largest greenhouse I’ve ever seen. Definitely worth it.
reviews/18/text: A pretty park. We enjoyed the views whilst riding electric scooters, it was a gorgeous escape from the busy city.
reviews/19/text: This is a massive park in the middle of the city.  It is quite a hike from the other tourist areas, but it's a lovely setting to relax and take in the views of the city.  There are sculptures and gardens to explore or just sit on a bench and people watch.  Lots of dogs and kids running around enjoying the green expanse!
reviews/19/title: Escape the hustle and bustle of the city!
subcategory_ranking: #65 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Largo Sao Vicente, Lisbon 1100-572 Portugal
description: The Monastery of São Vicente de Fora (St. Vincent Outside the Walls) is one of the most important historical buildings in the city of Lisbon. It was founded by the first Portuguese king, in the 12th century. Over the centuries, several kings have introduced many changes, including the rebuilding in the 16th century. Today it is still possible to see the original cistern, as well as the cloisters, decorated with tiles from the 18th century, being of special interest the collection that depicts the fables of LaFontaine. The Monastery also houses the Pantheon of the last Portuguese dynasty, the Braganza, and a very well decorated Sacristy. At the end of the visit you can go up to the rooftop of the church and enjoy one of the best views over the Tagus river and the city.
name: Mosteiro De Sao Vicente De Fora

reviews/0/text: Lovely cathedral with great views over the city. Nice museum, big enough to pay EUR 5 entrance. Nice courtyards, well maintanted
reviews/1/text: As of March 2023 the cost for entry is 5 euro paid only in cash. The monastery itself is pretty but some parts are definitely more well-maintained than others. Case in point I saw a pigeon poop on a 16th-century painting of Saint Anthony while I was there. I visited the church to see the tomb of Catherine of Braganza, Queen of Charles II of England and it was a very moving crypt where she and the rest of her family are laid to rest. there are also breathtaking views of much of Lisbon from the cathedral roof.
reviews/2/text: The Monastery is beautiful. It may be off track because a bit farther from the city centre, but with the famous tram 28 and a bit of stairs, the place deserves a visit. Better early in the morning at the opening because after a while the number of visitors increases. Cheaper and more beautiful than the Jeronimos Monastery in Belem.
reviews/3/text: Wasn't sure whether to make this sight a priority, but very pleased that we did. Spent almost three hours here roaming all around. It's just lovely. Not crowded and very peaceful. Spectacular views from the rooftop!
reviews/3/title: Really enjoyed exploring this beautiful monastery
reviews/4/text: Looks like a large and impressive place...I circled around but couldn't find a way in, all was locked...my guess is that this place is probably also subject to the current covid-19 restrictions :-(
reviews/5/text: We very much enjoyed the visit. Very well indicated all along and beautiful views from the top. A lot better to visit than Castelo de S Jorge.
reviews/5/title: Very nice visit including great view over the city
reviews/6/text: Go to the top of the church to enjoy the best view in Lisbonne -360 degree views on the sea, bridge, monument, gardens,…..
reviews/7/text: The cloisters of St. Vicente de Fora contain one of the finest displays of blue-and-white tile work on display anywhere in Lisbon. Amazingly, all the depicted scenes are secular rather than religious in nature: scenes of the hunt and court life, with (shockingly!) even a few women depicted. Equally impressive is the sacristy that bisects the two courtyards, which still impresses for its wealth with its soaring marble walls and richly decorated ceiling.
reviews/8/text:
Was not too are whether to visit to not, as they make a charge to view. However, the charge was very good (Dec 22 - €5 for adult with reduced for concession and children).

Well, it was extremely great value. We followed the route designated, looked at some wonderful history and read great explanations and descriptions of what we were looking at. 

Eventually, we reached the end; being the towers and the great views of the city.

We were very relaxed during our self made tour and took two hours to take in so much information on the history of the most iconic and important 12th century building in Lisbon.

The staff we met were extremely helpful an friendly. We also visited the shop, which is at the end of the visit, that takes you back to reception, in which the staff there were just as friendly and helpful.

We think we saw about as much as we could in one visit; understand they also do guided tours, if preferred. If we visit the city again, would definitely revisit the monastery and church.

Brilliant. A must when visiting Lisbon.
reviews/8/title: Brilliant. A must when visiting Lisbon.
reviews/9/text:
It is very much worth a visit.

It is well worth it see the lovely cathedral, the water storage area and all the innards of the monastery with alot of the preserved relics and artworks.

It is not very expensive either, I can't remember exactly but either 5 or 10 euros each. Well worth it either way. The views at the top of the bell towers are the best in Lisbon, we didn't even bother visiting the castle after this as it was so impressive.
reviews/9/title: If you go to Lisbon then you must visit
reviews/10/text: The monastery is so rich in history, but you will not know it unless you take a guided tour. When you reach the monastery ask for the guided tour schedule for the day, and try to book one. The cost for the guided tour is €2,50 per person in addition to the €5.00 price of admission, and there are senior and student discounts. We took the 90 min English tour with Miguel (monastery guide) and it was fabulous. Miguel was very thorough and we learned a lot of important details abut the monastery, the city, the country, and the monarchy plus a bit of world history in relation to the monastery. Without the history this place is just another museum, mausoleum, and church. Most of the Portuguese Royalty is buried here including an English Queen, and a very popular and worldwide famous Saint lived here. The staff is friendly, helpful, and fluent in English. We went on a Sunday morning and the monastery was practically empty to our surprise.
reviews/10/title: Guided Tour Is A Must Here!
reviews/11/text: We have traveled all over the world and this property is special. It is unbelievable that most of this property was started in 1147. Take your time to experience this treasure. The tile work is unbelievable. Sit in the courtyard and visualize how old this place is. The collection of vestments, ornate crosses and numerous other artifacts are some of the finest I have ever seen. This is truly one of the most exquisite historical architectural experiences I have ever enjoyed. My wife is not a fan of museum type experiences and she truly loved this tour.
reviews/11/title: This is a must visit, spectacular
reviews/12/text: Beautiful, tranquil, an oasis with fantastic views of the city from the roof. I went to see the burial places of the royals but there is so much more to see. Well recommended.
reviews/12/title: Beautiful views and an amazing building.
reviews/13/text: Apparently, this monastery isn't heavily trafficked, but it's a great way to get views of the city. We decided to do a tour and got Miguel, who was wonderful. We learned a lot more about Portuguese history than we ever would have and got to appreciate far more of what was in the building than we would have alone. I think it's worth a trip!
reviews/14/text: We really enjoyed this. We aren't particularly religious but found it a claming and beautiful oasis. The display of Las Fonatine's tales were good fun and beautifully made (like Aesop's fables). We spent a long time reading those. The view from the roof was breath taking. Highly recommend for that alone.
reviews/14/title: Interesting with great views and courtyards.
reviews/15/text: I would pay the €5 just for the views! There is also some very pretty azulejos and a chapel. It was very empty when we went despite the time of year
reviews/16/text:
Located on top of one hill 
On Tuesday morning there is à flee market just behind , interesting .
The church access is free of charge but you have to pay 5 euros for the monastery 
And it s worth it !
Nice architecture , stunning element , the church inside between the 2 courtyards is so unique 
And the best is the terrace with the view !
reviews/17/text: Ensure you go to the top of the monastery during your visit otherwise you will miss out on some great views. Very interesting tilework inside as well.
reviews/18/text: Unfortunately credit cards are not accepted! It‘s 2022!!!! I can‘t wait for the day when acceptance of credit cards are required by a law - everywhere!
reviews/19/text: A lot of people visit this place for the roof top view, but the real beauty is the interior of the monastery and the room with the graves. This is also a good place to view a lot of tiles.

description: Erected in the honor of Portugal's Prince Henry the Navigator in 1960, this is a dramatic work of art in stone that commemorates Portugal's many famous explorers and adventurers.

reviews/0/text: Padrão dos Descobrimentos is a stunning monument that pays homage to Portugal's colonizing past. While the architecture and views are impressive, it's important to note that the monument commemorates a time of colonization and exploitation. It's unfortunate that this aspect of history often goes unmentioned. Nonetheless, the monument serves as a reminder of the country's rich history and is worth a visit for those interested in learning about Portugal's past
reviews/0/title: A Stunning Monument That Tells the Untold Story of Portugal's Colonizing Pas
reviews/1/text: There are nicer places to visit in Lisbon, so going there it is just a tick in the box. Nonetheless it is an impressive monument. Access is not particularly easy. Take an Uber and cheap and easier.
reviews/2/text: This is one of the Lissabons symbols and with the right reason. The emigration of Portuguese people once in the history showed in white stone
reviews/3/text:
What an amazing sculpture and fantastic views from the top (there is an elevator!)
It is in the most beautiful square with an amazing world map on the ground, dedicated along with the statue, to the explorers from Portugal’s past. Well worth a visit
reviews/4/text: This is an interesting and well-done monument to Portuguese explorers in the age of discovery. We didn’t bother going inside but did take photos of both sides (different people). Don’t forget to look at the map in the square pavings next to the monument,  donated by South Africa - it’s also worth seeing and very well done.
reviews/5/text: We paid €10 per adult and expected to see some information displayed inside. Instead you go up in the elevator and after some flights of stairs you reach the view point. The view is nice however it is not worth €10 per person. The outside is enough to see and is free.
reviews/6/text: Worth a visit when you are in the area for the other attractions.  Quite impressive to see the explorers all represented.
reviews/7/text: Totally forgot that Henry the navigator was from Portugal. Didn't know that this statue was here until a friend pointed it out but I'm glad that I saw, it it is an artistic marvel. Best seen from the water so book a boat cruise out,
reviews/7/title: Henry the Navigator is from Portugal?
reviews/8/text: A beautiful monument even better up close! Give yourself a break from the many stairs of Lisbon and take the elevator to the top for gorgeous views. It is a 10euro ticket for adults and 5euro for 13-25.
reviews/8/title: Give your legs a break and take the elevator to the top!
reviews/9/text: There are monuments... and then there's this monument! Somewhat impressive from a distance and seriously impressive in close proximity. It truly represents the history of Lisbon and its wonderful cultural mindset. Worth taking the elevator to the top for the bird's eye view. My favorite is the marble plaza with a map of the world depicting all the places in the world that Portuguese navigators explored.
reviews/10/text: It is an enormous monument and tribute, and really impressive to see both up close, and from a distance with the water and bridge in the background.
reviews/11/text: Monument to the Discoveries or as the visitor map indicated Padrão dos Descobrimentos, was interesting to view from ground level as we approached the monument built in 1960, on foot, but will not appeal to all visitors.   With no intention of possibly returning to Lisboa in the near future, we took advantage of a short wait time to go up 52m to the top level and enjoy the unrestricted views of parts of Lisboa along the Tagus and taking note of the information supplied.
reviews/12/text: You just have to go and look and marvel at the sheer size and magnificence of it. It is also free to look at - so it's a no-brainer really!
reviews/13/text: Impressive monument to visit. It commemorates explorers that left Portugal to travel the world. It also has an observatory on top with wonderful views of the water, bridge, and nearby landmarks. Awesome place to visit along the water.
reviews/14/text: We only viewed this from the outside as we'd already been in the Tower of Belem and we thought the views would be very similar. Very impressive structure.
reviews/14/title: Worth walking to if you’re visiting area
reviews/15/text:
It’s quite enough just see the monument outside, which is free and great.   Don’t waste money on  entrance fee into museum, which increased to 8.5 euros from 5 for seniors, a 70% increase starting on January 1, 2023,  however the increase has not been mentioned in any official websites.  

The monument is 6 story high, but museum is only a very small room  in basement, really nothing much to see  maybe just 5 minutes , which just tells you the background stories of building it.  The rest of all 5 stories are closed to visitors,  maybe not part of museum? The only other thing to do is go to the roof top to see the city view, which you don’t need to spend more than 10 Euros, it’s not worthy.
reviews/15/title: Just see outside, Don’t waste money for entrance fee
reviews/16/text: Quite a dramatic monument facing out into the harbour. The detail is worth spending some time to view. There is also a large map on the ground in front of it
reviews/17/text: Padrão dos Descobrimentos (Monument of Discoveries) which is an incredible piece of extraordinary artwork. Full kudos to the creative abilities of the architect and designer. One is spellbound by the intricacies of the statues that depicts historical figures ranging from religion, philosophy and obviously adventurers and explorers.
reviews/17/title: Incredible piece of artwork - must seen
reviews/18/text: Lovely building to visit and view from the outside, I would not recommend climbing the stairs or using the lift to the tiny viewing platform at the top. Although if you want to, you’ll be able to see the monastery, and the ‘golden gate’ bridge but you are not missing out if you choose to just admire the outside.
reviews/18/title: Curious building to view from the outside
reviews/19/text: This is an absolutely awe-inspiring structure that looks impressive from any angle. The lift, for which you have to pay, takes you up to near the top, and then there are around twenty steps to climb to get out onto the viewing platform. From the top the view is absolutely amazing. Definitely worth a visit if you are in the area.

reviews/0/text:
建築物的外面是非常好看，但內部空空如也。不只是進去塔內需要排隊，差不多一個小時之後進去每一層也需要排很久的隊伍，但上到去，內部根本沒有值得看的東西。寧願發多一點時間去看外面的漂亮建築。

The exterior is very nice while the inside is a little bit empty. The queuing time to enter the tower already very consuming, but you still need to queue to different floors inside the tower, which have nothing worth to see inside.

The queuing time in total composite more than 90% of the visit time of the tower. If we knew, we should save the money and spend the time to enjoy the beautiful exterior.
reviews/0/title: 排隊進去看空空如也的浪費
reviews/1/text: Its a great site and important site but paddling about on that little foreshore the sand is covered in litter and `other things`. They need a clean up as do the other little stretches back along the front - not enough litter control in such a wonderful place.  Back towards the town the front cocktails bar is a bit of rip off! More alcohol in my big toe.
reviews/2/text: You have to see Belem! One of the most beautiful part of Lissabon. Take walk by the sea, it is so much nice to see here in Belem
reviews/3/text: Beautiful tower sits majestically on water. Good sightseeing place but far from everything. Good place to visit.
reviews/4/text: Not really much to write. Interesting historically and in a great location, but nothing there to put it in context and unless we had been in Belem we would have been disappointed to travel just for this
reviews/5/text: Beautiful place, nice view this site is convenient located near other attractions by walking distance.
reviews/6/text:
To be completely honest, the best part of the Torre for us was the outside view when queueing to get in (which you will do - when we went there was no differentiation between those with pre-purchased timed tickets and those buying from the booth on the day). 
Once inside, there is the downstairs level with replica cannons to see (ok, but very plain and just cannons), then a flight of stairs up to the open first level. Here you can take photos of the main part of the tower and out onto the river, but you are not high up.
You then join another queue to wait to go up the tower. This turns out to be in several sections, the most interesting of which is the loggia balcony on the next level, which has good photo opportunities but is very small so crowded. You have to queue each time you change level, as the only access up or down is a single narrow spiral staircase. But you have to do every section once committed, even though to be honest those above the loggia, especially the chapel at the top, are nothing memorable at all. Then you queue to get back down to the open level (but luckily not for the final stairs to the entrance). 
So would I recommend this? Answer - yes, go see the outside but probably don’t bother going in unless it’s a really quiet day.
reviews/7/text: Easy to get to by taking the E15 tram to the monastery then walking along the sea front. Tide was out when I got there so could walk right up to the building. Its really quite impressive but never went inside just enjoyed the view. Some nice little parks in the area to to sit and relax
reviews/7/title: beautiful building in a nice location
reviews/8/text: We visited Belem Tower while in Lisbon this past March.  Being that this was labeled as a must see site, we were alittle underwhelmed.  The views are great and the architecture and history are unique, but overall its just okay.  We're glad we had the Lisbon Cards so we could skip the lines going in.  Even in March (off season) it was fairly crowded.  And the line to wait to go to the top portion of the tower was a long wait, and honestly not worth it.  There were other sites in Lisbon we enjoyed more than the tower.
reviews/8/title: Underwhelming site considering the strong reviews.
reviews/9/text: This tower is a beautiful sites with nice views. It has three different levels  including the ground one, all with nice things to see.
reviews/10/text: A great place by the ocean to spend a day.  Historical tower worth seeing along with other sites in the area. Makes for a full day
reviews/11/text: Charming old"fort" at end of river facing ocean, great photos spot and history of King. Cannons, great architecture and stairs leading to chapel and Kings Room.
reviews/12/text: We didn’t have time to go in but the outside is amazing and very photogenic. It is a very interesting area with lots to explore- well worth a visit.
reviews/13/text:
Got to the area early and was already quite busy. Waited around 20mins in a que to buy the tickets and then went over to the tower. 
We went straight in. We found we hand to que to get to every section which was frustrating and time consuming however there is only one set of stairs to get up and down the tower so ques are inevitable whilst one group goes up and another goes down. 
Could have done with some form information plaques round the tower as left still without knowing much. 

As we left the ques were horrendous, a massive que for tickets, an extremely long que to enter the tower and so on. So would highly recommend getting there no later than 10am!
reviews/13/title: Must see but get there early!
reviews/14/text: We queued for a long time to get into the tower and then we’re disappointed by the lack of information inside. However, it was great for views of the 24 April Bridge and the statue of Christ on the other side. Access to steps inside the tower was expertly managed by the staff.
reviews/14/title: Long queue. Not much written detail
reviews/15/text: A nice place to visit and walk around and take pictures!! The day we visit it was very windy!! but worth to go!!
reviews/16/text: Great spot to see if coupled with other attractions in the area! If going solely for the tower, it won’t take you a huge amount of time to explore. However, it’s a beautiful structure nonetheless.
reviews/17/text: We arrived at Belem Tower on a lovely Thursday afternoon in March we had read that with our Lisbon card we could get in quicker not a chance we had to wait for 30 minutes just like everyone else.Once through the Belem Tower gates you are within the lower section then you had to get in another queue to go higher up in the tower.After ten minutes we went up into the other sections and to be honest I wish we had spent our time doing something else.The Belem tower needs more information which could bring the experience alive as most people who visit will leave the tower not really knowing what it is all about.
reviews/18/text: We passed by the Tour de Belem when we were waiting for our boat cruise into the river. We learned from our boat captains later that day that prior to the earthquake of 1755 the tower used to be in the middle of the river and was thus much more imposing, The quake having diverted the river some ways inland. I have to agree it's a little underwhelming when you see it up close at the edge of the water.
reviews/18/title: Would have been cooler before the 1755 Quake
reviews/19/text: Really. Impressive building. Worth going inside (in our opinoin). We got there early, but there were pretty long lines when we left.
subcategory_ranking: #7 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

description: Considered to house the best collection of Portuguese and European art, this museum features works by Gonclaves, Bosch, Raphael and more.
name: National Museum of Ancient Art

offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Experience Lisbon in style with our electric talking car
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon Combo: Hop-On Hop-Off Tour with Three Routes Including Tram

ranking: #31 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #31 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: We decided to spend our time in the separate Portuguese section which I would highly recommend in order to enhance your visit to Portugal.
reviews/1/text: Interesting museum and quite beautiful infrastructure.  Whilst we are not keen Museum visitors but we did find the museum’s collection of painting, sculpture, goldware, furniture, textiles, ceramics, and prints interesting.  In addition to Portuguese exhibits, they are also exhibits from China, India, Japan and Indonesia.  The museum is very comfortable to walk around.
reviews/1/title: Interesting exhibits and beautiful building and inside
reviews/2/text: Building from exterior is deceptive of the feast for the eyes waiting inside. Floor after floor and room after room of beautiful art & relic displays. My husband is not typically fond of museums and even he was impressed by this one! Lovely outdoor garden for taking a rest so that you can enjoy more. This world-class museum is a must-see in Lisbon. Staff is helpful & friendly.
reviews/2/title: Amazing visit at this most impressive museum
reviews/3/text: Perhaps we arrived with different expectations from other visitors but my husband and I loved the Museum. We weren’t particularly bothered by the absence of the Bosch as there was such a variety of items to see. In particular I would highlight the jewellery with the miniatures, the large boxes with illustrations inside the lids and the screens showing the trade connection with Japan. Excellent value (€12 for admission for both of us) and s lovely garden to have a coffee and look out over the docks.
reviews/4/text: I baffled by the curator of this museum. Why would you allow the two most important pieces of your collection to be out at the same time without a replacement? The one and only Bosch is in Milan until March 19th, could they not have traded? The Saint Vincent panels are being restored, but you can see part of that process. The museum is nicely spaced out, no lines and there are some interesting works, but we were definitely disappointed.
reviews/5/text: The Bosch is out on a tour to Munich (I think).  Other than that the collection is static, no great additions.
reviews/6/text: Well, if I had been on my own, I would have spent quite a few hours here, but my wonderful Portuguese friend who does not really like art practically walked through the museum without stopping. Didn't leave me much of a choice. What I did manage to see was wonderful, including the Panels of St. Vincent.
reviews/6/title: What I did see was great!
reviews/7/text: This was quite the collection of art, furniture, cutlery, instruments, statues and other things I'm sure I'm forgetting. Spent about 2.5 hours here (which included me taking many pictures of paintings and statues) and there was a temporary exhibit on games and how they influenced history where we spent an hour. At the time we went in Sept 2022, a few sections of the museum were closed. Note there are many galleries of furniture, silverware and decorations. They do have a Bosch painting, which was really cool to see.
reviews/8/text: Largest collection of Portuguese and European Art I have seen in Lisbon, Portugal 🇵🇹 . Great works on display from Hieronymus Bosch, Pieter Bruegel the Younger and many others. I enjoyed the European painting section of the museum the most but sculptures, gold and metal work are not to be neglected.
reviews/8/title: Largest collection of Portuguese and European Art in  Lisbon, Portugal 🇵🇹
reviews/9/text: A welcome respite from the exhausting 35 degree heat of an August afternoon, this charming and peaceful museum was simply wonderful.  Like most comprehensive art museums, it tended towards overwhelming.  BUT, that is no reason not to go.  This is a first rate art museum chock full of beautiful paintings and artifacts, the highlights of which come from Portugal's golden age (15th to 18th century).  I recommend 2- 3 hours.   Room after room of eye popping and engaging exhibits make you almost ashamed to have paid the modest entrance fee.  The entire experience simply reinforced my acquired understanding that Portugal was one of the most important nations of early modern Europe.
reviews/10/text:
A beautiful museum on the outside with an interesting collection on the inside. During our visit they had a special exhibition with the history of board games such as chess, which was very interesting. A lot of paintings and other old artifacts as well in the permanent exhibition. 

The ticket was €8 per person to access both the permanent and temporary exhibit which was well worth it. Highly recommend the ‘combo ticket’.
reviews/10/title: A beautiful museum with interesting art on the inside
reviews/11/text: This is a brilliant museum. There is something for everyone in here. It is well spread out and the staff are super friendly and helpful. The highlight for me was the Bosch painting; but there are so many wonderful things to see.
reviews/12/text:
We came to the Museum of Ancient Art on a Thursday morning.  There were not a lot of visitors.  We walked to the Museum from Time Out Square.  It took 20 mins and it was an easy walk.

the entrance fee was 6 Euro. There are 3 levels in the museum and it has a huge collection of different types of Portugal, European and Asian art work throughout different century.  Those include painting, altarpieces, glassware, ceramic, jewelry, furniture and religion accessories.  We spent 3-4 hours there and it was such an enjoyable visit.

We had lunch at the caferia at the lower level.  I am sorry to say the food was not my taste.
reviews/13/text: Nice collection, friendly staff.  A few very unique pieces - Triptych of the Temptation of St. Anthony in particular
reviews/14/text:
Created in 1884, the museum houses the most relevant public collection, from the 12th to 19th centuries: painting, sculpture, silver, gold, tapestries, decorative arts - Portuguese, European, African, and Oriental - including the largest number of works classified as ‘national treasures’.

The various halls are well set out and well lit.  Items are labelled in both Portuguese and English.

The museum also has a magnificent garden, with restaurant, overlooking the River Tagus.
reviews/15/text:
This is a reasonable large museum with a nice collection of Portughese and European Art. 
Jeroen Bosch - Altarpiece, The Temptation of St. Anthony is worth seeing for sure. 
Portuguese furniture evolution is quite interesting too. 

The museum garden is nice for sitting and having a coffee in between visiting parts of the museum. 

Unfortunately, the most beautiful part of the museum was closed when I was there. Maybe next time I'll get to see it :)
reviews/16/text:
Huge museum with 3 floors and a lot of paintings from both Portugal and other countries. The entrance is next to the garden overlooking the river.  Cheap entrance, and there are 3 levels, most of the paintings is on the 2nd level. There were some good exhibition on Portuguese-Japan expedition.  There's even a chapel inside the museum.
There were not many people there where I went, but that made it better for me since I can view all the paintings in peace. Great way to spend about 2-3 hours.
reviews/16/title: Large, art museum with great paintings
reviews/17/text: I liked the Museum but the Staff was very disappointing. They did not explain what we should see inside. The ladies in the Reception just give you a small paper. They did not say what is closed or open because of Coronavirus. Some Paintings are very beautiful. I loved the ones about Portuguese Expedition in Japan.
reviews/18/text: I visited on a Sunday, when entrance is free for residents of Portugal, whatever their nationality.  Otherwise, entrance is just €6.  The museum is a delight.  It's on 3 floors and the exhibits are well spaced and well displayed.  There is a garden at the back where you can just sit and relax amongst the statues, or you can buy coffee, soft drink and cakes in the cafeteria there.  There are nice views over the bay from the garden.
reviews/19/text: While it's not on the level of the Louvre, Uffizi, or Prado, it is a world class museum with an excellent collection.  It has a very good collection of fine metal pieces in addition to the expected paintings, etc.  Any serious lover of European painting should not miss this museum.
subcategory_ranking: #31 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

name: Arco do Triunfo

ranking_subcategory: #33 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: This Triumphal arch offer a viewing platform. If you have a Lisbon card, this entrance will be free for you. A must see in Lisbon!
reviews/1/text:
Enjoyed the atmosphere 
Minus the drug dealers and pickpockets in area.

Many restaurants to choose from. 

Great to walk around  but it s tourist area

More authentic for me was walking around near the castle
reviews/2/text: Beautiful arch that centers the plaza and is a great gateway to the city. The arch is impressive with its height, beauty, and many details. It's one of the most photographed monuments in all of Lisbon. It also has much history.  Awesome place to walk under.
reviews/3/text: Beautiful arch located right by the historical aqueduct and down the road from the chapel of Our Lady Of Monserrate. A little out of the way, but worth the detour.
reviews/4/text: Siting next to the Tagus river is where the  Rua Augusta starts. This triumphal arch is open to the public to climb for 2.50 euros giving you a 360 degree view of Baxia.
reviews/5/text: Located on the opposite side of the Tagus River, this arch is the access to Rua Augusta of the Praça do Comércio and for this reason anyone who visits Lisbon walks under it. Arco Triunfal da Rua Augusta, has six columns and is adorned with statues colossal in size to be clearly seen from below. The colossal figures of the Glory rewarding Valor and Genius are on the top while four historical figures are represented as well. The two bearded figures on the sides represent the two main rivers of Portugal, the Tagus and Douro. It is certainly a majestic triumphal arch.
reviews/6/text: Arco do Triunfo is another imposing monument which leads into a huge open square, they seem to appear in lots of cities around the world.
reviews/7/text: This is an imposing monument. The stonework is impressive and well preserved. It connects Rua Augusta to the Praça do Comercio and it is one of the most recognizable landmarks in the city of Lisbon. For a small fee one can go to the top and the views of the city are most rewarding.
reviews/8/text:
Beautiful Arch. Takes from the a huge open square to a wonderful street to walk, eat, shop. We picked up the local treat Nada and enjoyed the Buildings. Very well kept compared to other neighborhoods in Lisbon.
Go see the square admirer the arch and stroll all the way up a non steep hill to the Train Station.
reviews/9/text: This arch is beautifully decorated with three statues to it's peak along with many figurines underneath before the arch itself. It also has fabulous pillars and as a whole is exquisite architecture.
reviews/10/text: was crowded so great for people watching. pretty cobblestone pedestrian street that leads up to the arch. a lot of the walking tours meet here and some were free! so we were invited to join in and listen/follow. lots of street vendors nearby and close to the water
reviews/11/text: Beautiful architecture and square, should be on the list to visit if you are in Lisbon. On a sunny day it is necessary to bring a hat or sunglasses, all the white tiles are blinding 😎
reviews/12/text: As is the case with its plaza neighbor (the iconic, lively Praca do Comercio), this gorgeous arch is a must-see for anyone in Lisbon—I don’t care how old, how well-traveled, or how different you are. It’s a requirement for any and all, and in my book, it should be one carrying legal repercussions for those refusing to check it out! Lol! Just trust me and the thousands of other voices you’re probably hearing—it’s worth it. No need to enter the arch structure itself; admiring it from ground level is enough. It’s the definition of historic Lisbon.
reviews/12/title: A Hallmark of Anyone’s Lisbon Adventure
reviews/13/text: Beautiful historical site. The architecture and details on the arc is breath taking. I also recommend to see it at night when its illuminated. You can find multiple shops, restaurants and even a beach nearby.
reviews/14/text: This is Historical Place of Lisbon, the beauty is amazing and you will definitely enjoy the time. I was several times in this place and enjoy the all time. I would love to go again and again. Suggest everyone to go this Historical Place
reviews/14/title: Great Place of Lisbon you Shouldn't Miss
reviews/15/text:
Despite the tour guide we had which was not very good, Lisbon was a very nice city which we enjoyed.  Very hilly but nice. Lots of plazas and beautiful buildings.  The San Jorge Castle situated high above the city offers great views.

Many restaurants to choose from offering all kinds of foods. There are many day trips you can do from Lisbon, such as Sintra and Obidos. We also went to Coimbra, Nazare, Porto, Aveiro, Fatima, etc.

I would recommend a trip to Portugal, not just Lisbon, but to see it all, you need to be able to walk and don't mind steep inclines.
reviews/16/text:
This review is for the general area, which it has to be said is lovely. The largest square in Lisboa it flanked on either side with restaurants and bars, with shops behind them. 
The main square has an impressive monument in the centre with the Arco do Triunfo behind and the river in front. It’s generally a cool place to be and soak in the scenery.
reviews/17/text:
Praca do Comercio is the main and biggest square in Lisbon which once housed the Royal Palace until the devastating 1755 earthquake.
The most eye catching feature on the square is this glorious Triumphal Arch, set in the middle of yellow arched state edifices on both sides of it.
The Triumphal Arch represents Portugal's victory over the earthquake, as the city was rebuilt from rubble after it under Marquis de Pombal who redesigned and rebuilt much of the city.
You can climb the Arch for elevated views for a small fee, but there's really no need for that as Lisbon has many free Miradouros on his hills.
reviews/18/text: This lovely arch is the gateway from the city to the Praca do Comercio,  In many ways, this square is the centre of Lisbon and the archway is the entrance.  The statues at the top,  represent Glory rewarding Valor and Genius.  Originally designed as a bell tower, the building was ultimately transformed into an elaborate arch.
reviews/19/text: Very beautiful architecture on the commercial square.  It was  steps away from my hotel on Rua Agusta.
subcategory_ranking: #33 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Largo de Santa Luzia Alfama, Lisbon 1100-487 Portugal
name: Miradouro de Santa Luzia
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Private City Kickstart Tour: Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Lisbon Historic Center Private Tuk Tuk Tour 3h
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon´s Private Walking Sightseeing Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Lisbon by Heart_ Private Tour
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Lisbon Private Luxury Tour
ranking: #53 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #53 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: In Lisbon, there are several Miradouro  that offer beautiful views of the city and relaxed seating options. In Alfama, this is the best one to see and take photos/ a break during your walks. Highly recommended!
reviews/1/text: We were here around 6:30pm on a Thursday and it was packed!  We made a quick loop through, since we had our twins & their giant double stroller, but it was quite beautiful!  And the views were pretty too!  I just love that the lookout area is so nice so you can enjoy that as well as the view out.  It's not often you get a nice, pretty place to sit that matches the nice view.  I don't think the views are anything special, mostly because you're mostly seeing white building with reddish roofs and some water but perhaps I'm biased.
reviews/2/text: Fantastic place to sit and have a drink or coffee when exploring Alfama. Views are spectacular, lively atmosphere.
reviews/3/text:
Lisbon has several viewing platforms, but I believe this one is the best. The first time I visited it, it was cloudy and felt very disappointed, because I was expecting something else. However, I did visit it again, when it was sunny and the whole experience was magnificent! The view was breathtaking!

As you can imagine, the place was extremely crowded! It was hard to find a spot to lean and take photos. Perhaps a morning visit is better.

Overall, this place is a must visit when in Lisbon.
reviews/4/text: In my view Santa Luzia is the most beautiful of all the Lisbon Miradouros. Pretty balcony with Azulejos work and bougainvillea. Traditional music being played. Nice calm atmosphere. One can spend 1-2 hrs sitting there
reviews/5/text: We went to this lookout using the very popular tram 28 which stops right in front of the miradouro. From here you can easily observe the Alfama district and the Tagus river standing quietly under the characteristic pergola covered with bougainvillea. Interesting are the azulejos on the south wall of the terrace depicting the Lisbon Commerce Square and the battle in the Castle of São Jorge. A few tens of meters away there is a panoramic terrace, Miraduro das Portas do Sol, which, although less romantic and more crowded, offers an excellent and even better view of Alfama.
reviews/5/title: A romantic lookout with a bougainvillea pergola
reviews/6/text: A lovely little veranda to get nice photos of Alfama and the river. However, if you go two minutes next door to Portas do Sol the views are even better as that terrace sticks out further and therefore gives better views. This is a pleasant experience though as you will visit both of them.
reviews/7/text: This is one of the nicer viewpoints in Alfama. What is different about this one is that it's located inside a small garden, which in itself is quite nice. There were also a couple of musicians there. A nice stop in Alfama.
reviews/8/text: Lovely place to stop and look over the rooftops of Alfama. Iconic trams in the background as well as the inevitable tuktuks.  Buskers normally performing.  A great place to soak up the atmosphere of Lisbon.
reviews/9/text:
This is one (out of many) of the most famous and beautiful Miradouros in Portugal capital. It's set in the central, lower part of Alfama some 200 m uphill from the Se Cathedral.
Miradouro is aside the same name Church of Santa Luzia, and both, the Miradouro and the Church have beautiful Azulejos on their facades. 
Best is to come late afternoon when sun shines on the National Pantheon and that eastern part of town along with the Tagus river.
There're always some street musicians playing which just adds to terrific atmosphere.
reviews/9/title: One of the most famous Miradouros
reviews/10/text: Lovely view of the city - we enjoyed a treat at the cafe where we sat and took in the views. Go when you visit Castelo S. Jorge.
reviews/11/text: I chanced on this whilst on my early morning (OK so 9AM) walk. Fantastic view across the town to the river
reviews/12/text: It seems the done thing when in Lisbon is to take a tram to a view point. All of them have little cafés where you can grab a coffee and a pasteis de nata (custard tart), which is always welcome. The view from here was pretty good and on such a sunny day as was the day we went, it was really lovely.
reviews/13/text: Yet another great view from the upper hillside, this time of the river and the hillside below.  Of course a great place to stop, sit a while and take a lot of photos.
reviews/14/text: Nice atmosphere but busy.  Limited area to actually see the views.  Loved the tiles and music.  There are coffee shops and restaurants to enjoy the views as well (if you get a seat).
reviews/15/text:
The perfect evening spot to have a snack, sit outside and take in the beautiful views. The restaurant is a walk up to the window type, and while they were sold out of some items at 8 pm there was still plenty to choose from, the prices were reasonable. The next level up is like a park, lots of places to sit, and see the beautiful water views.  

The only caution is the Tuk Tuk drivers, we were in the very same spot Wednesday afternoon and took a Tuk Tuk to our Airbnb for €10, on Saturday night they quoted €20 for the same two people (grandmother and child). Needless to say we declined (the Uber was €3,25) as the Tuk Tuk drivers kept lowering their prices for us to no avail. Expect to pay around 3 times the price of Uber for the Tuk Tuk (which has been typical all week) but 6 times is ridiculous.
reviews/16/text: A pretty view and gorgeous tiles. We stayed for 5 minutes whilst exploring Alfama, a cute photo opportunity!
reviews/16/title: A view of the ocean & authentic tiles
reviews/17/text: We were not impressed with the view after seeing the incredible view from the castle, but the tiles on the terrace and on the church are so beautiful!
reviews/18/text: Nice area to stop en route to the Sao Jorges Castle and take in the view.  It's convenient to the #28 Tram/Trolley if you want to ride that there. We walked up from the Lisbon Cathedral (Se').  There were quite a few people up there ... busy area. We were hoping to eat at a restaurant there but it was not open, which surprised us.
reviews/18/title: Lovely flowers around a nice terrace (crowded though)
reviews/19/text: The area is nice with a water feature (which was empty) nice mural of the city on the wall. The views are disappointing however.
reviews/19/title: Nice area to view an average view however
subcategory_ranking: #53 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Praca do Imperio, Lisbon 1300 Portugal
name: Santa Maria de Belem Church
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Belém and Jerónimos Monastery Guided Small Group Walking Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Belém District and the Salazar Dictatorship Legacy - Private Walking Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Private Walking Tour in Belém
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: The Essence of the City - Lisbon Compact
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: The Portuguese Colonial Empire
ranking: #27 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #27 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Spectacular church, highest ceilings I have ever seen, incredible Gothic arhitecture with stain glass, Vasco Da Gama tomb, truly breathtaking. Must see
reviews/1/text:
We were so disappointed that on a Tuesday mid-morning this church was closed for a function. It was our last chance in Lisbon to go inside this church. We didn't know of its closure until we saw the sign on the door. We were limited to examining the detailed carvings of an exterior church door which faced the street. Between the doors was a statue of Prince Henry. Above him were intricate carvings of exotic plants and animals that explorers had seen on their journeys. Images of twisted rope surrounded a high window. These carvings, done in the 16C, looked eroded and, being so high up, I needed my telephoto camera lens to see the skilled craftsmanship. Since this church was one the seamen visited prior to their leaving Lisbon on ships, the replacement of the usual religious images for exotic lands are explanatory.  Also this church was paid for by the spice trade, particularly pepper.  
 
This church, which should be closed only on Mondays, has free entry. It is the Cloister that requires a fee. There was a line-up to visit the Cloister, probably longer than usual, as the Church was closed on the Tuesday we visited. This church is attached to the Jeronimos Monastery. Each doorway on the block long exterior of the Monastery is the same.  One was the entrance to the Archaeology Museum and on the side, the entrance was to the Marine Museum. Each has a separate entry fee.
reviews/1/title: Unexpectedly closed for a function on a Tuesday
reviews/2/text: When you arrive at the Monasteiro dos Jeronimos, although the access is the same, there are usually two queues, the one on the right is for the Church of Santa Maria and the one on the left is for the Monastery. If you want to visit the church, just get in the right line as access is free even if regulated to avoid overcrowding. For this reason normally you have to wait in line for for ten to twenty minutes. The visit of this church is very interesting and inside there are also two more recent Neomanueline tombs in which the mortal remains of the explorer Vasco da Gama and the main Portuguese poet Luís de Camões were transferred.
reviews/2/title: To be visited together with the Monastery
reviews/3/text: Beautiful church from the outside to inside, free to enter the queue moves quickly , huge pillars and high ceiling, contains the tomb of Vasa Da Gama.
reviews/4/text: This is a most beautiful church, and entry is free. The stone work is superb making for a most exquisite interior. There is a side door facing the street and the front door (entrance door) next to the entrance to the Monastery. Allow about 30-45 min for your visit depending how full the church is. The front door opens at 10:30AM on weekdays for visitors and a queue will form about 30 minutes before. Most of the staff is friendly, except for a large man with a mustache who mans the side door (pictured here). Don’t approach him as he is most unfriendly and extremely rude. Very unusual for someone employed by a religious institution. They usually are better people, but not him. I recommend visiting the Church and the Monastery as they are next to each other. You will need a ticket for the Monastery.
reviews/4/title: Vasco da Gama & Camoes Are Buried Here
reviews/5/text: This is a beautiful church with grand high steeples upon entry. It is exquisite inside with wonderous high ceilings and pillars that are all majestically carved. It has a lovely laid out altar and houses the tomb of the explorer Vasco da Gama.
reviews/6/text: I saw from the inside of the Monastery, which it adjoins. It was an ornate, lovely church, but I didn't feel that I needed to make a special trip just for this. Worth a look if you're there, though!
reviews/7/text:
The Santa Maria Church attached to the Jeronimo Monastery is so gorgeous, both inside and outside.
Terrific flamboyant Manueline architecture adorns it, while the interiors are stunning with a beautiful altar, fab stained glass and Vasco de Gama ornate tomb.
Entrance to the Church is free, but I suggest also paying the fee to visit the Jeronimo Monastery (see that review).
reviews/8/text:
The free queue to get in the church was massive when we went, I'm not sure if it was because there was a limit due to covid protocols or because it is always busy on easter weekend.

We had a Lisboa card so walked straight into the monastery and got to view the church from above.  The high ceiling and support pillars are really impressive and frame the stained glass windows.

You probably only need about 30 minutes to have a look around, as it is just the main body of the church, but still definitely worth a visit, although if you have the time and money/Lisboa card it is worth heading into the Monastery to see that little bit more.
reviews/8/title: Beautiful church viewed from the monastery
reviews/9/text:
We viewed the church attached to the monastery, not the monastery. There are two lines. We picked the shorter line. There was no fee. There were no people monitoring dress for entry. There were signs advising behavior.
Upon entry you are struck by the pillars which resemble palms. The floor plan is very open and beautiful.
All along the area are wonderful, fanciful carvings. 
Vanco de Gama is buried in this church.
reviews/10/text: We ended up visiting this beautiful church by accident as we  mistook the entrance for that of the monastery but I am very glad we did.  Stunning stone building. Some of the decorations included elephants which was unusual and interesting. Free entry.
reviews/11/text: Free entry to this magnificent church attached to the monastery.  Beautiful guided masonry. Ceiling, tombs altar stunning
reviews/12/text:
We been too late in the evening so missed much of the parts of this vast place.
However there is so much to see and enjoy both in the church and the beautiful
 monastery next to it.
reviews/13/text: Free to enter this single church unlike €10 for the beautiful monastery next door. And it is an amazing church, just wonderful, not just the main altar but side altars around the church, stained glass windows etc.
reviews/14/text:
This church is part of the Jeronimos Monastery and it is separate from the cloisters. It’s free to enter the church but will have to pay €10 for the cloisters. If you are wondering whether it’s worth doing both, I’d highly recommend visiting the cloisters also. They are very different and it is the cloisters that is the highlight. The church has some very interesting features but overall, it is rather gloomy and dark and does not prepare you at all for the magnificence of the cloisters and monastery grounds.
What you’ll see in the church are the tombs of the explorer, Vasco da Gama who died in India in 1524, the poet, Luís de Camões (died 1580) and King Manuel I (died 1521). You’ll also see a very striking ceiling, spanning an extraordinarily wide central nave (30m). The ceiling is a single span with ornamental branch-like tracery vaults.  Together, the vaults and the tall, slender trunk-like pillars that support the roof, create an overall effect that made me think of a forest.
If you are visiting the cloisters, make sure to find the viewing area where you get a special vantage point, looking down over the interior of the church towards the altar.
TIPS:
* There are 2 lines. The longer line on the right is for free entry to the church and the left hand line is for the cloisters. Here’s the catch - a cloisters ticket, doesn't get you into the church. You’ll have to exit the monastery grounds and line up again. We arrived early and went to the cloisters first but this was a mistake. By the time we came out of the monastery, the church line had grown much longer. If you're there early, I'd recommend visiting the church first when the line is likely to be shortest. 
* Closed on Mondays
reviews/14/title: Free Entry to Church But Don't Miss the Cloisters
reviews/15/text:
The building is lovely but I hated seeing the poor horses givin* carriage rides around the area.
Please don’t get a ride and encourage it.
I was there in September in 35 deg heat.
Poor horses working in full sun
reviews/16/text: A great facility for architecture lovers. Church where the tombs of Vasco da Gama and Luis de Camoes are located.  Magnificent vaults and altars with amazing figures. The representative southern portal, created by João de Castilho, is 32 m high and 12 m wide.  At the very top, the Archangel Gabriel watches over the eaves. The 24 nearly life-size figures, the apostles, saints and bishops are all under a canopy. The architect  created one of the most beautiful and unusual interiors in Portugal. The ribs open up from six slender columns,  to support the mesh vault at a height of 25 m.  Due to the rich structure, the columns look almost weightless and without a support function. Though this structure may seem fragile, it survived not only for nearly 500 years, but also a major earthquake in 1755 . Below the gallery, on the north side, is the Vasco da Gamas sarcophagus. The majestic Church of Our Lady in Belem is a must-see place, especially as the admission is free and the impressions are unforgettable.  I absolutely recommend it.
reviews/17/text: It is a church, but it is quite beautiful. Large, free admission and close to the Jerónimos monastery. A visit is to be made.
reviews/18/text: This UNESCO World Heritage Site church was built 1492-1528 in late Gothic/early Renaissance style.  Entrance was free and there were large crowds, so it was a little hard to navigate, but we were awestruck by the unbelievably high vaulted ceiling and the grey stone with lovely decorative roping that ran up the columns and across the ribs in the vaults above. There were a number of tall, thin stained-glass windows in really deep colors which did not  let in a lot of light, so the church had that dark, medieval feel.  The main altar combined gilt and marble with beautiful artwork.  Tombs of Vasco da Gama and Lagos Henriques (foremost Portuguese poet) are located in the back of the church.   The sacristy is the hidden gem—and they do charge admission for it (1.5 Euros), but it was definitely worth it.  The most distinctive feature is the column in the center of the room.  Springing from the top of it are the ribs of the vaulted ceiling.  Four additional columns connect to the central one via their vaulted ribs.  Because the ceiling is low in this room, it was easy to see the ribbed vaulting close up, rather than having to see it from so far away (like in the main sanctuary).  This church is truly a Gothic architectural marvel.
reviews/18/title: Breathtaking medieval church--incredible example of a Gothic rib-vaulted ceiling!
reviews/19/text: This church is stunning from the ouside, we went inside and listended to the mass in progress, sounded beautful.

address: Lisbon Portugal
description: Named after the famous 15th-century explorer, Vasco da Gama, this immense cable-stayed bridge across the Tagus River is eleven miles long, and punctuated with more than seven miles of bridges and viaducts.
name: Vasco da Gama Bridge

ranking_subcategory: #37 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: We have cross this bridge on the way to a beautiful beach in Costa do Caparica. It reminds on San Francisco bridge, and it is 3.8 km long.
reviews/1/text: The first I stopped to see upon arrival, walking from the Metro system, and a lovely long walk along the promenade until  you reach the bridge. Loved it... Stretching off into the distance.
reviews/2/text:
Lisbon is one of the nicest cities in the world. People are very friendly and kind.
Coffee and cakes are superb and vinho verde is an excellent all-around drink.
June 12 is the St Anthony fiesta and the whole of Central Lisbon is permeated with the smell of BBQ sardines. Azulejos, the ceramic tiles are the decoration signature across the whole of Portugal.  While in Lisbon do not miss Palacio della Fronteira on the outskirts of the city with easy connections. But make an appointment to Palacio; there are many functions there. And make sure you buy FADO CD; would help you to remember your experience of a good time in Lisbon but also in Portugal.
reviews/3/text: Now THIS is a bridge! We drove on it back and forth to Lisbon coming from Sesimbra. Magnificent architecture and great views, especially nice at night.
reviews/3/title: It's the second longest bridge in Europe!
reviews/4/text: An amazing bridge, the second longest in Europe after the Crimea Bridge at over 12km long, linking Lisbon and Montijo. When we were there the traffic queue to join the bridge was so long that unfortunately we did not get to cross the bridge, but driving alongside the River Tagus, the bridge is certainly architecturally stunning.
reviews/5/text:
Named after the famous Portuguese explorer, this is the longest bridge in Europe spanning over the Tagus river. 
It connects the new northeastern part of Lisbon - Parque des Nacoes (Nations Park) with a small town of Montijo across the bay.
If you have time, I suggest an interesting trip over this bridge, making a full circle through towns of Montijo and Almada and returning to Lisbon over the 25 April bridge (see that review). It will require around 2 hours with included stops on interesting places along the way.
reviews/6/text:
We went to visit the oceanarium and got a great view of the bridge from by the Vasco Da Gama tower.

Measuring 17km and barely able to see the end of the bridge it really is an impressive sight, well as bridges go.

Worth a visit just so its in the memory for the inevitable quiz question on The Chase.
reviews/7/text:
As soon as we planned to go to Lisbon, I planned to see and cross the Vasco da Gama bridge (not by foot) - the second longest bridge in Europe.

We went to Parque das Nacoes and the Vasco da Gamma Mall.  From this area, we took bus 431 (or bus 432) to cross the bridge to Freeport Outlet Mall.  

It was a wonderful ride on the bridge when the weather was nice.  I could see the bus leaving Lisbon behind and heading to a long journey to Montijo.  It took the bus 20 mins to cross the bridge.
reviews/7/title: Amazing bridge between Lisbon and Montijo
reviews/8/text: Did not cross it, but I walked a long way along the river in the Parc de Nocoes and I admired this very long bridge.  Most of it is down low close to the river, but there is a tall span to accommodate ships.
reviews/9/text:
This giant, snaking cable-stayed bridge is very impressive. At over 17km, it's the longest bridge in Europe - so long that it’s pretty hard to make out the end of it. It’s relatively new and was only opened to the public on 29 March 1998. Apparently it took 3,300 workers and 18 months to build it which I found an astonishingly short period of time. 
 It is named after the famous explorer, Vasco da Gama, who 500 years earlier in 1498 discovered the first sea route between Europe and India. He sailed via Africa at a time when no-one was really very sure whether the Indian and Atlantic Oceans were even connected. This was a game-changer and meant that all trading, including valuable spices, could now be done by sea instead of being trekked overland from India so it’s very appropriate that the bridge is named after him.
reviews/10/text: One of the most interesting bridges I have had the pleasure to cross. The Vasco da Gama Bridge was inaugurated on March 29, 1998. His name commemorates the 500th anniversary of Vasco da Gama's arrival in India in May 1498. Currently, it is the second largest bridge in Europe with a length of 17 km. A good alternative to the 25 de Abril bridge. A great work of engineering.
reviews/11/text: We were so mesmerized by the bridge when we first saw it. That we really did want to see it the next time if possible. One of the longest bridges in Europe. We wanted to film this experience. I am glad we could. Check it out on Channel NaanAndLuchi Travels. This is from Day5 Part1 of our trip. The bridge has a total length of 12.3 kilometers.
reviews/12/text: the bridge is very long. it takes quiet a long time to cross this very long white bridge across the river
reviews/12/title: the most longest bridge i have ever seen
reviews/13/text: We travelled on the Vasco da Gama Bridge on a Bus when we left Lisbon to go to Seville, in Spain. This is a very long bridge indeed. It is 17 kilometres long and it acts as a link, connecting two parts of Portugal! The bridge opened to traffic in 1998, the same year the International Lisbon Expo was held. In fact it was parts of the works, leading up to that Expo.  And of course it is named after the most famous Portuguese explorer.
reviews/14/text:
Once the longest bridge in Europe and named after a Portuguese famous explorer, it"s a pleasure to cruise along this bridge at sensible speeds.
As you leave Lisbon behind and cross the vast river. This bridge seems to go on for ever in a good way.
It's a treat to drive across it at sunset.
reviews/15/text: Every time I travel to and from Lisbon International, I end up taking this fantastic bridge that saves me a tremendous amount of time coming to or going away from Lisbon. It’s not at all busy like 25 April bridge, the reason I believe must have to do with the cost of rolling as you pull a tab and travel to your destination and that fee is based on the kilometres you have used it for... never the less, the amount of time you save is incredible (time is money 🤪) so I strongly recommend the use of the bridge/highway...
reviews/16/text: We visited the local area for the Cable Cars and went to see the Bridge, it was pretty impressive, much longer and larger than we had thought! Well worth a visit.
reviews/17/text:
Have seen it and pass over it . It is a great architectural monument and a masterpiece!!!! 
It is a must to see if you find yourself in Lisbon ,you will never forget its image!!!
reviews/18/text: An amazing bridge, the day we were there, it was quite misty, and the bridge seemed to just carry on, into the water, well worth a visit.
reviews/19/text: Walk from the Oceanarium to the bridge, by the sea, is absolutely amazing! The whole time you have beautiful view of the bridge and Vasco da Gama Tower. There are a lot of benches to rest, some great places to eat and drink. And the best thing is that it is not crowded.

address: Rua de Santa Cruz do Castelo Rua De Santa Cruz Do Castelo, S/n, 1100-129, Lisbon 1100-129 Portugal
address_obj/street1: Rua de Santa Cruz do Castelo
address_obj/street2: Rua De Santa Cruz Do Castelo, S/n, 1100-129
description:
Standing proudly on Lisbon's highest hill, this historic castle offers panoramic views of the city all around it. The fort dates back to the Moorish times in the 11th century, and has served as military barracks and royal chambers. Currently, it's a national monument which is home to a museum and archaeological site, though most people visit for the fantastic views and gardens to relax in. 

There are free and paid guided tours available in the ticket, as well as regular free demos for the camera obscura which provides 360º detailed views of the city in real-time 

– Tripadvisor
name: Castelo de S. Jorge

ranking: #6 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #6 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: We had a guided tour, which I recommend.  There is too much history to keep it all straight.  The grounds and views are outstanding.
reviews/1/text:
It is too many tourists here, but you gonna come in really fast. Wonderful viewpoint
So clean and nice. I say just yes  see it
reviews/2/text: Best stop of the trip.  Incredible views of the city and sea.  Note:  Buy tickets online!!  There was a huge queue of people waiting in line to get in, but it’s super easy to buy tickets online and you can just walk by the whole line of people standing in line and walk right in.  Watch out for the peacocks – they are everywhere and lovely.  Just note…if you feed them, they will follow you.
reviews/3/text: Fun place to wander. Great views of the city. Can be a bit crowded at times. Be sure not to miss the museum and active archeological dig area.
reviews/3/title: Great way to learn some history of the city
reviews/4/text: While getting aesthetics service we were advised to go to the castle and to make sure we took the audio tour. Perhaps the audio tour was a thing pre COVID but I assure you there was no information to be had about the castle upon entering. We simply roamed around looking at brick walls and statues. We asked one of the property guides if there was information to be had and she recommended we scan for information. We scanned and less than a page of information came up. Very disappointing.
reviews/4/title: It wouldn't be in my buckets list.
reviews/5/text: The most beatiful view i have eer seen in my life!! reaaly a good experience in lisbon!! we are so grateful!!!
reviews/6/text: This was a bit disappointing as long queues to get inside and once there wasn’t a great deal to see. The views were spectacular and walking the battlements offered a 360 of the city, but there was little to explain the historical significance of the castle and no facilities inside the walls itself.
reviews/7/text:
We were very pleasantly surprised by this castle! Yes there are no rooms, but the outer walls and ramparts are largely intact and it was thoroughly enjoyable spending time climbing around the various walls, towers etc. The archaeological site part is ok but you can’t see the Iron Age or Moorish remains as they are both covered over with no public access.
The main plaza is a stunning viewing area with absolutely superb views across the whole of Lisbon - we had great fun spotting places we had visited already as well as looking for others we were going to see later on!
There are a large number of resident peacocks which were very entertaining at times.
The easiest way to get to the castle is to use the 737 bus (we then walked back).
reviews/8/text: Great views but not an actual castle. A look alike castle was built in 1940 to look like what they thought was a castle site. Bought are pre time tickets online at 10am but ticket was issued for 9am. Audio download stopped working after 20 mins.
reviews/9/text: Really beautiful grounds and castle, great to be able to climb up to the ramparts and walk along the walls. The grounds have beautiful spots to sit and enjoy the view. I went up for sunset as the castle is open till 9 pm and there is a large open area facing west to be able to sit and enjoy it. Happily spent about 2 hours there even though it is not a large place.
reviews/9/title: beautiful spot to spend some time and enjoy the view
reviews/10/text:
Be aware: basically you just walk around on old walls. Really, without exageration. Be careful where you step. This place is extremely expansive for what it offer. You did enjoy "the dark room" session where you can see Lisbon is real time. The lady explaining was nice and interesting.
I forgot: the place is full of peacoks, nice detail.
reviews/11/text: Must see on your trip to Lisbon. Brilliant views and the peacocks are incredible. Worth the hike. Recommend going early to avoid the queues and the temp is cooler!
reviews/12/text: I'm not talking about the Castelo itself which is well worth a visit. However, I want to warn everyone about the Camera Obscura. Watch out for pickpockets! The camera obscura is a perfect place to get your pocket picked, take it from someone who knows.
reviews/13/text: Happy we decided to do this. The Castle is OK but it's the views you pay for. Absolutely beautiful/breathtaking views of Lisbon from every angle. You can walk up to the castle walls and see views from higher up. Lots of other things to do too, Museum and Shop and Courtyard. Tip: Buy the tickets before and when you arrive you do not need to join the huge queue you can go the left.
reviews/14/text: Mountaintop castle w exqusite peacocks, very interesting, not on Lisboa Card, 15 euros, worth it,  interesting museum included
reviews/15/text: The castle is the best thing to do in Lisbon. It gives you a view of the entire city. The entire Fort is just majestic. Best way to start the day. Make sure you buy the tickets online. Will save you time and the line is different for people who buy online. Took us 10 mins to get in at 10.30 PM.
reviews/15/title: Best Way to Start your day.
reviews/16/text: Neat hilltop castle with great views of the city of Lisbon. Sadly much of the historic palace was destroyed in the 1755 earthquake but the medieval fortress and its battlements remain to walk around. The coolest part was definitely all of the peacocks strutting around and calling out up in the trees. It was early spring so they were putting on a show for us and all the other peahens.
reviews/17/text:
I tried to visit this at night by taking the public bus (no. 737 or 747?) but it's closed already. I then went again in next morning and had spent over an hour there. One can overlook the city from there. To me, it's beautiful at daytime and mesmerised at nighttime. There are some eateries in the neighborhood outside the castle and worth trying. 

Last but not least, I was surprised and pleased to see quite some peacocks 🦚 around inside the castle. I rarely see peacocks in other places.
reviews/18/text: We saw large queues waiting for tickets so booked online (small reduction for seniors) which made for quick entry. Wonderful views all around - especially with the city bathed in sunlight but a heavy mist hanging over the Tagus. Not too crowded once inside. Be prepared for lots of climbing up on to the walls and  towers. Peacocks strutting their stuff - did not know they could fly up to the upper reaches of tall trees.
reviews/19/text: This is a beautiful and ancient castle that is located high on a hill in the beautiful Alfama neighborhood of Lisbon. Some tour guides had told us not to bother visiting the castle since only the walls remain and the lines to get in are usually very long. I am very glad we did not follow their advice because I would have missed probably the most amazing views of the city.  I also found that the castle itself was very interesting.  I recommend booking your visit online or, as we did, go very early in the morning (they open at 9 am) to avoid the lines.
