ranking_subcategory: #54 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text:
This is definitely where all the expensive shops are and while I didn't go into any stores, I definitely window-shopped.  There are beautiful tree-lined areas that run down the middle and the whole are is just really clean & nice.

We walked the avenue several times going to/from the Parque Eduardo VII, a large green open space that our kids enjoyed running around.  It was definitely out of our way and not on our normal route but the area is just a joy to be around.
reviews/1/text:
Liberty Avenue is patterned after the elegant Champs Elysees in Paris. It is about 1 mile long and contains ponds, fountains, and statues running from the Praca dos Restauradores to the Parque Eduardo VII.

It is the 5th Avenue of Lisbon with high international designer stores and luxury hotels.
reviews/2/text: Wide grand avenue that is a shoppers delight with so many high end shops mixed with them are hotels, various monuments dotted around and little sidewalk kiosks that you can enjoy, beware though cross at the crossings this is a very busy road.
reviews/3/text: Must see and walk at least a little. An Uber driver tould us that this was modeled after the Champs-Elysees. He said when they started building it ( after the earthquake) people asked "why do we need this?" Now they love it. There are many cities that have a similar street. We enjoyed walking for 3-4 blocks before lunch.
reviews/4/text:
Avenida de Liberdade is one of the main city streets, better say Avenues, running from Restaudores square to Marquis de Pombal square.
It's a wide avenue with double tree line pavements on both sides, decorated with terrific pavement Calcada Portuguesa cobblestone. The street is full of high end shops and exclusive hotels and restaurants.
I suggest walking it from Marquis de Pombal southwards as that way is slightly downhill.
reviews/5/text: Stretching from the Plaza de Pombal to the Plaza de Recueltos this is the main boulvard of Lisbon and perhaps the most prestigious boulevard in the whole of Portugal. There is everything here from tiny bars to luxury hotels and embassies. The Avenue itself is like a dual carriageway with a tree lined central reservation providing both shade in Summer and an area to walk if you dont want to window shop and are keen on avoiding the rather uneven pavements in some places. It is also wide enough to accomodate some cafes and stalls. Word of warning - cross the road at crossings; the traffic is fast and takes no prisoners!!
reviews/5/title: Great for a stroll and window shopping; good reference point.
reviews/6/text: Such a wide bisected avenue with sites monuments squares shops hotels and residences. April 25th is Independence day is so there were crowds of people for the parades and celebrations.b
reviews/7/text: It's a broad avenue with several lanes of busy traffic and a tree-lined center for strolling and sitting.  Some kiosques with drinks and food in the center.  Hotels, offices and luxury shops line both sides.  Served by the Metro.
reviews/8/text: Every country has one!  Lisbon's luxury shopping street for the rich.  Wide and spacious.  Generally well kept.  Worth a trip for designer shopping or if your staying in a 5 star hotel.  Don't bother otherwise.
reviews/9/text: A pretty, luxury shopping street. We hired out 2 electric scooters to travel up the street towards the park - it was a great place to see.
reviews/10/text: Avenida da Liberdade is an important boulevard in central Lisbon, Portugal, famous as one of the most expensive shopping streets in Europe. With national and international  cuisine, emblematic venues and dream hotels to relax. Avenida da Liberdade was inspired by Paris’ Champs-Élysées. It's a tree-lined avenue connecting two squares (Praça dos Restauradores and Praça Marquês de Pombal). Great place to shop.
reviews/11/text: Located right in the downtown of Lisbon, this walking path has multiple plazas, shops, restaurants and more. It is also remarkably clean and very safe.
reviews/12/text: a great walking street. you can choose the sidewalk in front of the businesses and stores or you can choose the leafy pedestrial concourses, with fountains, statuary, and kiosks serving drinks and snacks. lovely. stroll the entire length.
reviews/13/text: This is deemed to one of the more exclusive shopping areas of Lisbon with designer boutiques well out of my price league. Its a nice place to walk however with interesting patterned walkways and gardens and a few cafes for a drink.
reviews/14/text:
Below you can find my review from 2014.

Has anything been improved ?

The parking has become a bit better but the rest nothing has really changed.

The local drivers are really bad drivers and drive very fast, too fast in all situations. They really are bad drivers and e.g. turn corners in crossings without any consideration for crossing pedestrians.

The smokers on the street stand in clusters and at restuarants they show no concidertaion at all to non smokers. They even smoke cigars at the restuarants!
Stop all smoking outdoor at restaurants. Then all cigarette butts are trown on the streets.
At the two big malls in central Lisbon, there are smoking areas at the entrances/exits and they realy contaminate the suroundings and bad air spreads through the exit doors to the malls!!!

Is this behaviour really the Portuguese cultur to be proud off?
Sharpen up, improve, behave with consideration. Follow up.
Who are responsible? The local politicians?

All this is really disgusting.

Review from 2014

What so great about this run down street in a run down city....
Many buildings looks like after a raid during World War II. What are the authorities doing?

A lot of dog excrement every where, people spitting and slippery cobblestones all over this run down city, car parked wrongly all over on the sidewalks making it almost impossible to walk with a stroller, crazy men and women drivers everywhere, small filthy restaurants severing this food from ancient times named bacalau swimming in undefined oil.... Is this what is left of the old Portuguese culture is this the proudness of Portugal....

What are the authorities doing to stop the city's decay... who is implementing any laws who is following up, is there any program to self improve this situation... It is sorrowful to see......
reviews/15/text: The most beautiful avenue of Lisbon. You will see some beautiful paved walkways with patterns, and also  shops, cafes , monuments  and beautiful trees here. This is the  part of Lisbon with expensive shops and impressive buildings.The best shops around town and a nice place to walk around.
reviews/16/text: Lovely Avenue in the Centre of Lisbon with nice Shops ( Expensive Brands ) and nice Kiosks were you can sit and have a drink . Funny almost every Kiosk  has cold Beer from Draft which tastes good .
reviews/16/title: Very nice long Avenue in Lisbon
reviews/17/text: We stayed at a hotel very close to Avenida da Liberdade and we would walk up and down this beautiful road daily, for several days. It is very wide with trees and wonderful architecture. It is supposed to be a very expensive street with some really great shops including fashion shops, restaurants and cafes.  It's definitely worth walking along this great street.
reviews/18/text:
During my time in Lisbon, my wife and I were fortunate to stay at a hotel that was located at one end of the Avenida da Liberdade. This provided the perfect location where we could walk and explore this iconic avenue in the heart of Lisbon. A walk up and down the Avenida da Liberdade allowed me to learn quite a bit about Portugal and Lisbon in particular. The numerous statues and monuments pay tribute to historical events from Independence to World War I to historical figures such as Simon Bolivar and the powerful former Prime Minister Sebastião José de Carvalho e Melo.

There is also high end shopping available along this avenue. An abundance of restaurants are within walking distance after visitors have built up an appetite from exploring this avenue in the heart of Lisbon. The avenue has a lovely wide median in the center of the avenue which provides a tree lined walkway which also offers seating along the avenue.

We were blessed with excellent weather which allowed us to spend a great first day enjoying this iconic Lisbon avenue.
reviews/18/title: Great walk to learn about some of Portugal’s history
reviews/19/text: The street is very wide and very nice for walking.  The stores are all for the super rich.  Not my kind of thing.
subcategory_ranking: #54 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Largo Trindade Coelho Bairro Alto, Lisbon 1200-470 Portugal
name: Igreja de Sao Roque
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Lisbon Chiado & Bairro Alto Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Lisbon Essential Walking Tour: History, Stories and Lifestyle
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon Combo: Hop-On Hop-Off Tour with Three Routes Including Tram
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Full day Small Group Tour of Historical Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Private City Tour: Highlights of Lisbon
ranking: #20 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #20 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: A beautiful Church. Something FREE to do on our last day in Lisbon. I'm so glad we did. We read that it survived an Earthquake. Inside it has the most beautiful gold-cladded areas. Every inch of the sections is detailed and magnificent. We didn't take any pictures out of respect. There was no queue.
reviews/1/text: The church was beautiful and the museum was very interesting. It won’t take long…but worth the hour or so for both. Don’t let the facade fool you, the interior of the church is ornate and gorgeous!
reviews/2/text: The church is definitely worth a visit, the opulence is breathtaking. We went to the museum afterwards but you’re not missing out on much if you don’t visit the museum. The Church for me was the main attraction.
reviews/3/text: What a beautiful church! My favorite in Lisboa. The chapels to the side are all breathtaking due to all the details in the walls and ceilings
reviews/4/text: The church of San Rocco was built in 1570 and consists of a nave, a presbytery and eight main side chapels. The eight chapels are very richly decorated and different from each other belonging to different styles since they were built in more recent times (mannerism, baroque and romanesque baroque). One of the few buildings in Lisbon to survive the big earthquake, this relatively small church is truly a jewel and should not be missed by anyone visiting Lisbon
reviews/4/title: This church is truly a jewel
reviews/5/text: Like a rose bud before it blooms, the unassuming façade conceals the brilliant beauty inside this church. This church has one of the most ornate interiors we’ve see yet in Europe and the UK. All the chapels are beautiful and shiny. The ceiling is a work of art. Entry is free and it is a popular stop for the tour guides, so go in at opening hour (9:30) if you want to enjoy this church without big crowds. When you enter, to the left there are some English pamphlets with a bit of history about the church and chapels. Enjoy…
reviews/6/text:
A truly remarkable church; the plain exterior does not prepare you for the fabulously over the top Baroque decoration of the interior - side chapels filled with cherubs, saints and tons (literally!) of gold leaf.
Also display cases filled with hundreds of relics (not my cup of tea, but fascinating).
An absolute must-see.
reviews/7/text: It's shocking that this church isn't at the top of every list about Lisbon. You can spend a solid 2+ hours here, as there is so much to see and photograph. It is far more ornate that the Lisbon Cathedral and there is a good amount of info in English, especially in the museum, which is also worth a visit. It's not nearly as crowded as the other sites in the city. Don't be mistaken by the very plain exterior - this was our favorite spot in Lisbon!
reviews/8/text: This church is really beautiful on the inside but doesn't look that interesting from it's exterior. Inside it has a wonderful altar but it's majestic feature is it's fabulous gold leaf alcoves and giant muralled ceiling. If you're interested in visiting it's adjacent museum, then go between 10 and 2 on a Sunday as it's free to enter.
reviews/9/text: This is my favourite church in the city by a long mile. It's just completely over the top. A baroque extravaganza with heaps of cherubs and saints. There are two huge glass cabinets with displays of the relics of male saints in one and female saints in the other. So that's bits of arms, skulls, etc. Bit gruesome but very typical of Roman Catholic practice three hundred years ago. There's an interesting museum attached and I recommend this place wholeheartedly.
reviews/10/text: We stopped in briefly and enjoyed it; I wouldn't call it a must-see, certainly not by the standards of the country's European neighborhood.
reviews/11/text:
Being on TA page 2 is the first misleading fact about this Jesuit Church.
Second misleading is once there, if not knowing about it you'll probably bypass the more than ordinary facade, paying no attention on it. Don't do that.
The moment you enter you'll open your mouth in disbelief.
Outstanding Church built by Jesuits in the 16c with amazing interior - one of the best we saw on our 7 days Portugal tour.
You simply cannot tell which side Chapel is more beautiful (there're 8 of them), as well the amazing altar. Each is well explained in Portuguese/English. Gorgeous painted wooden ceiling.
Really, a must visit in Lisbon, should be in top 5 attractions.
reviews/11/title: Wooow - how is this Church on TA page 2 ???
reviews/12/text: Absolutely incredible!! Don’t let the outside deceive you. Everything is so incredibly beautiful and detailed.  We happened to go on a Sunday, so we were even able to hear the organ and some choir singers practice. An experience I will never forget!
reviews/13/text: The Church of Saint Roch in Bairro Alto was the earliest Jesuit church in the Portuguese world, and one of the first Jesuit churches anywhere.  It is plain on the outside but lavishly adorned with the riches from the age of discoveries (gold and jewels).  It is famous because it has a bone reportedly from Saint Roch and because it was one of the few buildings to survive the great earthquake of 1775.  It is definitely worth a visit when in Lisbon.
reviews/14/text: Stumbled along this hauntingly scarred church on our first evening strolling around the streets of Lisbon. The ceiling is completely unadorned, with scraggly columns and interior walls, a relic of the calamities it experienced in the past. Interesting to see this kind of memory preserved.
reviews/14/title: stumbled upon this hauntingly scarred church
reviews/15/text:
As part of our hidden gems tour we visited here with its many chapels, which were certainly something to look at.  Not exactly subtly adorned with all manor of gold and cherubs they are certainly an acquired taste.

Worth it for the photos but 10-15 mins is probably enough time.
reviews/16/text: Famous church because of the little chapels that line the walls and because it survived the earthquake and is decorated with the riches from the age of discoveries.  Lots of gilded silver all over the place.
reviews/17/text: An absolutely beautiful church, probably the most impressive I've ever seen. Must-visit attraction in Lisbon.
reviews/18/text: Must see…One of the most beautiful buildings you’ve ever seen..The visit is totally worth it and highly recommended
reviews/19/text: This is a neat church with a wonderful painted wooden ceiling. Like many Jesuit churches, it’s elaborate ornamentation almost overwhelms your senses. Sometimes they are overly gaudy, particularly in its gilding, but here it is just lovely and the quality of workmanship exquisite. It’s the sort of church you do not want to leave, because no mater how closely you look and how long, you know you haven’t seen it all. The trouble is you want to see it all. Eventually it’s time to move on. Saddened, but just glad you had the opportunity to see it at all and if you are one of the lucky ones, like we were, you get to come back and admire it once again. Don’t worry. It’ll be just as magical the second time around.
subcategory_ranking: #20 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Rua Belem, Lisbon Portugal
description: This dramatic statue commemorates the famous 15th-century explorer, Vasco da Gama.
name: Afonso de Albuquerque Square
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Belém and Jerónimos Monastery Guided Small Group Walking Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Belém District and the Salazar Dictatorship Legacy - Private Walking Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Uncover Classic Lisbon: A Self-Guided Audio Tour

ranking: #102 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #102 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Although under construction for improvement when we last visited, a visit a few months earlier showed us the grandeur of this beautiful fountain.
reviews/1/text: Nothing special, to make you stop for more than 10 minutes. An ordinary square, with a lot of greenery that makes it look like a park, with a beautiful monument in the middle. That's it.
reviews/2/text: This garden is now very big but well constructed with the bigger trees on the outskirts. Large monument / statute in her middle that is quite artistic. See photos.
reviews/3/text: Pleasant park to relax under trees, have a walk before or after enjoying bars or restaurants close to the Monastery. My children enjoyes having space for run, do cartwheels and I even tried out some of the gym equipment to burn calories of Pastries of Belem. The statue is interesting but not as impressive as others around the city.
reviews/4/text: Jardim Afonso de Albuquerque is very close to the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos. It's a big garden, with a statue (Afonso de Albuquerque, Governor of Portuguese India). It's a relaxed zone, worth if you're in Belém, but that's it.
reviews/5/text: Superb park in center of Lisbonne, with banchs, statues, trees and flowers, near two museums and restaurants with terraces; near the place to take the tourisme seightseeing bus
reviews/6/text: This is a good place in this area that has good statues to represent specific people and therefore times in the history of the area and if Portugal
reviews/6/title: A Nice place with great statues
reviews/7/text:
For a people place it is not easily accessible. You wouldn’t want to compare it with Luxembourg Gardens, still it is pleasant and visual relief. Reviewers on this site seem confused about who the statue represents as it is not named. Albuquerque, who is better remembered as a City, than a Viceroy to Goa, or DaGama who is under appreciated for his contribution to world history. There is no name plate. Can somebody make an authoritative identification
,
reviews/8/text:
One day during our 4 day stay in Lisbon, we had caught a tram to visit the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos at Belem.  
It was a hot day and after visiting the monastery and exploring much of the Belem neighbourhood and adjacent waterfront area on foot, we were hot and tired.
Fortunately, we eventually found ourselves in the Afonso de Albuquerque Square. This proved to be an ideal spot to take a much needed rest from our hectic tourist activities.
It was very pleasant sitting there on a park bench in the nice, well maintained garden surroundings while enjoying the cool afternoon river breeze and taking in the view of the impressive large commemorative statue. 
If you find yourself in the vicinity and need a quiet place to enjoy a rest then this is an ideal location to do so!
reviews/9/text: A place with a statue of Albuquerque together with a lion. The old minister was famous for his strength and work for Lisbon. The lion made that clear.
reviews/10/text: Square named after the former governor to India for Portugal.  Set in front of the president's palace and featuring a large column statue.
reviews/11/text: Pleasant park with ⛲ and trees providing respite from July sun. Belem involves lot of walking so it is good to have place to sit and relax. In far corner are public toilet free of charge.
reviews/12/text: This is a nice square with a large monumental statue. It's worth walking around if you are in Belem already but it is no way a must visit.
reviews/13/text: We walked through this area which is nice, there are different area some tree lined, fountain, statues etc. There are benches around. This is a nice place to have a nice relaxing walk around. The train station is a short walk away, there is a church opposite, the river and other places to see.
reviews/14/text: This park commemorates the second governor of Portuguese India (Goa etc.), which bronze statue stands on top of the impressive monument in the centre of the park. Interesting is that the site of this park was once a harbor, Across the park is Belem Palace where the Portuguese president resides. In the park you'll find benches and shade trees and many tourists and locals alike. It can get busy here.
reviews/14/title: Nice park in front of the Belem Palace
reviews/15/text: The statue of the Vasco da Gama is impressive. This square is to celebrate the old Portuguese sea explorers.
reviews/16/text: So if it's so great, why is it only considered average? Well, beautiful though it is, it is very crowded on most sunny days, and incredibly difficult to get to. It is bordered on one side by the river, that's where the stunning view is, but the landside of the park is separated from the town are itself by the main railway line and a very busy road. There are two footbridges, half a mile apart, to enable you to cross the railway. So if you have children, or elderley relatives, or pushchairs, or wheelchairs, you will find the going tough. To be honest when you get there it will be almost certainly be very crowded anyway. But if you like a bit of an adventure then why not give it a go?
reviews/16/title: A beautifully laid out garden area with trees, paths, and a stunning view.
reviews/17/text: Maybe i am a bit jaded but yes it's a nice square but the monument is historic but nothing special so if you are going to the Belem Palace to check out the changing of the guard you can go across the road and feel happy with Alfonso's achievements in India.
reviews/18/text: There are a row of parks along the waterfront in Belem. They are great to walk through on your way to see the sights.
reviews/19/text:
What made Alfonso so memorable was his conquest of India.  "Conquest" is so over-rated.

However, looking at the bright-side, his statue is in a beautiful park-like stretch of greenery and who can argue with that?

name: Experience Pilar 7 - Ponte 25 de Abril

ranking_subcategory: #101 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: It's worth visiting the bridge as you can see nice views and learn about construction and engineering. The people were friendly and cooperative
reviews/1/text:
1) Difficult to find: I took the 15E Tram to the correct stop BUT there were then NO SIGNS so I ended up walking the long way around a big block to get to Pier 7.
2) Little to see in the museum.  Yes the anchor block  wires are spectacular but little else to see. 
3) The viewing deck at 215 ft is next to noisy traffic.  One can't see in the direction of the city centre other than through the traffic.  Looking the other way there is a good view but they do not clean the glass so no good for photos.
reviews/2/text: Interesting experience,  firstly you get all the history of the bridge. Then you start moving up the bridge. Until you reach the viewing platform.
reviews/3/text: The Pilar 7 "Bridge Experience" was totally worth the visit! We decided to go because it was included for free with the Lisboa Pass package, and I'm so glad we did! It was educational, but also exciting. Agree with other reviews that this is not for folks who are afraid of heights. But if you can handle heights, this experience offers an incredible view of the city and river. Definitely recommend!
reviews/3/title: If you can handle heights, highly recommend!!
reviews/4/text: It isn't every day you get to go inside a bridge. It's a really well designed and interesting experience. The main experience involves an elevator taking you to road /bridge level and you can step onto a glass floor (freaked me out). Interesting and a fun diversion whilst I walked back from Belem.  (NB: I got in with the Lisbon card and the LX Factory is behind.)
reviews/5/text:
This is not for the faint hearted or if you suffer from vertigo. Interesting walk through the concrete garden around the cable anchor points. Only €6 for an adult entry price.
There is a scale model which gives a list of dates and significant events of the times during the construction stages.
The lift is glass. Made my heart miss a beat and I didn’t manage the glass bottomed viewing platform. Not quite brave enough for that.
Lovely view across Lisbon and the River Tagus. 
The vehicles are unnervingly about 10 feet away going across the bridge by the side of you as well as 143 trains that also use the crossing which is 24 floors up.
reviews/5/title: Terrifying glass viewing platform on Pier 7, Ponte de 25 Abril
reviews/6/text: Not really, if you are open minded and technically interested in the essence of the bridge. It is a good idea and the museum looks like a modern art concrete bunker with almost nothing in it except the cables of the bridge as the main attraction apart from the elevator and the view deck.
reviews/7/text: As I have high interest in bridges and constructions this was ofcourse a must. The information about the bridge is given in a very inventive way; on big metal panels on the ground between the receptionbuilding and the pylon itself so outdoors. Very informative and gives a good insight on the construction. In the pylon itself you can see the anchorcables and how the are connected to the ballast. Also in the elevatorbuilding is a model of the bridge and a timeline on the “birth” of the construction, including some irrelevant info on the first man in space and the introduction of the euro for example which has nothing to do with the bridge. The viewingplatform was a bit dissapointing; there isn’t much to see as one side is blocked of by the road and on the other side isn’t that much to see as the beklemtonen area is to far away for a good overview. But when interested in bridges or construction and you have the time it’s definitely worth a visit.
reviews/7/title: Go for the information about the construction and not the viewpoint
reviews/8/text: I am interested in bridges so definitely wanted to see this! There is information about how the bridge was built and a close up view of the cable anchor points.  However, for the family the viewing platform was the best bit - standing on the cantilevered glass platform with a view in all directions. We walked here from Belém and then taxi back to Lisbon, but City Sightseeing buses stop here. We were the only visitors (Christmas Eve) so had the place to ourselves which was great!
reviews/9/text:
I enjoy heights, bridges and views from high places. I was hoping the viewing platform would be higher up, like at the top of one of the support towers, but the view is from the level of the bridge road. The views were nice as you can see from the included photos, but to be honest I thought Padrão dos Descobrimentos had a better vantage point and was more exhilarating as it did not have protective glass.

It was cool to see though, and free because I had the Lisboa Card still. A little hard to navigate to because of the adjacent highway.
reviews/9/title: Was hoping for more, but enjoyed the visit
reviews/10/text: The view point has a glass floored area and a separate viewing platform. They are next to the bridge and this gives you an interesting view of the bridge. You can also see lots of the river and the other side opposite Lisbon. Great.
reviews/10/title: Excellent view point in an interesting place
reviews/11/text:
We recently visited the bridge using our Lisboa card .The only issue we experienced was trying to get some good instructions on how to get there and we did end up walking the long way round to find it ! . I hope the details below will help anyone in future if they decide to visit .They should be more direct .
Get the number 15 tram from Praça Comércio heading towards Belém .
Get off the tram at Estacao Sto Amaro stop ,this is after you have gone under the bridge . Cross the tram tracks ,you will now be in front of the Carris tram museum .Follow the tram tracks in the direction of Belém for a few hundred yards until you reach a street on your left named Travessa Do Conde Da Ponte .Go down this street .At the bottom of this street you reach a hotel called Vila Gale Opera .Turn left across the front of the hotel ,you should now be on a main road under the bridge .The entrance to the Pilar 7 is on your left .
It is a fascinating place to visit with a good insight into its construction ,the viewing platform has a glass floor that gives great views up and down the river .If you do not want to go on this you can still go up in the lift and see the views from a less scary position .Keep hold of the tickets you are issued as you need to scan them several times on the way round and go through some airport style security scanning of bags etc .There are no cafe facilities but there are toilets and bag lockers .
If you are looking for lunch or a drink ,google LX Factory ,this is a lovely area just around the corner where old printing and cotton mills have been converted into food and retail spaces .This is also really worth a visit especially whilst in the area .
reviews/12/text: The April 25th Bridge - which was built to look like the San Francisco Bay Bridge is best experienced at the Experiencing Pillar 7. It gives you the history of the before during and after the building of the bridge, the structural essentials of the bridge and takes you up an elevator to the top of the bridge.  Quite an experience.  You will get to walk on a clear acrylic floor and go through a number of security checks.  It is included in the Lisboa card.  It is a stop on the hop on and hop off tour buses.  If you don't have a Lisboa card, it costs 6 Euros for adults, 4 Euros for students, (children under 5 are free) Groups of 10 or more are 4 Euros each. The museum is open every day during the summer season (May to September) 10 am to 8 pm and the winter season (October through April) 10 am to 6 pm.
reviews/13/text: I thought that we would just go up and experience a glass bridge. We got more than that. Our guide to the top was a blast of fun. I cannot remember much though because I have a fear of heights and just the thought was scaring the crap out of me. The weather did not help that day. It was pouring and cold and the noise of the passing traffic just intensified my fear. I promised my kids I would do it. Took a few minutes until I walked in with my eyes closed. When I opened them and looked down I was rooted with fear to the spot and could not move. I think my subconscious kept telling me that if I moved the glass would break. Anyway, you get a great view of the bridge as well as it’s workings. Our guide was very informative and we got loads of info from him. I am glad I did it. I just do not know how though.
reviews/13/title: Great way to conquer your fear of heights
reviews/14/text:
This is a nice place to go when you have a Lisboa card. Don’t forget to have your ticket with you all the time until you go to the top since there are several areas where you have to have your ticket scanned. 
The exhibits are astonishing and very informative. When you go up the elevator, a magnificent panoramic view is waiting for you. I am not acrophobic but I was too sacred to stand on the glass to see a better view. The rest if my family was close to the bridge with a wonderful view. I was just happy to see the view in front of me.
reviews/15/text: This is a really well laid out and informative place. Went initially  because it was included within the Lisboa card and it ended up being my favourite of the attractions that were included on this card. Information about the bridge’s history and construction is clear and well laid out. The VR experience is also great, as is the viewing platform which is quite exciting to visit as you are really high up right next to the traffic on the bridge.
reviews/16/text:
While there’s plenty of places to snap great pics of the Bridge and the view, there is only one way to do it like this. Take the time to learn about the Bridge itself or continue on and take the elevator to top. Spectacular views over the city, pics up close of the Bridge and a glass bottomed viewing platform are all at the top. 

Tickets are reasonably priced and include a virtual reality experience. These are also part of the Lisboa Card.
reviews/17/text: On going up this new attraction one first hits you is the noise of the traffic. You have about 10 minutes at the top to marvel at the bridge and look over the panorama of Belem. Fun to stand on the glass floor .
reviews/18/text: We almost accidentally visited Pillar 7 when the yellow bus dropped us there. So glad we went in. Did the tour, which was interesting and offered spectacular views, of the bridge, and the city. Also did the short VR experience, and would recommend that too.
reviews/19/text: One of our last points of interest in Lisbon, wasn't sure what to expect. We went on a Friday at midday, tickets are very affordable, (less than 10 euros), no lines, you'll be able to see the technical aspects of the pier, history, model, and finally take the elevator to the glass observation deck, at the level of the bridge top lanes. Nice view of the Tagus River, Belen tower, Discovery monument. The mirror room was awesome and scary!!!
reviews/19/title: Unusual attraction but worth the trip!
subcategory_ranking: #101 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

name: Estufa Fria
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Best of Lisbon Small-Group Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Full Day Best of Lisbon Private Tour
ranking: #25 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #25 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: This is a beautiful place near Lisbon centre. Heaven for everyone who likes plants. The place is very big and built at different levels so you can observe the whole place from different angles. You have a feeling that you are in Hawaii or Brazil not in Europe.
reviews/1/text: A beautiful botanical place really in the middle of Lisbon. The bio diversity there it’s amazing. They have different kinds of plants every where and all explained. You pay €3,25 to entry but worth every cent.
reviews/1/title: Beautiful botanical garden in the city
reviews/2/text:
This was a brilliant, accidental find in the middle of Lisbon. 
Such good value for money, the gardens inside are breathtaking. A plant lovers’ paradise! 
There are so many levels to explore, and plenty of places to stop and admire the plants.
reviews/3/text:
We were here for a wedding. The venue was lovely and so much to see.
You can get lost in the maze so keep an eye out for the signs.
Wear comfortable flat shoes as there is a lot of walking and the surfaces are not all flat and easy to walk on.
For the wedding there was only 1 disabled toilet on the ground floor. Everyone else had to go up the stairs.
It was lovely to hear peacocks and see lots of birds around in the greenery.
Its a botanical venue - the uk version would be Kew Gardens
reviews/3/title: Lovely Venue to go and see
reviews/4/text: One of the best, if not THE BEST, botanic garden’s you’ll ever see. Saw the amazing roof from Parque EduardoVII and had to investigate further. So glad we did. Amazing, jaw-dropping, outstanding. Should be at the top of everyone’s “to see” list in Lisbon.
reviews/5/text: Small botanic lush tropical garden centrally located off the park. Good afternoon side trip. Inexpensive experience. Recommend at least 30min for viewing. I bet it is very lovely when the plants are in bloom. Very few blooming plants in October.
reviews/5/title: Very lush covered area. Small, weary to see in a short time. Inexpensive.
reviews/6/text: We were looking for something to do and stumbled upon this fantastic botanical garden!! We loved it! You should definitely visit if you are a plant lover!
reviews/6/title: Estufa fria botanical garden PLEASE VISIT
reviews/7/text: This botanical garden was amazing and by far better than the Tropical Botanical gardens in Belem. It had a “cold greenhouse” which is a new experience to us. It was awesome and inspiring and relaxing all at once. We visited late one Sunday afternoon. It contained all your usual houseplants, but growing voraciously outdoors! Tree ferns, maidenhair ferns, monsteras, rubber plants. The paths are windy and uneven but this adds to the experience. A must see if you are visiting Lisbon and like plants!
reviews/7/title: A must see if you are visiting Lisbon and live plants!
reviews/8/text: Before we got to Lisbon we didn’t realise these were here. We walked up through the park and then into the greenhouse area. The plants are wonderful and there are lots of paths round. Entry was only €3.10 and €1.55 for seniors - great value for money!
reviews/9/text: Great park, really a oasis in the city of Lisbon and really amazing plants! I loved the big spaces here and its really cool to go around, also with 4 euro (which you have to take in to cash they dont accept cards) it pretty affordable too!
reviews/10/text: The best botanical garden we’ve visited. A calm sanctuary amongst the hustle and bustle of Lisbon. Would highly recommend.
reviews/11/text: Great place to vist, especially for children. It was a pity that a big part was closed due to a wedding, and other part was under maintaining.
reviews/12/text:
Although called Estufa Fria, this complex actually consists of three greenhouses: Estufa Fria (Cold Greenhouse) - the largest; Estufa Quente (Warm Greenhouse) - medium size; and Estufa Doce (Sweet Greenhouse) - the smallest. The whole complex is covered by a protective, special wood lathing roof, but It’s quite easy to forget that one is actually in a greenhouse. Some of the pathways give the impression of actually being out there ‘in the wild’. 

Probably a good idea to wear shoes with solid tread on the soles, as some of the little pathways, especially in the Warm Greenhouse and Sweet Greenhouse, are carpeted with tiny little pebbles, which could make for a ‘slippery’ experience. 

Good signage. Lots of benches along the pathways. WC in the Cold Greenhouse. Excellent brochure, with a map of the complex, available in both Portuguese and English. Very helpful lady at the ticket office.  Lovely way to spend a few hours!

Hours open
Daily:
10:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. (summer)
09:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. (winter)

Estufa Fria is located in Parque Eduardo VII, so it’s easy to access by either metro or bus. Most visitors will arrive at the bottom of the park, facing the monuments at the top of the hill. There are paved lanes on either side of the large, central ‘maze’ garden.

The pathway to Estufa Fria is off from the left lane, approximately opposite the large Carlos Lopez Pavilion on the right side of the park.
reviews/13/text:
If you like nature, peace and tranquility, this is an unmissable place. 
Absolutely flawless! thousands of well-kept and tidy plants.
A paradise in the middle of the city.
No defects! Congratulations!
reviews/14/text: My boyfriend and I decided to visit this botanic garden after all the positive reviews and we were truly surprised. The entrance was free and there are 3 different greenhouses. Definitely recommended.
reviews/15/text: Estuda fria (Cold Greenhouse) is a beautiful garden worth the visit. It is composed by the bigger cold greenhouse and a "sweet greenhouse" and a "hot greenhouse". Beside the plans you can see a lot of birds, ponds with fish and tortoises. Entrance is cheap but on Sundays mornings is free. Easy to park and to get there by public transport. Good visit for families.
reviews/16/text:
If you like to enjoy the nature and plants, then this is a very lovely place and a must. Different varieties of plants and some chickens to make your day.

Entrance fee is only 3€(1,6 for students) so dont miss it while you are here.
reviews/17/text: Several colleagues and I took a 90 minute detour to Estufa Fria while on a business trip to Lisbon. We enjoyed walking through the indoor gardens, seeing flowers, greens, and many cactuses. Although the experience was nice, I wouldn't rate it as the best of the trip. Make sure you can handle steep inclines and steps. It was cash only to enter (3 Euros each).
reviews/18/text: From the Eduardo park, just take a small detour and visit this place.  If you have the Lisboa Card, you can get in here for free!  Its calm and very relaxing inside, so a nice break from the chaos outside.  If you have a stroller, then this is not the place for you.
reviews/19/text: The tropical gardens are an oasis of calm in the central busy area of Lisbon. Well worth a visit to see these well presented gardens giving a feeling of calm in this otherwise busy area of the city.
subcategory_ranking: #25 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

reviews/0/text: A painting rather than a sculpture. I didn't know about it, and I don't think it can be considered a tourist attraction. I found it by chance, when I was going to the Maritime Museum. Interesting, anyway.
reviews/1/text: Fabulous artwork of Bordalo’s - so close to the Cultural Centre. This is one of my favourite pieces and I’ve seen 7 of his art now..
reviews/2/text: This was just by the museum that we were visiting which was great as otherwise we would have missed it totally - we got a better view from the balcony on the museum than below (see photos) - but unfortunately there were building works going on at the time which partially covered it.
reviews/3/text: This is probably my favorite Bordalo II piece so far. It's 3D but you don't notice it until you're up close. An easy walk from the monastery and basically right next to the Belém Cultural Center.
reviews/4/text: We drove by this artwork and had to stop. It is made of used car parts and other trash.  It is best seen from afar, as you lose the 3D effect the closer you get. There are other such artwork around including the rabbit in Porto. Worth seeing.
reviews/5/text:
Stunning in its realism when seen from a little afar, it's a marvellous creation.

Made by the artist from an assemblage of waste and discarded rubbish and metal, it is well worth taking time out in front of it.
reviews/6/text: Warto zaplanować spacer w dzielnicy Belem tak, aby zobaczyć borsuka na własne oczy. Polecamy nie tylko miłośnikom street-artu i fotografom. Na każdym turyście zrobi wrażenie.
reviews/6/title: Odszukaj na mapie i zobacz osobiście
reviews/7/text: Mais uma bonita escultura feita de lixo,que alerta com estes trabalhos certos perigos para a humanidade.
reviews/8/text: Cette fresque murale est belle de loin, impressionnante de près, au vus des matériaux utilisés, de loin une œuvre comme tant d’autres, et plus vous vous rapprochez et plus les détails s’affinent, pour finir devant un amas de récupération automobile.il faut avoir un esprit très imaginatif, bravos l’artiste la preuve qu’avec pas grand-chose, on peut réaliser de grandes choses.
reviews/9/text: Création faites avec de la récupération de pièces détachées automobiles et divers autres accessoires,  soudée les aux  autres et repeint.
reviews/10/text: É o meu artista plástico preferido da actualidade. Artur Bordalo (Bordallo II) nasceu em Lisboa em 1987 e é neto do pintor Artur Real Bordalo. Com o lixo "produzido" por nós, cria arte desde 2012, que actualmente se encontra espalhada pelo mundo. Os animais são a sua inspiração, alertando para os perigos que actualmente correm. Infelizmente não terá falta de matéria-prima...
reviews/11/text:
Posta in un angolo non molto frequentato ci ha sorpreso per la sua originalità 
Interessante da lontano ma ancora più curiosa  da vicino

address: Largo Jose Mariano Gago N0 1 Parque das Nacoes, Lisbon 1990-073 Portugal
name: Pavilhao do Conhecimento

offer_group/offer_list/1/title: EXPO 98 walking tour with cable car trip
ranking: #18 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #18 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Real science, wonderful place to see science in action. So many things to try and experience. Perfect for families with kids
reviews/1/text:
We had a massive 2 hours of out of this for both our 3-year-old and 8-year-old as well.
They can touch and try everything, sometimes by the help of the staff, but there were plenty of them available.
First room with little science experiments/observations; make a giant bubble, play with putting obstacles in the way of the light, observe a tornado forming, etc.. Definitely more fun for the older ones, but the little was happy just to touch things.
Second room, the biggest fun, the most time spent. Put on a velcro suit and jump on a sticky surface to get stuck, drive a car with square wheels, try the fakir's bed. For the younger ones; climbing wall, lily pad piano, springy ride race and so on.
Downstairs they have an installation about the importance of water and activities about it.
They also have a big robot/ electricity themed room. It is a very hands-on room with tons of longer, more devoted activities, like make flying paper creations, sew a little creature, put together basic circuits. They have a lego robot building section and a field where you can control two bigger pretty serious programable robots.
We went 2 hours before closing (after the aquarium and the cable car which you can easily combine it with), but could have spent some more.
There are plenty of restaurants around and you can get there by metro and a bit of a walk from the center.
reviews/2/text:
We love a science museum and knew we'd come here. It's closed Mondays though so watch out if you're planning your trip..
Kids (8&7) loved it. We bought a family ticket which you can't buy in advance, and it's for all day. We managed to exit and return later which was great. 
It's on 2 floors and lots of things to do. There's a dedicated section to toddlers too. 
We spend 2.5 hours in total over 2 trips in a day. We had lunch and visited the Oceanario in between and kids insisted on returning back - and who can blame them. Love seeing them have a blast
reviews/3/text: We have been there with our 5 year old daughter and she enjoyed it a lot. It is full of things to do and you can easily spend at least half day inside it with a lot of fun!
reviews/4/text:
We had a rainy day so needed options for kids and adults. The reviews are a bit mixed but our group LOVED IT! We had two adults, a 13 year old and a 4 year old and all were entertained completely. 

It’s super hands on and large enough to spend at least 2 hours. Our four year old loved it so much we went back later in the week and she spend ANOTHER four hours here! 

All signs are in multiple languages and the workers also speak multiple languages. People must be masked and they have plenty of sanitizer around so it felt pretty covid safe too. Highly recommended
reviews/4/title: Kids AND adults loved it! A must do on a rainy day
reviews/5/text: This is one of the best Science Museum’s we have been to that is geared towards children, our nine year old loved it!  There are lots of interactive displays and things for the kids to play with.  Don’t miss the chance to draw your own fish and then see it on screen as well as engaging with a robot.  The museum is near the Oriente train station in the Parque das Nações.
reviews/5/title: Wonderful space for children to learn and play
reviews/6/text: I am not sure that we saw all of it as we were entertaining a four year old, however, there is a huge amount to see and enjoy (for kids of all ages). We liked the way that entertainment was fused with learning. The props/exhibits are high quality and interactive, designed to engage even the mildly curious. Try riding the cycle on the high wire (with counter balance below!), or go to the climbing wall, study light refraction, or go to the ground floor to be educated about water and climate. We thought this was a top class facility with much to enjoy and plenty of space to walk around.
reviews/6/title: A brilliant fusion of entertainment and education
reviews/7/text: We had visited a couple of years back, so we knew it is a must to visit. Plenty of educational and entertaining activities for kids. You could easily spend 2-3 hours here. They are taking good precautions for sanitization and limiting the number of people.
reviews/7/title: Definitely a must do for kids
reviews/8/text: We loved this place! Yes, not everything was open in lieu of a combination of CoVid restrictions recently being lifted and/or shifted, and the museum undergoing minor construction in some areas (new exhibits). But we still had a blast!
reviews/8/title: Loved it! We will be back!
reviews/9/text: Great afternoon with my daughter couldn't get her out of there with so many experiences and activities to try.
reviews/9/title: Fantastic for kids of every age
reviews/10/text: Worth taking the subway to this interesting suburb where you will find several museum spaces and the Oceanarium. particularly good for younger kids and teens with an interest in sciences.
reviews/11/text: It’s just a great place to visit specially if you have kids or teens. It’s an interactive museum just like in NY London or Vancouver! Fun for all ages. Prices are ok! The museum is on the Expo area and you can reach out by metro and walk less than 1k. Many options of restaurants in the area and the other places to visit!
reviews/12/text: if you time and you are with your kids spent some time there. Its opposite to the aquarium. There are always some extra exhibitions. The day we visit it there was one about the human body
reviews/13/text: Excellent learning museum for all the family. Even get a chance to cycle on a tightrope! Can easily spend several hours there.
reviews/13/title: Great fun and hands on learning
reviews/14/text: If you visit Lisbon with kids then this is a must visit Museum. Lots of things to learn and play with. Spend 2-3 hours and enjoy it.
reviews/15/text:
Great to combine with the Oceanario next door.

Everything is interactive and fun here. Really lovely place.

Great for kids and adults alike.

Highly recommend.
reviews/16/text:
Arrive early to avoid lines and ride the bike - you’ll get a photo similar from the movie E.T. My daughter was too small for the ride .. so I did it 😀😀😀... twice 😁.
The museum is one of the coolest I’ve seen for children, they have a circus 🎪 themed area, a temporary area now showing a cats & dogs exhibit and a 3rd one holding activities such as sewing, robotics and others. Check the workshops dates for your visit. I’ve missed this piece and nothing was available on the date I’ve chosen.
I’d suggest 3 hrs for the visit, but of course this will depend of how energetic your child is.
reviews/16/title: Ride in the Sky - E.T movie - bike chase scene
reviews/17/text: You will have a great time in this facility.  It is an interesting interactive experience for everyone to learn about many scientific topics under one roof.  Check it out as part of a day trip . It is next to the Oceanarium.  Lots of fun for everyone.
reviews/18/text: The reviews i read didn't do this place enough justice.  My 7 yr old and 3 yr old loved it.  we spent 6 hrs here and could have stayed longer if we weren't hungry and needed to go eat!  there are activities for all age groups... our young one was just as intrigued as our older one.  they've been to museums like this elsewhere and this one offered them new activities and discoveries.  it's great value for money and perfect for a really hot summer day or a rainy winter day as it can keep kids and adults busy for hours!  i had more fun than my son in the DOING section at the end!
reviews/19/text: not easy but alwasy good when you visit a big city like lisbon its have been great big city big movements ya for sure you must want to rapeetgooid good memory''''

name: Miradouro das Portas do Sol

offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon Historic Center Private Tuk Tuk Tour 3h

reviews/0/text:
Come here for the view and drinks if you are in the area but don’t go out of your way to visit. 

Staff was pleasant but service really slow, we waited over 10 minutes to be seated and our drinks took 20min to get and the food almost an hour to be served. 

Food was ok, nothing special. Price you pay is for the location and view, not the service or quality of food. The drinks were really nice and if I go back I’ll skip the food and just go for a drink and enjoy the beautiful view over Alfama. 

I don’t discourage visiting, just be aware that it’s tourist-y with just ok food you could get anywhere else for half price and probably quicker, but anywhere else won’t get you this view.
reviews/0/title: Come for the view, not the food or service
reviews/1/text:
Lovely place to walk around, we tried to get there for sunset.   Not much of sunset but still lovely area. Live music , and someone selling ginjinha.
Several areas to eat and drink, and you can get the Tram here.
reviews/2/text:
This miradouro is just one of many in Lisbon - and not worth a long detour. Two shots - and you’re off.

For your information: Miradouro da Senhora do Monte is probably the best…
reviews/3/text: The Miradouro das Portas do Sol is a beautiful garden with a lookout over the Alfama and Tagus River. Come here any time of the day to enjoy the view. Come in the evenings to also enjoy the sunset and some free music. You can buy a drink at the mini supermarket across the road, at the bar next to the terrace or from the local vendor. Nice relaxed vibe and plenty of seating and space.
reviews/4/text:
This little plaza is the best place for sunset and cocktails. Folks are really social and the kiosk called Quiosque Portas Do Sol offers cocktails, small bites, and seating right on the plaza overlook. The staff there are the best too! 
Note; Avoid the little patio bar to the right called Terazio do Santa Luiza or something like that - the service is the worst. Stick to the overlook and enjoy the music too since local artists stop and play.
reviews/4/title: Happening Social Spot with a Stellar View
reviews/5/text: I saw eight different Mirodouros whilst in Lisbon and this was my second favourite. It allows you spectacular views and photos close up of Alfama along with distant shots of the river.
reviews/6/text: After taking the tram, we stumbled upon this location. I wish we had a chance to come here earlier, it would have been great to be here to catch the sunrise. This location has h views in multiple directions including the beautiful clay roofs straight into the river. There are several other lookouts/restaurants in the area that would be great place to grab some snacks and enjoy the view even longer.
reviews/7/text: This is one of many viewpoints in Alfama. This is one of the nicer ones which overlooks the river as well as the rooftops of the city. Would recommend stopping here while visiting Alfama.
reviews/7/title: One of the nicer viewpoints in Alfama
reviews/8/text:
From Miradouro Portas do Sol you have, let's say limited views. It is in the lower part of Alfama hill. You cannot see the city center as this lookout is oriented to the northeast - towards National Pantheon and St. Vincent de Fora Church and Monastery.
However, we enjoyed the atmosphere as there was a live band playing before sunset.
Opposite the Miradouro is the tram 28 stop to take you further exploring.
reviews/9/text: From this patio decorated with flowers, at a place where instrumentalists mingle with tourists on any given day, you’ll be afforded a quintessential view of Lisbon. Miradouro das Portas do Sol literally translates as “Viewpoint of the gates of the Sun.” In a panorama reminiscent of the famous shots in Santorini, Greece, with those blue domes and white buildings against the sea, you’ll be able to photo Lisbon’s Alfama district with red-roofed buildings stacked on parallel streets right down to the Tagus River. It’s worth the 17-minute uphill walk from the Baixa-Chiado metro station, and we prefer this view to the slightly lower Miradouro de Santa Luzia viewpoint a few streets below.
reviews/10/text: Views of rooftops here, not the best view in Lisboa, but still very good and worth a stop for photos and to get your bearing.  It's a city of hills and views.
reviews/11/text: This viewpoint compared to others lacked atmosphere and character. Views were OK but nothing wonderful.  Lisbon is a city of miradors.  I went twice to this one, but for me it lacked the ambience and 'fun' of the other viewpoints.  Maybe I picked the wrong times!  The haze of the sun was also quite strong here and it was difficult to capture a good photograph.
reviews/12/text:
This lookout is just okay - there are better ones a short walk away.

There are several tables and a cafe, so it’s a nice place to hang out, but the view is limited.

For a better view, head just up the hill to some of the other lookouts, or go over to the castle.
reviews/13/text: This is one of the better spots to get views of the castle and the port over the rooftops. Nice spot for a panoramic photo. Recommended
reviews/14/text:
Large open terrace typically crawling with noisy walking-tour crowds, tuk-tuk groups, and the ubiquitous narcissistic selfie fans. 

I can’t say I was impressed at all with this place. Basically, we all take the same photo of the same view, assuming someone’s selfie stick doesn’t first impale an innocent bystander.

The Miradouro de Santa Luzia just a few meters away actually has a much nicer environment than does the Miradouro das Portas do Sol. Of course, the view there is rather limited as well, but the ambience is considerably nicer than that of the Miradouro das Portas do Sol.

Probably the best viewpoint is the Miradouro da Graça some way up the hill.
reviews/15/text:
We quickly learnt that in Lisbon anything with the word ‘miradouro’ in the name was worth going to. It roughly translates as ‘viewpoint’.
This is the most photographed viewpoint in Lisbon. The large, open terrace is almost like a balcony, looking out across Lisbon. From here you get an expansive view over the red terracotta rooftops of the Alfama, looking down across Lisbon to the water. 
I wish we’d known a little more of what we were looking at while we were there. For future reference:
* the statue in front of the view is St Vincent, patron saint of Lisbon. 
* the large building on the skyline is the monastery of Sao Vicente de Fora. 
* the chalky-white dome is the Pantheon (or the church of Santa Engrácia) 
* the white church in the distance is the Baroque church of Santo Estevão (St Stephen).
Before you leave, don’t-miss the hidden tunnel and Santa Luzia. The tunnel is tucked away below the lookout and is covered in a colourful, fun mural that tells the history of Lisbon in cartoon panels (look for the set of stairs to the right of the statue). 
Santa Luzia is basically next to the lookout and if you go around the back of the church there’s another lookout point. It’s less expansive but gives a different angle however what makes it really special, are the beautiful panels of traditional blue and white azujelos tiles. 
GETTING THERE: It’s very easy to get here and I’d highly recommend catching the famous #28 tram which takes you right to the lookout. It is also an excellent starting point for exploring the St Jorge Castle. From here, we walked about 10-15 minutes uphill, following the brown ‘Castelo de S.Jorge’ signs.
reviews/16/text: Amazing view of the old city. There is a great quiosq nearby, with great sangria! Snacks were also good, specially the chicken chamuças
reviews/17/text: It is also a nice miradouro with the view of Tagus river, the Church of São Vicente of Fora, the National Pantheon and the roofs of houses in this part of the city. You can't see much of the sunset from here though and the late afternoon sun doesn't shine much to it. If you want some sun and sunset, try other miradouros.
reviews/18/text:
If you go to the Miradouro de Santa Luzia overlook, is it worth it to see this overlook also ? Yes, definitely come see it. 

This overlook has a slightly view so it’s worth coming here also. The two overlooks are very close by. It has an outstanding view of Lisbon & the Tigus river.

It’s a must see in Lisbon.

Take an Uber up to the Castle & walk down to these two overlooks. From here you can easily walk downhill through Alfama.

Come early to get good pictures as it gets very crowded.

If you like my review, I hope you'll click the 'helpful' button; those of us who write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more.
reviews/19/text: Enjoy the view sipping a glass of Porto or Muscatel while listening the street artists playing their music. From one side the tram are passing and from the other cruise ships are sleeping on the docks of Tago river. Enchanting and relaxing spot!
reviews/19/title: Street musicians and a glass of Porto

address: Praca Imperio, Lisbon 1400-206 Portugal
description: The world-famous Maritime Museum in Belem has a children’s section as well as ship models. Portugal was a world leader in maritime exploration (Christopher Columbus, Vasco da Gama, etc.)
name: Maritime Museum
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: The Portuguese Colonial Empire
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Lisbon World Heritage Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon World Heritage Deluxe Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Lisbon Private Tuk Tuk Tour - Discovery Tour (2h00)
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Lisbon Private Tuk Tuk Tour - Old Town Tour + Discovery Tour (3h00)
ranking: #59 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #59 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text:
Nice collection of maritime pieces.  The history of Portugal’s maritime was very well done.  
The hall of ships was fascinating with a good collection.
reviews/1/text: The maritime museum is full of displays and information, and our visit was very interesting. We enjoyed the first part of the visit best - we learned a lot about the beginning of the sea adventures and discoveries of Portugal. Highly recommended!
reviews/2/text: We visited this museum as it was at one of the hop on hop off bus stops. It consists mainly of models which are quite interesting and there is English translation for nearly all things. There is a large area full of historical boats which was nice to walk around.
reviews/3/text: We got a late start to visit the Jerónimos Monastery and there was a massive line to get in. Towards the end of the building is the Museu de Marinha with no line and no waiting. This is a gem of a museum! I loved the welcoming statue of Henry the Navigator at the entrance. There were displays of Portuguese ships throughout their history through the modern era. The layout of the museum is very nice. After the main exhibit hall, there is another large room containing royal barges. [Don’t miss the royal jet ski!] One thing I noticed on the description of the naval vessels – they state when the ship was built, where it served…and when it was paid off. I appreciated this level of fiscal information.
reviews/4/text: I have visited a lot of nautical museums, but this one is definitely one of the most famous. Placed in monastery give unique experience, which will bring you to the history of Portuguese navy. I hadn’t a lot of time for visit, but I believe one day I’ll come back
reviews/4/title: One of the most beautiful nautical museums
reviews/5/text:
I have spent my career going to sea so I could not miss this one.

I especially enjoyed leaning about the early Portuguese voyages. The early celestial navigation instruments and other artifacts are fascinating.

There are incredible, large-scale sailing ship models that very detailed. 

And, don't miss the warehouse in the back filled with actual boats.

My wife also really enjoyed this museum.
reviews/6/text:
Very nice museum, especially the first part, regarding the pioneers in world exploration.  
Great models of old ships.
reviews/6/title: Nice morning in the maritime museum
reviews/7/text: Wow! What a fascinating museum for anyone interested in anything nautical. I only had two hours but I could easily have spent all day at this huge museum – perhaps more!
reviews/8/text:
One of the best attractions for us in Lisbon. Fascinating information in the navigation history of Portugal. The building is large and very well presented (although not all exhibits have an English translation). It was easy to access (no long queues) and has items to cover many different interest - ships, aircrafts, history, weapons.
The cafe food was also excellent, some of the best in the area. 
Highly recommend a visit.
reviews/9/text: Combine a visit here with a visit to the Jeronimos Monastery for a delightful morning or afternoon.  The Maritime museum provides an excellent overview of Portugese maritime history.   The Portugal of early modern European history owed much of its wealth, power and prestige to the voyages of exploration (and exploitation) undertaking by a few remarkable generations of seagoing individuals.  This museum tells that story in an interesting and informative way.   The museum is spacious and well laid out.  Real maritime buffs will enjoy the array of retired watercraft in the hanger like annex to the museum proper.
reviews/10/text: V interesting museum - learned loads about Portuguese maritime explorers - maps from 1500s particularly interesting - well worth a couple of hours - nice cafe too
reviews/10/title: Interesting museum with lots of information about Portuguese maritime history
reviews/11/text:
One of the best things for us in Lisbon. We learnt so much from the Portuguese point of view, about Vasco de Gama and Henry the Navigator. We saw some amazing relics and models. Beautifully laid out and lovely cool place to spend a couple of hours.

Highly recommend.
reviews/11/title: Fascinating and comfortable place to learn so much about Lisbon navigation history
reviews/12/text: As somebody who is not usually into war-related museums or boats, it was a very interesting experience. The exhibits were interesting to walk through, and the museum has a lot to offer. My favorite exhibit was seeing the progress of the vessels/war ships of them getting bigger and better over time. They also show the different trade routes that the navigators would use around the world to acquire many spices such as: pepper, ginger, star anise, cardiman seeds, pomegranate seeds, etc. Overall, was a great museum to visit with friends and family and I would definitely go back to revisit it.
reviews/13/text:
English speakers: I highly recommend you read “Conquerers: How Portugal Forged the First Global Empire” by Roger Crowley. You’ll get a much more interesting and nuanced take than what the museum provides.

Here’s what I wrote to the museum after having visited:

To whom it may concern,

I visited your museum recently and would like to give you feedback.

While I loved the digestible nature of the content you provided, I was appalled to see how your curators completely ignored the atrocities committed against Indians during the voyages of de Gama, de Albuquerque, and de Almeida. There's no mention of the Meri, for instance. And there's no mention of the effects of Portugal's colonialism. And the considerable contributions of Jewish intellectuals are also completely omitted.

I was also horrified to see such a laughably short treatment of Portugal's role in the slave trade. I am an American and we have an abominable history of ignoring the effects of the slave trade and our role in perpetuating this horrible insitution. But at least we are making efforts.

Your museum's selective displays are one more example of Europeans' enduring refusal to look at their history honestly. In my mind, Germany is the only country to have courageously taken accountability for their past sins (though they have much work to do regarding their violent colonialist history). What's omitted is reflective of your conviction of your cultural supremacy. While there is much to admire in your collective achievements, your determination to ignore your country's oppression of other peoples, and how you benefited from that oppression, is depressing and beneath you.

Europeans constantly assert that they value the pursuit of knowledge, but it's hard to believe they truly do when I see such intentional erasure. Take some responsibility, for god's sake.

As a museum you have a sacred duty to share the good and the bad of your people's history. You do a disservice to your citizens, to tourists, and to humanity at large by hiding your country's sins. Again, as an American, I know that we are guilty of the same. We need to do better, and you need to do better.
reviews/14/text: Agree with other reviews that this museum offers a unique collection of historical and technological evidence which explains the great seafaring Portugese achievements. Round off your visit with a delious meal at the adjacent cafeteria and museum shop.
reviews/15/text:
My wife took me here because she knows I love ships. I play both older  sail battleships and the more modern motor battleships. Tons of historical ships and I spent a lot of time reading everything, the wife on the other hand, haha not so much into ships but she was happy to see me enjoying it here.

Definitely would recommend here for those who love ships.
reviews/15/title: Big Kid toy for ship lovers
reviews/16/text: Very nice experience if you’re passionate about history and marine, boats, it’s just great. Very big exhibition, a lot of interesting information and the location is great also, inside the monastery.
reviews/17/text: If you're into maritime history, check out this museum! The museum takes a visitor through Portugal's seafaring history. There are original artifacts as well as models of the sailing vessels used to discover new lands. An entire wing houses original restored vessels - some elaborate and some simple. Plan about 1 hour to see most of it. There's a nice cafe and gift shop if you want to take a break.
reviews/17/title: Excellent exhibit of the maritime history of Portugal
reviews/18/text:
Next to the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos, this museum gives you a glimpse into the history of Portuguese seafaring. The first part has a fairly modern exposition. The other rooms are mainly scale models and the largest room is filled with large-scale ships.
There are lockers available.
reviews/19/text:
This museum is interesting and has a lot of potential, however one leaves a bit frustrated!  
Truly,  Portugal deserves a better marine museum,  given the importance of 15th and 16th century Portuguese explorers, and the fact that this tiny and resilient country turned to the sea and became so influential  in establishing trade routes!
There is not much about their discovery of Newfouland, nor about codfishing, so important to the country's survival ( the small Bacalhau museum on Commercio square is way more interesting on that subject). 
The first rooms are well articulated and, yes, there are a few interesting antique maps here and there, but it is a shame that a whole room was not devoted to Portuguese cartography which played such a crucial role in Portugal expansion!
Don't get me wrong, this museum is worth visiting, but definitely needs improvement and focus.
subcategory_ranking: #59 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Praca de Italia 1400, Lisbon Portugal
name: Capela de Sao Jeronimo
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Lisbon Hop-On Hop-Off Tour: 48-Hour in Belém & Modern Lisbon

ranking: #234 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #234 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: You come to Belem to see the monastery here, especially the cloister with its elaborate gothic work.  It is unique and large.  The church you can visit for free but this monastery requires a ticket which includes the museum. This place is very popular and all the tour buses are here.  If you come don’t forget the coach musuem nearby which is definately worth a visit.  Lastly walk to the water which boasts both the Tower and the Monument of Discovery, both walkable and close by.
reviews/0/title: Large Complex within Walking Distance of many other attractions.
reviews/1/text: Beautiful church that has been very well preserved. Beautiful gardens out the front. Does get very busy but the crowds didn’t seem to be too much of a concern. Getting into the church is free, but to tour the rest of the building requires tickets
reviews/2/text: This Monastery was commissioned in 1501. It definitely lavish and worth a look. The tomb of Vasco da Gama is here too
reviews/3/text:
I think we saw this lovely Chapel at the perfect time of day, as the sunlight began to fade, illuminating it with a warm evening glow.

Formerly known as Ermida do Restelo, it dates from around 1514. Although simpler in style and embellishment than the famous Monastery downhill, it makes for a serene and tranquil scene.

Four fine pinnacles reach for the sky; these plus the corner gargoyles and the grand entrance way are just about the sole ornateness, which is quite pleasing.

Tremendous vistas are to be savoured from the high point, cityscapes and to the majestic Tagus.
reviews/3/title: Wonderfully placed on a hill overlooking the city
reviews/4/text: This cathedral is a work of art, both inside and out.  The facade is so intricate that you can easily admire it for 10 minutes.  The inside is grand, huge columns, beautiful windows, and such an air of history.  Separately visit the inner cloister for more great photo opportunities.  And last but not least, head down the block for a pasteis de nata and Pasteis de Belem.
reviews/5/text: We spent over half a day looking around this magnificent Monastry and church,it was Breathtaking and so Beautiful. Very clean and well Preserved..
reviews/6/text: La vista che si gode da questa altura del Restelo è "deslumbrante"! L'Oceano sul quale viaggiavano le caravelle dei navigatori portoghesi che andavano a conquistare nel sedicesimo secolo il mondo. Qui, in questo eremo manuelino, venivano benedetti prima della partenza, un rito che l'interno ricorda e che replica, in piccolo, lo splendore architettonico del più famoso Mosteiro dos Jeronimo, lì sotto, a pochi chilometri. La discesa verso la Torre di Belem è un tuffo nella bellezza assoluta lasciando alle spalle il monumento a Nuno il Contestabile. Una visita che fa ancora più grande questa meravigliosa città
reviews/7/text: Fomos ao mosteiro dos jeronimos e depois fomos a Capela. Imperdível! Para mim é a visita mais bonita da visita. Linda demais! Enorme
reviews/8/text: Belissíma Igreja na entrada do Mosteiro dos Jerónimos e que é de livre visitação sem pagar ingresso e já é uma demonstração da grandiosidade sacra que encontaremos ao visitar o Mosteiro propriamente dito.
reviews/8/title: Retornando à cidade de Lisboa capital de Portugal e apresentando-a aos amigos de viagem.
reviews/9/text: Personalmente è una delle chiese più belle mai viste con le sue colonne imponenti,la tomba di Vasco da Gama e tanto altro.
reviews/10/text: Después de visitar su magnífico claustro me decepcionó la iglesia.  Esperaba un templo impactante digno de una de las épocas de esplendor de Portugal (y con mayor razón por ser panteón real de la dinastía de los Avis) pero me encontré con una iglesia tremendamente oscura, sucia e inclusive mal iluminada (o mejor dicho sin casi iluminación artificial del S XXI que podría resaltar sus virtudes).  En conclusión todo aquello en vez de engrandecer el templo lo empeora muchísimo.  Como es anejo a la visita del claustro tampoco se pierde nada por dedicarlo cinco minutos.
reviews/11/text: Capela muito bonita, com uma arquitectura bonita, diria até um pouco invulgar,inserida num espaço com bancos para se puder relaxar.A vista para o Tejo vale a pena.
reviews/12/text: Après avoir attendu presque 1h, nous avons pu visiter ce monastère mais déçu par le peu de pièces à visiter surtout pour 10€ par adulte, par contre l'architecture du site est d'une finesse remarquable, on a déjà une petite idée vu de l'extérieure et de l'église que l'on peut visiter gratuitement par un accès particulier.
reviews/13/text: Na verdade como tutista temos curiosidade em visitar varios locais, mas a visita a este local e um pessimo custo beneficio. Pois a grande parte fo monsteiro nao se tem acesso. A parte que tem acesso e apenas um jardim sem maiores cuidados. sem guia ou qualquer explicacao ao local. Entao pagar 10 euros, enfrentar filas, os funcionarios sao indelicados. A parte mais bonita e que vale a pena ver, seria a capela que e gratuita, ou seja pra acessar so a capela nao precisa pagar nada. So paga se quiser entrar no mosteiro(que so tem paredes e um jardim msl cuidado). A vista mais bonita mesmo e a vista de fora. Isso engana os turistas porque quando ver a belissima vista de fora, ficam logo interessados em entrar, pois esperam mais coisas dentro.Pura ilusao, pois dentro nao tem nada demais. Na capela , gratuita, e que  e mais interessante
reviews/14/text: Le plus beau monument de Lisbonne à mes yeux. Un site à visiter absolument tant par son architecture que par son histoire. À ne pas manquer!
reviews/15/text: 벨렘탑에서 30분정도 한참 걸어서 올라가야 만날 수 있는 곳입니다. 벨렘지구 전체 조망을 탁 트인 곳에서 볼수 있어서 좋았습니다.
reviews/16/text: Vous entrez à droite , c'est gratuit et là vous êtes éblouis par tant de beauté. Pour 10 Euros vous pouvez pénétrer dans le cloître qui est des plus beaux au monde . Vous pouvez prendre un billet Fort de Belem et la Capela c'est groupe et c'est moins cher. les deux sont proches environ500 mètres à faire à pied.
reviews/17/text:
Junto ao Monasterio de São Jeronimo, de linda arquitetura.
Muito bonita de se apreciar pela bela obra arquitetônica e de arte também.
reviews/18/text: Обязательно посетите эту часовню, особенно если Вы любите готику - это воистину прекрасное творение рук человеческих.
