address: Largo de Santo Antonio da Se, Lisbon 1100-401 Portugal
address_obj/street1: Largo de Santo Antonio da Se
name: Church of St. Anthony
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Lisbon Full-Day Small Group City Tour with River Crossing by Ferry
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: 2 Hr City Tuk Tuk Tour of Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: 1 Hr City Tuk Tuk / Electric Car Tour of Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: 3 Hr City Tuk Tuk Tour of Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Lisbon Historical Vintage Tour: Typical Lisbon
ranking: #56 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #56 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: We were here on Palm Sunday and there was a modest mass going on.  No special decorations for the holiday.  The church was rebuilt after the 1755 earthquake so is of that era.  Lots of light because of the high windows.
reviews/1/text: Beautiful church built over the birthplace of St. Anthony. There is a lovely subterranean chapel built over the alleged birthplace that worshippers can spend contemplative time in front of. If you're looking for a perfect gift for the St. Anthony fan in your life then the church shop has a lovely array of rosaries and memorabilia all of which can be blessed by the priest.
reviews/2/text:
This patron Saint has a special significance in our family, as we were married and both our kids baptized in his Church in our hometown Belgrade, Serbia.
Therefore, every time I'm in Lisbon (and this was my third time) I pay my respects here visiting this beautiful Baroque Church. 
Lisbon's San Antonio is set at the foot of Alfama oldest part of town, just steps before the oldest Se Cathedral.
It's a classic Baroque 18c Church (rebuilt after the 1755 earthquake, the original dates back to 15c) on the place where St. Anthony was born in 1195, marked with the crypt beneath the Church ground level. Beside is a plaque of Pope John Paul II visit.
reviews/3/text:
Dedicated to Saint Anthony of Lisbon. According to tradition, the church was built on the site where the saint was born, in 1195. 

Admission free.
reviews/4/text: Have been there by cruise ship, it is amazing church and good enveronment, want to visit again next cruise itinery may be in this year to look more detail.
reviews/5/text: If your in the area, pop in.  Right near the Lisbon Cathedral.  Be sure to go to the crypt.  Don't make a special trip.  Nice but not a must.
reviews/6/text: I only went in as I was having breakfast nearby.  Not a highlight but worth a stop if you are in the area.  Go to the crypt downstairs as well.
reviews/7/text:
Not a huge church, but beautiful and solemn inside. I say it is a church pilgrims visit during their tour. There is a story that says, if you pray to St Anthony and he helps grant your petitions, you have to come back and thank him. This is especially true for people who are seeking the love of their life. Such a beautiful story☺️💙
The church also has a small gift store inside.
reviews/8/text: Right by the cathedral. Not nearly as small as it looks from the outside. Fairly attractive and tasteful inside. I’d even say it has a peaceful, serence atmosphere. I like it. You could spend 10, maybe 15 minutes here, before you run to the cathedral.
reviews/9/text: Although he is best known as Saint Anthony of Padua, this beloved Portugal saint was born in Lisbon in 1195. A small underground chapel in the Church of Saint Anthony marks the spot of his birth. Saint Anthony is revered as a matchmaker, protector of young brides, and patron of the lost and found. Our guide told us that Mass marriages known as "St. Anthony's Weddings" are held here during the June St. Anthony's Day celebrations. The Church is located across the street from the Cathedral where the saint was baptized. Tradition says you will find a better partner if you can land a coin in the book St. Anthony is holding (statue located outside in front of the St. Anthony church). No, we didn’t try, probably best not to do when you are with your current significant other. Free entry.
reviews/10/text: A real gem of a church with a long history as the birthplace of saint Anthony, Elaborately decorated with wood carvings gilded in gold everywhere. The ceiling frescos are well executed. The church is small but covered in expensive decoration and well worth the visit. The admission fee is small but as with most sights in Portugal it need interpretation which is sadly missing. Ticket desk were unhelpful and i was chaperoned whilst inside the church, closed at lunch time.
reviews/11/text: Just 50 metres down the hill from the cathedral hardly noticeable was Igreja de Santo Antonio de Lisboa so we popped in while passing. Free to enter this pretty church just had a quiet serene feeling about it, a nice place to spend a few cool contemplative moments
reviews/12/text: Near Se in Lisbon is the Igreja de Santo Antonio, built exactly at the birthplace of the saint. The church was built in 1767 according to the design of the architect Mateus Vicente de Oliveira. Inside, paintings by Pedro Alexandrino and sculptures, in particular the wooden image of St. Anthony on the main altar. In the sacristy, the polychrome azulejos coating of Real Fabrica do Rato from the beginning of the 19th century is distinguished. In the basement of the church there is a crypt marking the birthplace of the saint.  It is one of the most important monuments of the city, both for visitors and for Lisboners.
reviews/13/text: The church was built on the site of the house where St Anthony was born (1195) and spent spent his childhood.  It's a small church and is literally a stone's throw down the hill from Lisbon Cathedral. (Sé de Lisboa).   St Anthony's Day is a public holiday in Lisbon and he is one of 2 saints of the city.  The other being St. Vincent.  When I visited the church there was a service being conducted so I took a quick photo of the interior and left without exploring it.
reviews/14/text: This old church was really wonderful.  The alter was amazing and it is pretty well maintained.  It doesn't take long to look at.  And I really ejoy the old churches of Europe.
reviews/15/text: Just below the cathedral, this church is free to enter. It is quite beautiful inside and much bigger than it looks from the outside.
reviews/16/text: The Santo António Church is a religious building.It is one of the main monuments in Lagos, and is known for its interior richness in tile panels and gilt carving.Attached to the church building is the Lagos Municipal Museum.This Church rises over the place where St. Anthony was born, before he left the world as a preacher, eventually dying in Padua. The current temple was built into the year 1767 on the site where a chapel has existed since the 15th  century. It offers elements as the image of the patron saint, spared by the earthquake, the crypt with his birthplace and the canvas representing Saint Anthony with the most authentic features that are preserved. It was visited by Pope St. John Paul II in the year 1982.
reviews/17/text: Absolutely beautiful and quaint little church and birthplace of Saint Anthony.  Also has a crypt you can see as well.  Free entry
reviews/18/text: I have visited many churches around the world and this was definitely one of the most beautiful I have ever seen.  We visited in December, when it had a lovely Christmas atmosphere and the choir was simply enchanting.  We also went to the Museum next door and heard beautiful Fado music one night, with excellent acoustics and in the perfect setting.  All this was free to the public, although they obviously like donations but if you are in Alfama, put this on your 'to do' list, ahead of the Cathedral nearby, which has cashiers lined up on either side as you enter.
reviews/19/text: Passed this while walking as our mother had great devotion to St Anthony went to light a candle, we did not realise he was born there & got to see the crypt it was lovely inside and we got those candles lit,we enjoyed seeing inside..

ranking_subcategory: #40 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Beautiful church in the city center. It looks like in ruins but at the same time in perfect condition. Lot of visitors around
reviews/1/text:
Immediately upon entering this church, visitors will be entranced with the orange/coral ceiling, so unusual for a church. Perhaps it was to hide damage done by a fire in 1959, damage which could, however, be observed on the grey battered looking columns against the walls. The interior is simplistic with the main nave drawing the eye to the main altar, gilded with gold. The high clerestory windows were the only windows that allowed in light - typical of a basilica church architectural style.  The exterior of the church is plain and flush with other buildings on each side. Just look for the cross at the top of the building. The church is located behind the Theater, quite close to other attractions in the area and is easily found.  We popped in for a quick photo. There is no admission charge. 

Outside on the square in front of the church, don’t miss the unusual shaped monument to Jews massacred on the square in 1506. That public square was also the place for burning people at the stake by the Inquisition who had offices around this church.
reviews/1/title: Unusual vivid ceiling color the drawing point for me
reviews/2/text: I was amazed by this church built in 1241. At first it felt like entering a cave -- some of the the stone walls were left blackened by the 1959 fire. The church experienced two earthquakes (1531 and 1755) but has been beautifully restored in most parts of it. It's a National Monument.
reviews/3/text: Church was nearly destroyed by fire in 1959, see the information board at the entrance, you can see the result of the damage along the walls, to my mind it is as beautiful a church as you will find in the city.
reviews/3/title: Fire in the House of God
reviews/4/text: At first glance this church doesn't look that great from the outside, but once within it's an entirely different matter. It's greatest features are it's arches and pillars that adorn either side of the aisle and on it's altar. They look like they've been flown in from Athens with their old style rugged and rustic look and seem as though they've been carved out of the rock. The altar is equally as splendent and this is one not to be missed!
reviews/5/text: Entry was denied because I was wearing a top that exposed my shoulders. The man with the glasses who denied me, let other older Portuguese women in wearing similar clothing. Policy should be removed. Avoid if you have shoulders.
reviews/6/text: Don’t miss this one. It is beautiful. We have seen a lot of ornate churches on our trip but I think the simple beauty of this one makes it one of my favorites.
reviews/7/text:
Do not expect lavish decorations, gilded sculptures, marble carvings, painted ceiling, stained glass, Azulejos....and other Church decorations you're used to see in Portuguese Churches.
Contrary to that, you'll see eerie interiors with damaged stone columns, partly with black leftovers from fire and the ceiling painted in orange. 
But, in these features is the beauty of this very unusual Church in Portugal capital.
Once the place of royal weddings from 13c onwards, this Roman Catholic Church was severely damaged, but survived earthquakes and fires.
Don't miss this different kind beauty as it's very easy accessible - in the very center, steps away from the Rossio square.
reviews/8/text: Just outside of bustling Plaza Rossio is this intriguing Lisbon church with an ordinary, unremarkable exterior but a dark and mysterious interior. While the cathedral isn’t among the most striking in Europe, you’ll notice the stunningly cavernous cathedral with towering pillars. It looks ancient, and in fact the foundation of Igreja de São Domingos dates to 1241. However, most of what you see was built by 1807 after the cathedral was leveled by the 7.7-magnitude earthquake of 1755. The ceiling is unremarkable, but the interior is certainly unique among the Portuguese churches.
reviews/9/text:
The dim interior is painted a haunting orange, with ruined sections of old fire damaged church jutting out from the walls. 
Hidden in the small alcoves are gruesome & disturbing depictions of Jesus’ death & decaying body.

The massive stone pillars are scorched from the fire (1959) that ravaged the church & there is still a lingering smell of burning in the air. 

Admission free.
reviews/10/text: Right in the center of Lisbon, this used to be a place for royal weddings.  Having survived two earthquakes and a one major fire, I suppose this 1240’s built church was built well.  The restoration after the 1959 fire left behind a lot of the signs of the fire and that is just one of it’s charms.  Made extensively with rose marble on the inside, this church is a lot more somber feeling than many others but if you look closely, still a lot of very ornate details.  It is very beautiful but in a very different way that most the the ostentatious counterparts across the country and Europe.  A quick stop here for a few minutes to check out this stalwart of the neighborhood would be a good option.
reviews/10/title: Untraditionally beautiful church in the center of Lisbon
reviews/11/text: The church is extraordinary and very interesting. You can see the impact of earthquake on this church and it has amazing atmosphere. I liked it very much, the best church in Lisbon to visit. Entrance is free.
reviews/12/text:
I’ve been trying to figure out why I like St. Dominic’s Church so much. It doesn’t seem to follow the same pattern of decorative perfection that most other churches in the city do.

There’s something about St. Dominic’s that conjures up in my mind two images. One image, of a young girl - blessed with all the innocence and beauty of youth. The other, of a very old woman - now devoid of youthful beauty, but blessed with all the wisdom of age.  Each is beautiful in her own way. 

Youth is like a blank canvas, with the lines of life yet to be etched on it. On the other hand, age is like the canvas that has recorded all the scars that come with the passage of time and a life lived.

To me, St. Dominic’s is like the old woman: beautiful, but not in the conventional sense.

And, with that, I hope St. Dominic will forgive me for not using a male in my analogy. :-)
reviews/13/text: Excellent interior. Many of the pillars looked to have suffered previous damage from earthquakes etc and have not been restored. This only served to enhance the overall appearance which just seems so authentically affected by time
reviews/14/text: The Church of Sao Domingos is situated Between Rossio and Praca da Figueira, It is  one of the most beautiful churches in the city. It was built in the 13th century by order of King D. Sancho II, but the work, repairs, earthquake and fires completely changed the original medieval structure. Partially rebuilt after the fire ,  the ceiling was erected, the walls were not renovated.  There are still blackened areas. It is simple, but at the same time impresses with its huge stone columns. A wonderful church that you should see while in Lisbon.
reviews/14/title: The church makes an amazing impression
reviews/15/text: I visited this church on a walking tour so my first time going inside was a surprise to me. The interior, although clearly fire damaged is incredibly striking and successful both as an example of restoration but also triumph over adversity.
reviews/16/text: This wonderful church which is free to enter sits at one end of Rossio Square and dates from the thirteenth century, having survived two earthquakes and fires. The scars of both are still visible which makes the church quite unique in that sense.
reviews/16/title: Survivor from two earthquakes with scars still visible
reviews/17/text:
Wowowwowo

The church was destroyed by earthquake and fire.  Inside you can see the damage and it has so much soul and character. I felt it was a lost building from the bottom of the ocean. Atlantis like. 

You must go and it. It is also free.
reviews/18/text: A lot of bad things have happened to this church.  A massacre during the plague, a earthquake, and then a big fire.  You can still see the scars of the fire on the walls and that makes this church eeire and unique.  I fould it to be very cool.
reviews/19/text: At one end of Rossio square. Free to enter. This was a major Lisbon church used by royalty. After the earthquake it was made smaller. In 1959 it was destroyed by fire and then rebuilt. When you enter you get the sense of the fire and also of the history of the building
subcategory_ranking: #40 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Estrada de Benfica 158-160, Lisbon 1549-004 Portugal
animal_welfare_tag/msg_body: Click below for expert advice on animal welfare in tourism.
description: LISBON ZOO – GO AROUND THE WORLD IN JUST ONE DAY At Lisbon Zoo, we invite you to travel around the world without leaving Lisbon. Find the Sumatran Tigers in the dense vegetation of the Rainforest, observe Lions, Giraffes and Elephants behaviour at the dry African Savannah and dazzle with the majestic flight of the colourful birds of South America. Our mission is to develop and promote a zoological and botanical park, as a centre of conservation, reproduction and reintroduction of endangered species, through scientific investigation and environmental enrichment programs. Along with education is a strong entertainment component that will ensure a great family time, always with the conviction that when visiting Lisbon Zoo you’re contributing to this great project of conservations of endangered species and their habitats.
name: Jardim Zoologico

ranking: #75 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #75 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text:
A really nice zoo. Spent a good 3 hours or so here. There’s a little bit of renovation taking place but there were still a lot of animals to see. 

Loved the Sumatran monkey he was great and the bears 🐻 

Easy to get to from the metro from the city. 👍🏼
reviews/1/text: Small enclosures, animals do not look in good condition, posters outside showed animals they did not have. Lots of enclosures were closed off or empty. And paid 27.50€ each for what was  distressing visit. ☹️☹️☹️☹️
reviews/2/text:
I like to go to zoo whenever visiting a country for the first time, as I can observe the local people or families apart from the animals. This is my first time visiting Portugal and this zoo is on my wish list. 

The zoo is not far from a metro station so quite easily accessible. I was first very impressed by the elegant and beautiful peacocks freely wandered inside the zoo. I rarely see peacocks in my hometown or any other countries actually. 

The zoo is spacious and has quite a variety of animals. I spent less than two hours here. The amenities are not new but the zoo does satisfy me. 

Overall, worth a visit for animal lovers.
reviews/3/text: Great zoo, not too crowded.  In my opinion the zoo was better than the aquarium.  The dolphin show better than Sea World and the ape temple was great.
reviews/4/text:
My daughter and I absolutely loved our visit here. So many animals to see, lots of beautiful photo opportunities.  We were very blessed with warm weather when we went on the 11th January, this added to our enjoyment. Lots of animals basking in the sun so made taking photos easier! The signage coupled with the map handed out on entry made finding everything really easy. It's an incredibly large zoo and even though there were lots of people we were never in a crowd, seeing everything was as if we were the only ones there. I can imagine in the height of summer, it would be a very different story. 

We enjoyed reading all the info on all the enclosures and how vulnerable a lot of the species are. Makes you realise just how precious they are. 

We arrived just after opening at 10am and made sure we visited the dolphin show at 11. It was magnificent. The keepers clearly love the animals and you can see the bond between them. 

We stayed until about 2pm then left to have lunch before leaving the zoo. We had a great time.
reviews/5/text: I love zoos, and this one didn't disappoint! It was kind of chilly the day we went but we still saw most of the inhabitants. We took the sky ride - kind of like riding in a Roman chariot in the air. They are very concerned about animal preservation to prevent extinction, and the exhibits are very well laid out. A very delightful morning excursion!
reviews/6/text:
I don’t recommand to go there at all!!!!! 
Animals looked so sad, they didn’t have proper habitats for the species (ex. 3 bear in a small cage, dolphins in a smaller pool than in a resort) the water looked so dirty. It looked more like a prison than a place that is supposed to protect them, the smell indicate they also don’t clean the cages often. 
I’ve visited other zoo before, but i never seen something so heartbraking… :(
reviews/6/title: Do not go!!!! Looks more like a prison instead a zoo
reviews/7/text:
Was so excited to return twenty years later.
Loved it! The place is well taken care of. The sites were clean and neat. The whole surrounding area was restored and is part of the city's daily life.
Money well spent. Most lovely afternoon with my family!
reviews/8/text: We visited here with our 1 year old daughter on a trip to Lisbon. This zoo was horrific- small animal enclosures, dirty, eerily empty and unkept. We were saddened to see the small enclosures, the animals had no stimulation and looked sad and unhappy, and it felt like a completely immoral place. You can tell by how quiet it is that this was really going downhill, perhaps popular 30 years ago, it’s never been updated since and felt like we were in a time warp. We spent an hour walking round and then left, annoyed we had contributed €60 to this cruel place. The monkey indoor enclosure was just horrific, the bears were so sad, so upsetting. The enclosures were dirty and very unkept.  Do not visit.
reviews/9/text: We loved our time spent at this zoo! It was wonderful, you can feel how much the staff care for the animals. The location is beautiful with restaurants and outdoor space for your little ones to enjoy
reviews/10/text:
Definitely worth a visit, very easy to get to via public transport. 

Great day out, we love a zoo visit when we travel to different countries. Lisbon zoo has got to be up there with the best we’ve visited.
reviews/11/text: This is one of the best Zoos I’ve ever visited. Close to the metro and hop on tour bus stop, it is easily reachable. The zoo was just brilliant. The animals had wonderful space, and there were plenty of refreshment stops around the park. We were there for a good 3-4 hours and had the most wonderful afternoon. All photos taken by me!
reviews/11/title: A must visit if in Lisbon!
reviews/12/text: Great show with the dolphins. The crowd really gets into it. Take a trip on the air tram for a birds eye view of the park.  Kids will enjoy this and is a good activity for anyone
reviews/13/text: Had a nice day out at the zoo. Lots of trees for shade, animals seemed happy, not crowded and was also great to jump on the cable car for overhead views.
reviews/14/text: Lisboa is under a heat wave, so we decided to take the kids to the Lisbon zoo. The grounds are really beautiful--lush and with a lovely tree canopy. The grounds were well-taken care of and had many interesting paths to follow. There were a diversity of animals at the zoo too. By far the most impressive part was the dolphin show. We have been to many a zoo in the past (including most recently the Atlanta zoo) and this show was really, really impressive. I can not speak of it higher.
reviews/14/title: Outstanding zoo day--even in 100 degree heat
reviews/15/text: Great time. Good fun for kids (1 & 2 year old). Many interesting animals. Air carousel is great to explore the zoo quicker and see animals that are not visible from ground (the ones that live or rest in trees or high platforms)
reviews/16/text: There was so very little to see. It was quite relaxing and there where nice walking trails, but very few flowers. Would not pay to Uber up.
reviews/17/text: Overpriced decadent space. Needs a refresh. The animals look unhealthy and depressed. Another tourist trap.
reviews/18/text: Unexpected great experience :) I did not wait too much from Zoo as did not see to much reviews about Lisbon zoo earlier. ButIt was great experience. Very nice place, animals in good conditions. Special from Lisbon Zoo: cable cabin gives you opportunity “fly over” animal places and see them from up to down. Easy access by metro. No family tickets.
reviews/18/title: Zoo in city, Lot of animals, all in good conditions
reviews/19/text: We arrived first thing in the morning when they had just opened & the place was pretty dirty - grounds, bathrooms, etc.  However, the worse of it was most of the animal enclosures - especially the larger animal.  There were NO enrichment toys or structures - the bears looked like they wanted to be put out of their misery. It was So Horribly Sad.
subcategory_ranking: #75 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
tags/animal_welfare_tag/msg_body: Click below for expert advice on animal welfare in tourism.

address: Praca Dom Pedro IV, Lisbon 1100-026 Portugal
description: Located in the heart of Lisbon, this vibrant and colorful city square is bursting with flower vendors, shoppers and people bustling to and from their jobs.
name: Rossio Square
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Best of Lisbon Guided Walking Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Lisbon Small-Group Portuguese Food and Wine Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: 90min Amphibious Sightseeing Tour in Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Experience Lisbon in style with our electric talking car
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Small group Lisbon Roots, Food & Culture Walking Tour - With tastings
ranking: #60 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #60 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: A beautiful city with very individual sites.  Apart from the famous bakery cakes, the tiling on the floor of the squares, footpaths, roads, and buildings is certainly remarkable
reviews/1/text:
Rossio square or also called as Praca Dom
Pedro IV, is a very central plaza with beautiful fountains. Here you can take a subway or train (in a very close distance) as well as taxi, bus and tuk tuk. Close by, you can find exchange offices, restaurants, cafes, shops and hotels.
reviews/2/text:
My hotel is just next to Rossio Square so I had the advantage of visiting each day and took pictures day and night with my selfie stick. A beautiful square, not very large, but with quite a lot of visitors (groups or individuals). Felt safe and no weird guys like other cities of other European countries. 

The ground is beautifully designed, same as what I saw in Macau of China (ever a Portuguese colony).
reviews/2/title: I Visited Nearly Every Day and Took Pictures Day and Night Here
reviews/3/text: This square was near our hotel and we parked our car in the parking structure underneath so we went through it a couple times.  I don't know if they have the little market year round but when we were there in Aprils 2022, they had some great little food & gift shops.  We had lunch here one day and it was pretty reasonably priced!
reviews/4/text: We visit this place during Christmas holiday. We could feel the Christmas vibes here. There was a big Christmas tree and this place was lit by Christmas lights.
reviews/5/text: One of the most lively squares in all Lisboa. So many shopping and dining options around to choose from. Loved walking around here
reviews/6/text: Praça de D. Pedro IV (Rossio for the Portuguese and tourists) was built during the 13th century, but its current appearance is the consequence of several modifications made over time starting with the greatly destructive Lisbon earthquake. In the center of the square is the tall Column of Pedro IV while to the south and north there are two bronze fountains while the typical Portuguese mosaic forms the beautiful floor of this square. Even the buildings around the square have undergone important changes during the historical evolution and among them the Queen Maria II National Theater stands out. In the northwest corner of the square is the Rossio train station. Interesting historic square in Lisbon
reviews/7/text: This square is absolutely beautiful. Fountains, statuary, wavy cobblestones, lots of cafes, great people-watching.  I wish we had had more time to spend more time.
reviews/7/title: It's known as the heart of the city.
reviews/8/text: WOW. I was disappointed. There was an enormous amount of construction and it really subtracted from the experience. The photos on the internet show something magnificent.  On this day, this square or; more correctly, this rectangle, was being setup for Christmas. I could hardly walk around the square. Also, the facade of one of the main buildings facing the square was covered with scaffolding. I think I must have come at a bad time and, after the construction is completed, it will look better.
reviews/9/text: Yet another square to take a minute or two of rest before continuing to explore this wonderful city, no water in the fountains though, sign of the times I suppose.
reviews/10/text: This is a nice place to sit and people watch.  Enjoy the fountain and statues.  It's a good place to recharge.
reviews/11/text: Beautiful square as you head to Praça do Comercio. You need to stop there to admire it and maybe eat something before you continue. Around the square many restaurants and stores are located. The tiles on the floor are very unique and for sure worths a visit.
reviews/11/title: Beautiful Square before Praça do Comercio
reviews/12/text: Toward the end of our walk. Sat here and took in the sights. Very pleasant. Away from a lot of activity it was nice to see a quieter part of Lisbon,
reviews/13/text:
This square is quite large in size and has a giant needle to it's centre that has a statue of Dom Pedro at it's peak. There are two fountains at each end of the square that have lovely figurines on them but unfortunately are both in need of a deep clean.
The fountains were not working when I was there but imagine it would be a lovely sight when they are on.
reviews/13/title: LARGE SQUARE WITH LOVELY STATUE AND FOUNTAINS
reviews/14/text: This is one of the most central squares in Lisbon. We were actually staying close by, it is very well connected to the rest of the city via underground or tram. Shopping districts close by as well. We even walked from here to Alfama instead of taking the tram. The square itself is quite nice, there are some markets on some days of the week which seemed nice as well.
reviews/14/title: One of the most central squares in Lisbon
reviews/15/text:
Rossio is the most central square in Portuguese capital.
It's official name is King Dom Pedro IV square, whose tall obelisk statue is in the middle. Two beautiful fountains adorn it on both, north and southern side from the statue, along with the National Theater on the northern side as well.
However, its main feature is the "Wave" cobblestone pattern (every square in Lisbon has a different pattern) of "Calcada Portuguesa". This is the famous pattern you see on Copacabana in Rio de Janeiro and in Senate Sq in Macao.
Great place to admire this beautiful pavement artwork, take pics and just people watch.
reviews/15/title: Copacabana and Macao waves originate from here
reviews/16/text: Lovely place, lots of places where you can eat, there's a water fountain  to cool down,  by the metro and busses, 2 mins walk to trams so great location.
reviews/17/text: A must place to visit if you are in Lisbon the architecture and statues are amazing and if you are thinking of doing a tour you really should there is so much to savour about the history of this beautiful city.
reviews/18/text:
We passed through here on the way to somewhere else...which is probably how most people see it. We also heard it had good views of Carmo Convent...which it sort of does.

We didn't pay much attention to the buildings around it as we were drawn the the wiggly tiled floor and the kids chasing a man blowing bubbles. 

It is a nice place to watch the world go by and has great connections to other places.
reviews/19/text: We pass through this square often during our long visit, but we do not pay enough attention to the historic buildings.  We were reminded of the historic taverns and cafes that are around.  And note the wavy stonework, waves on the ocean.
subcategory_ranking: #60 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Av. 24 de Julho, 1200, Lisbon 1200-481 Portugal
description:
In the morning, Mercado da Ribeira is a traditional food market that dates back to the 1890s, where you'll find local vendors selling fresh produce, flowers, fish, cheese, and other groceries. When the market closes, head to the next-door dining hall (Time Out Market), where there are over 30 stalls showcasing the best of Lisbon's culinary scene. Curated by Time Out’s food writers and editors, you'll find street food vendors and Michelin-star chefs serving up traditional Portuguese fare, seafood, pizza, ice cream, and more. Get your food, grab a beer, and find a seat by the communal tables. Meal times are busy, so get there early to avoid the lines.

Don't miss all the best spots on a walking food tour of Lisbon. – Tripadvisor
name: Mercado da Ribeira
neighborhood_info/0/name: Bairro Alto, Bica & Cais do Sodre
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Central Lisbon E-Bike Tour

offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon Your Perfect Day in the City Custom Private Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Lisbon Half Day Private Tour
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Lisbon Scavenger Hunt: Princes, Poets, Playwrights & Promenades
ranking: #87 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #87 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text:
The food court is nothing short of amazing. There is something to entice every palate and some of the nation's aspiring chefs are represented here.

Although there are an extensive array of tables or benches available, it can be difficult at peak periods to find a couple of seats together in the communal dining area.

We arrived prior to 2pm and it was disappointing to discover that the flower and vegetable market closed around 2.30pm. Having opted to eat first, we never got to visit the markets. We will be wiser next time around.

The Time Out Market as it is known as is well worth a visit.
reviews/1/text: After hearing a lot about this market, we visited during our vacation. It was packed and the produce part was closed. We found much better places to eat and enjoy than Mercado da Ribeira. The only exception was Manteigaria.
reviews/2/text: Mercado da Ribeira (Time Out Market) in Lisbon opened in 1892, it remains Lisbon’s main food market.  The building is interesting, the vibe is vibrant and bustling.  We walked round the food court which offered not only Portuguese food but international food like sushi, tempura, hamburgers.  There are long benches every and full of customers sharing them on a Sunday.  We didn’t eat there.  We also visited the flea Market adjoining it but not many shops were opened - just shops selling stamps, coins, etc.  Good for a visit.  For those who like the bustle abd vibe of eating in a large food hall, I guess this is an ok place.
reviews/3/text:
For us it was overrated, it has a good atmosphere but the food and services are less than average. We had pizza and salads from two different restaurants, heard people complaining about the quality and food coming out cold. 
We didn’t try other foods so we cannot generalize. 

Maybe we should’ve come earlier
reviews/4/text: This is a big traditional market open early in the day.  I found my favorite merchant and she loved to show me what she had each day, beautiful fruit and vegetables.  How could I refuse?  Filled up my kitchen.
reviews/4/title: Where I Bought Fruit and Vegetables
reviews/5/text:
We chose to visit this market as we wanted to enjoy a local Portuguese market.
The market has got 2 parts, one part which is opened until noon and where from you can purchase all kinds of fruits, vegetables, meat and flowers. And another part where you can find a lot of mini-restaurants with a variety of food which you can take away or eat there. The prices here are accesible for everyone and the dishes cover all tastes, wheather it’s drinks or food, both local & international: cocktails, freshes, smoothies, pastries, appetisers, all sorts of meet and sea fruits cooked or grilled.
We arrived at noon when the market was very crowded. We were glad to find here the restaurants of few famous chefs from Lisbon decorated with Michelin stars like Vincent Farges, Marlene Vieira, Henrique Sá Pessoa and Miguel Castro e Silva and, although we haven’t had the complex experience of a Michelin stars restaurant, we had the chance to enjoy a dish from all of them.
reviews/6/text: This is a perfekt place for a Break - short or long - daytime or evening. Lots Of people and lots Of great food for everyone.
reviews/7/text: It's a lovely place but overcrowded and overpriced. It still could be a good dining experience but not in the height of summer when it gets hot and stifling and no place to sit ant enjoy the food. Autumn and winter are far better I think for this experience.
reviews/7/title: Good to visit but not a good dining experience in summer
reviews/8/text:
Really great little place. Loads of choice of food and drink. Great atmosphere. Great food. We had burgers, filet mignon, jungle curry, doughnuts, gelato and the traditional Portuguese tart. 
Worth a visit. 
Wine bar let’s you taste first. And the wine was excellent!
reviews/9/text: We had an apartment near here and I came to this market regularly to buy fresh fruit.  Also good for vegies and all sorts of other food products.  Next door is the amazing Time Out Market.  Food Land.
reviews/10/text: This is a great market with loads of food outlets. You can sit at long tables inside and buy all sorts of food or sit outside at the restaurants for lunch as we did.  Superb seafood.
reviews/11/text:
If you go early before 10 am, you can see the fish and fruit market.
The food is above average, deserts are good...
Its place to visit and relax.
reviews/12/text:
Mercado da Ribeira (Time Out Market) is a tourist-must-visit.  The location is excellent (next to metro, ferry terminal and train station).  

There is a huge food hall, traditional market place and craft market (the day we visited).  

The traditional market opens everyday but closes quite early.  The food hall is always busy.  The price is quite high for the same food compared to other food courts or restaurants.
reviews/12/title: Food market at an excellent location
reviews/13/text: Good place for a quick lunch stop. Food we had was good, all ate at communal tables. Wide variety of places to choose from
reviews/13/title: View variety of places in eat in hall
reviews/14/text:
We Paid parked outside in a public parking. 
Went in and found out the prices are little higher than outside,and  with least options.
We made U-turn and Went to eat elsewhere.
reviews/15/text: We are staying in the area and I am happy to come to this pleasant market to buy vegetables and fruit, that is on the days it is open.  Come early as it closes early and check for open days.  Nice displays.  Friendly vendors.
reviews/16/text: Went here for lunch; disappointed in the selection of food (mostly seafood and pastry shops); prices were high and the waiting time for some of us was lengthy.  It felt like it has turned into a tourist trap.
reviews/17/text: It’s nothing special and prices are high for what you get..Five minutes away at the small streets around you can find great and cheaper food
reviews/18/text:
This place is just perfect when you want to try new things without committing to just one restaurant or style. You can explore different flavors and dishes by deciding right then and there. The quality is surprisingly good and the price is average. 

Bottom line: you’ll find something you like for sure!
reviews/19/text: Time Out is an excellent place to go and taste all the flavors of Lisbon.  So many great restaurants from seafood to burgers to pork to desserts.  You must go here if you like to eat a lot of food.  Fantastic food hall and every place was top notch.  I think I tried food at 6-7 places and they were all excellent.
subcategory_ranking: #87 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Praca da Estrela 12, Lisbon 1200-667 Portugal
name: Basilica da Estrela
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Belém Lisbon Hop-On Hop-Off Bus Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Lisbon All-in-One Hop-On Hop-Off Bus and Tram Tour with River Cruise
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon Hills by Tram 28 route
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Lisbon Hop-On Hop-Off Tour: 48-Hour in Belém & Modern Lisbon

ranking: #69 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #69 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: I really love this church and the view from the roof is amazing. Very quiet & off the beaten path. I will definitely be returning.
reviews/1/text: Beautiful church. Go up on the roof as the views are amazing. You can also Walk round the dome of the church. It is like the whispering Gallery in St Pauls Cathedral, London. Only 4 Euros to go up to roof, free to enter church.
reviews/1/title: Wonderful view of the inside of church from the dome walkway.
reviews/2/text: Paying to go up to the roof of the basilica was the best €4 of our holiday. Beautiful building and lovely photo opportunities.
reviews/3/text: This is a lovely church that is in need of a clean on it's exterior. However, inside it has a sublime altar with a large mural and white winged angels. There is a fantastic dome and a wonderful painted ceiling with mural down each side of it's aisles.
reviews/4/text: Basilica de Estrela can be seen from far away from many vantage points in Lisbon, with its white facade end two bell towers. Taking tram 28 there from Chîado is the best way of getting there. The interior is  - well - nothing much special, and a quick stop is enough.
reviews/5/text: Known for the white exterior and dual bell-towers, Basílica da Estrela warrants a brief visit to view Queen Maria's tomb and an impressive pulpit.  Less ornate than other churches in Lisbon, there is an outside terrace available for a small fee but the view is fairly limited.
reviews/6/text: Impressive Basilica that’s on the infamous Route 28 tram. Worth having a stop off to view and pause. Well worth a stop off .
reviews/7/text: Probably because of the new covid-19 restrictions, but the church was closed when I passed by here... otherwise looks pretty impressive from the outside... there's a nice green park in front
reviews/8/text: Basílica da Estrela is a nice church, outside of the main touristy circuit path in Lisboa. It's quite big, neobarrocan style.
reviews/9/text: It looks fantastic outside, but it makes a really  big impression when you enter it. Basilica da Estrela is one of the most beautiful and impressive churches in Lisbon. It is huge with very impressive baroque and neoclassical architecture. The church  has a giant dome, the bells of the two bell towers ring in a charming way, and paintings by Pompeu Botoni and Pedro Alexandrino emphasize the baroque elements of the interior.  A bit out of the way from the center, but  is a must-see in Lisbon. It is also a stop for tram 28 which is also a must when visiting the city.  Opposite is the most beautiful garden in Lisbon, my favorite.
reviews/9/title: One of the most beautiful churches in Lisbon
reviews/10/text:
In 1789 this basilica was consecrated, it was the first church in the world to be dedicated to the heart of Jesus.
It took a decade to complete. The room behind the tomb of the founder houses a magnificent nativity scene.
A wonderful place to sit, reflect and be mindful.
reviews/10/title: Well worth a visit. Beautiful basilica
reviews/11/text: Beautiful church but it's quite a walk with not that many tourist attractions around it (though there is a lovely park opposite). You can go on the roof and visit the dome (thought this was closed due to a mass when I visited.)
reviews/12/text: We visited on a Sunday morning between masses (an English language mass is offered at 10:00am). Recorded religious music was playing, adding to the ethereal qualities of the ornate sanctuary. One of the highlights here is a 500 figure terra cotta and cork nativity diorama in the Presepio, open 10-11:30am (Tuesday-Friday) and 3-5pm (every day except Wednesday). Admission to the church is free; admission to the Presepio is 2 euros. Tip: Bring a pocket flashlight to highlight details in the nativity.
reviews/12/title: Time your visit so you can view the terra cotta and cork nativity -- we didn't :-(
reviews/13/text:
Estrela Basilica is recommended to visit as typical church at LIsbon center.
Preferably using E28 tram
reviews/14/text: The Basilica is not like its" colleagues " in Lisbon. It has two towers topped with domes. At the time of our visit there was a service, so acquaintance with the interior was very brief, so as not to disturb anyone. But with a separate entrance it is possible to climb to the roof. This part of the Cathedral itself is very interesting, besides it offers excellent views of the city.
reviews/15/text: We went in and were surprised that it wasn't bigger. Still worth a visit to admire the construction and the religious artwork.
reviews/15/title: Impressive building especially from the outer side.
reviews/16/text: If your able pay the 3-4 euros and climb the 104 steps up to the roof of this church. The views are nice and seeing the upper parts of the church, up close is a neat experience.  The best part is you get to walk around the catwalk on the upper part of the dome. This unique view is breathtaking and seldomly offered in the great churches of Europe.
reviews/17/text: Set on steep hill I wisely took tram 25E there. Well worth paying 4euros to climb the 110 steps to the dome and then the roof with great views. Slight contradictory info on opening hours as one site said 10.30- 7.30 whilst second site said closed between 1-3pm. Having asked at Lisbon Info centre they phoned Basilica who said it was closed for a wedding and next day would be closed at 5 for mass. However, I still went to take photos of outside, only to find it open till 3 when wedding starting!
reviews/18/text: There was a wedding about to start, which was magical but we could only view the church from the rear. You can walk up to the terraces 114 steps for 3 euros but check opening times as was closed when I descended around noon. Fantastic views.
reviews/19/text:
Arrived via Tram 28 from the old town.
Lovely inside (free to enter) and paid the €4 to climb the spiral stairs (totally safe) to the roof for lovely views. Very peaceful
subcategory_ranking: #69 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Rossio dos Olivais Parque das Nações, Lisbon 1990-231 Portugal
name: Altice Arena
ranking: #76 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #76 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: This area is great with lots of restaurants by the river, left and right of the Altice Arena. It has been a couple of years since we have been down this way, but there is a little bar, between the restaurants, and at 2.50€ for half a litre of beer, it has to be one of the cheapest places in Lisbon to have a drink. They also have cocktails. It is open to the elements to a certain degree, but still under cover, so wrap up warm this time of year....
reviews/0/title: One of the cheapest bars in Lisbon......
reviews/1/text: Travelled from the UK to see Andre Rieu. Excellent venue. Very well organised and good seating. Very easy access. Would certainly visit again.
reviews/2/text:
Travelled from England to see Andre Rieu and his orchestra.
We were shown to the VIP entrance, walked through a bar, then shown to our seats. Excellent serve, good acoustics, comfortable seating. Easy to get out also.
reviews/3/text: Must see in Lisbon, the Pavilhao Atlantico/Pavilhao da Utopia(old names) is a state of the art arena.This cat close to the Arena is just outstanding.
reviews/4/text:
Excellent venue for music concert. Michael Bublé Concert, was absolutely amazing. Well run, very well attended.
We will definitely return.
reviews/5/text: Purchased VIP tickets for Michael Buble at the Altice Arena, October 1st 2019. We have been to the Altice twice before, an excellent venue but this time there was a lack of security around the extended stage. With no one to prevent people standing, the only way of watching the show from the VIP area was to watch it on the screens. It reached the point people began booing and jeering until Michael Buble requested people return to their seats, this was greeted with cheers. It should not have been the responsibility of the performing artist to maintain order. However within two songs people were back standing around the extended stage area, what is the point of buying VIP tickets you might as well buy the cheapest tickets you can and stand at the front of the stage. If I wanted to watch the show on a screen I can wait until the DVD comes out and watch it on my TV! Not impressed with the organisation at the Altice but Michael Buble was excellent.
reviews/6/text:
Whilst this show venue is nothing short of spectacular, some of its services let it down. We were there to see the Michael Bublé concert (an amazing show it was too), but when I asked for a gin & tonic at the bar, besides the 6€ for the G&T, they wanted another 1€ non-refundable for the plastic 'glass'. I mean, seriously? Who drinks G&T out of a plastic 'glass'. And charging the extra 1€ is not going to save the whales, as the plastic galss was used anyhow. Its just another way of bumping up the price. To top off the insult, the bartender told me they didn't have any lemon (or lime) to put in the drink! Really? It's just not going to happen... I had a beer.
The mens and ladies restrooms were also undergoing renovation (which I understand as necessary once in a while), but to ask guests to use the facilities whilst the work is on-going (half-finished) is a bit too much.
Like I said, the venue is oustanding, unlike the services.
reviews/7/text:
We were here for two events, the Tool concert and the VOA rock festival. 
We loved the acoustics, the staff, clean facilities, the fact we did not have to queue for anything, food and drinks are reasonably priced (3 Eur for a small beer, 1.5 small water, 1 Euro for a coffee). While during the Tool concert the smoking inside the arena was corrected by the staff, during the VOA festival it was unbearable.  People had access to outside areas but many of them chose to smoke inside as well. The festival took place on 2 different days, from 16.00 to 01.00, so imagine having to inhale the smoke for so many hours. The staff was completely overwhelmed so smoking inside was no longer a problem. It's a pity people are so selfish and do not care about our health as well.  Maybe the arena should have a better ventilation system if they know these things happen.
reviews/7/title: Great arena, pity you can smoke inside
reviews/8/text:
Great Tool show here. 
Sold out!
Easy access, public transportation and near the mall to grab a meal. 
Definately a great place for a show in Lisbon.
reviews/9/text:
Absolutely FAB evening with Kool & the Gang.
Brilliant music, excellent seating, a real “feel good evening”.
Just wish Altice Arena Lisbon would put on MORE music shows!
Great ground handling staff, well attended.
Thank you Altice Arena, Lisbon. Highly recommend visiting.
reviews/10/text: Visited the arena for the Eddie Vedder concert, was first amazed by how reasonable the prices were for a beer 3€ wow and a decent beer too, O2 London take note. The venue was very intimate feeling so was perfect for this gig, I had great seats and no issues finding them. Staff and security were all very polite and helpful too. Nicely done
reviews/11/text: I put a tick on my bucket list and went to a final of the Eurovision contest in 2018 in Lisbon. The Altice arena was a fantastic venue. It was well organised and the staging and sound was excellent. easy to get to via the metro system. lots of bars and restaurants in the area. Well done Lisbon and the Altice team
reviews/12/text: Easy to reach via train or uber , nice surrounding boardwalk and mall, great hall for rock concerts.
reviews/12/title: Great venue, accessible, offers a great concert experience
reviews/13/text: I've been here for a concert. I was really surprised by the size of this place. Although there were a lot of people one don't have that awful crowd feeling that is usually in such places. Excellent acoustics. I hope to come again.
reviews/14/text: Formerly known as the MEO Arena, the Altice Arena hosts almost all of the concerts in Lisbon by international singers and bands of renown.   Inside there are several stand where concert goers can buy food and the various entrances to the different sections are well signposted for ticket holders to find their places.  There are a good number of toilets, which are well maintained.  Large conferences are also held here on occasion.  It's about 200 metres from the Oriente Metro Station and the Oriente mainline station.
reviews/15/text:
Great experience during Web Summit 2018 in Altice Arena. Close to Metro Station and river. 
Enough Space for Lot of People.
reviews/16/text: Great space for watching concerts. The only problem for me is that it gets very hot when it's crowded. Needs a better ventilation system
reviews/17/text: My second visit to the Altice Arena and was not disspointed. Show was fantastice and the Aren staff were very courteous and helpful
reviews/18/text:
Fulfilled a lifelong dream by managing to get a ticket for 2018’s Eurovision final held at the Altice Arena. The arena is huge but well managed, once through the doors it was easy to find your access point to your seat.
I suppose the only issue is that no bottles (plastic or otherwise) are allowed in the arena itself - even bottles of water had to be poured into a cup as that was the only way you were allowed to take drinks in.
reviews/19/text: Great gig tho the long line to get in was unusual but it moved quick, the sound was good inside. Only down point was there was patrons smoking inside the arena near the toilets which for modern arena disappointing for this be allowed to happen

address: Rua Augusto Rosa 42, Lisbon 1100-059 Portugal
name: Museu Do Aljube
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Full day Small Group Tour of Historical Lisbon
photo/caption: Exterior of museum; building used to house tortured prisoners
ranking: #15 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #15 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: We stumbled upon this museum while we were looking for an activity to pass the time until our tour started. I'm so glad we did! Everyone should visit this museum, especially at this time when many nations are taking democracy for granted and it is losing ground to right-wing dictatorships. The museum takes you through a time in history from the 1920s to the 1970s. It begins with the rise of fascism and the reign of the brutal dictator, Salazar. It takes you through the stressful, dangerous, and inspiring resistance to the eventual liberation with the fall of Salazar in April 1974. It makes one appreciate the fragility of democracy and what life can be life without it. History has a habit of repeating itself, and this museum's exhibits were a chilling reminder of what could happen to us should we fail to pay attention and work to safeguard our rights and democracy.
reviews/0/title: Moving, enlightening, chilling - a must-see for all
reviews/1/text: Very detailed and thought provoking museum with excellent exhibits, concerning the period of Salazar's dictatorship of Portugal. A bit too detailed in some sections, but sometimes we need to remember the things our fellow humans did to each other. Important lessons from history and really brings it to life with lots of explanation.
reviews/2/text: Amazing museum about Portugal’s history, it allows you to discovers the history behind this country in less then 2 hours in a simple but interesting way
reviews/3/text:
I am loving my time in Lisbon, but as I write this on the last day I am reflecting on how so much of the city, at least from a tourism-facing perspective, seems content to act like the history book ended on the glorious reconstruction of the city after the earthquake, aside from a small number of other modern builds. Even the Lisbon Story Centre nearly ends it's main section on that note, consigning just one room to the history of the square it's on in general. 

This is a roundabout way of saying that, with the Museum of the Republic/Presidency in Belem closed for renovation, this was the only museum in my 4 days here that actually addressed the modern political history of Portugal in it's capital city, and very effectively too. While I think I may have appreciated more background information before diving straight into the dictatorship (I think they assume you know more of the basics than I did), it overviews the principles of the Estado Novo, it's awful tactics for squashing dissidents, it's policies at home and abroad, and the resistance actions that would add up to defeat the regime in the 1970's very well. The prop work on the second floor deserves special attention, and it is a little chilling to remember that you're standing in the same building so many atrocities occurred at decades ago.

Some notes: this is very much a museum of political history, so expect that sort of tone and focus; plus I can imagine kids getting uneased, scared, or simply bored by sections.
reviews/3/title: An essential change of tone; affecting and informative
reviews/4/text: Portugal's long history of dictatorship, which began in the early 1930s and lasted over half a century, has been regrettably eclipsed (at least in America) by Franco's reign in nextdoor Spain. This museum, housed in a structure that has served as a prison for a millennium, provides an essential an moving account of that terrible time, in exhibits rich in photographic and material evidence of relentless repression. It's humbling to sit in the cramped confines of a former cell and feel some small portion of the fear that once reigned here. An absolutely essential visit for all travelers who desire to understand this frustrating and complicated city.
reviews/5/text: A thoughtful and important exhibition set in a historical prison. Well worth the visit and entrance fee!
reviews/6/text: Although the displays are not flashy they give a great insight into the times under dictatorship and the struggles for freedoms. It is well laid out and a good way to learn about a past that hopefully has gone for ever. We need to be aware of the past so we do not allow a repeat in the future (maybe too late!)
reviews/7/text: Interesting museum on Portugal's history of war and resistance against governmental tyranny. It's a little tedious to enjoy as it is extremely text intensive, some of it is in small print in low lighting, AND (notwithstanding the fact that Lisbon is, after all Portuguese, the English translations were sometimes a little elusive to find.
reviews/7/title: Interesting if you're a modern history buff!
reviews/8/text: The first two floors, including the special exhibition, are essentially useless if you don't read Portuguese. The portions that discussed the history of colonialism and the treatment of dissidents during the dictatorship were amazing. Until a week ago, I hadn't given any thought to Portuguese history. I knew they'd colonized Brazil and vaguely remembered something about Vasco da Gama from school. That was about it. Wow. I was missing out on so much. This museum is definitely worth the 3 euro fee. It would really benefit from an audio guide.
reviews/9/text: This museum provides an exorbitant amount of information. We spent about 2 hours here (not much to photograph, and we read about 90% of the info, but definitely not all of it). The history is fascinating and it's probably one of the few places in Portugal that really describes what life was like under the dictatorship. The info is just presented a little disjointedly and is a bit hard to follow sometimes. So much of it was really really interesting... but disorganized.
reviews/10/text:
Not really a place for little kids.  Popped in here after the Tram 28 tour, as it had started raining, and I chose not to get soaked going to the castle.  But this was an excellent educational tour across the dictatorship that controlled Portugal for nearly 50 years (1920's to 1970's), something that I had no prior knowledge of.

Repression of the population was paramount.  Did you know the dictatorship took advice on torture from pre-war Nazi Germany, from the nationalists in Italy, and from the CIA ?  Of course there was an underground movement for democracy, which eventually resulted in a populist coup in Portugal, and de-colonisation too.

But there's so much more to this museum, and you'll need a minimum of an hour and a half to do it justice.  All the exhibits are labelled in Portuguese and English, and well organised in chronological order, so you can follow everything.  There's tangible relief at the end of the tour as you re-live the uprising with the people and the military who opposed the dictatorship.  What a journey.
reviews/10/user/user_location/name: Ashby de la Zouch, United Kingdom
reviews/11/text: Only opened in 2015, this museum utilises the old military prison that was at the heart of Portugal's brutal military dictarship - which only came to an end in 1974.  It's been very well put together and most of the exhibitions have an English translation.  I highly recommend visiting this museum where you will learn of the difficulties and heroism which is so much of Portugal's 20th century.
reviews/12/text: We walked past this randomly and so glad we went in. It has English into the brutal dictatorship of about 50 years, political prisoners and the slave trade of Africa. There were 3 floors and each interesting but a horrible history that shouldn’t be forgotten. A very well presented exhibition space.
reviews/13/text: This museum tells the story of what people who were against the dictatorship had to endure. There is a lot of text to read, but you will get a good impression. They even reconstructed the jails they had to survive in.
reviews/14/text:
This amazing Museum documents the fight against the dictatureship endured by the Portuguese people for nearly 50 years ( between 1926 and April 1974 when a peaceful military Coup, named the Carnations Revolution, organized by leftist soldiers put an end to the regime ).
The museum brilliantly documents fascism and pays tribute to all those who fought and risked or lost their lives during those years. It shows the ravages, the destruction caused by nationalism and by dictator Salazar and his vision of a New State (there were indeed concentration camps located in Capo Verde, a Portuguese colony at the time).
The 3rd and 4th floors are particularly interesting and accessible as they reconstruct Portuguese' life under the Salazar dictatorship.
reviews/14/title: MUSEUM OF RESISTANCE AND FREEDOM A MUST!!!!
reviews/15/text: We came here with our young adult daughters intending for a quick stop at an interesting museum between a couple of other stops.  Almost 4 hours later we walked out.....  Many people know of the history of Portugal from the exploration periods in the 1500-1800's but not a lot know about it's history in the 1900's.  In order to truly understand so much of this country, this museum gives a lot of perspective into the much more recent past.  Our visit here also coincided with the inclusion of "The Three Marias" exhibit which was an amazing experience for our young daughters.  While the location and building as a prison dates back to Roman times, the largest part of the museum is about the reign of the Estado Novo - a corporatist/fascist/dictator era in Portugal from the 1930's until its overthrow in 1974.  This regime was highly brutal and aggressive with its imprisonment and torture of dissidents of the regime for decades.  It's longest standing head having had close relationships with Hitler and Mussolini should give some indication of the outcome if not the original intention of the regime.  To see the information that in 1970 (the year before I was born) that in Portugal only 47% of the people had running tap water, 64% had electricity and 60% had sewage pipes leads you to understand just how far behind the development of the rest of Europe and the US this country really was under this brutal regime.  The fear and memories still live within the older generation and per local friends, is slowly being removed from subsequent generations.  The country now is far from these 1970 statistics and the scarring left behind on its people is fading but definitely not completely gone.  This museum is a strong reminder of the past that must not be forgotten so as to avoid repetition.  To understand where you are, you must know how you got here.  Truly one of our more memorable stops in Lisbon.  It's not pretty or grand but a very informative and important place.  Located right around the corner from the entrance to the cathedral as well could not give you much easier access.
reviews/15/title: An amazing stop to really understand Portugal's recent history
reviews/16/text: Really a must see to understand and learn about Portugal drasmatic 20th century history. The museum made an amazing job in collecting facts, direct testimony and pictures of the unspeakable crimes marking these dark decades of its history.
reviews/16/title: Really a must to understand Portugal recent history
reviews/17/text: An intense journey through the fight against the dictatorship from 1926 to 1974, highlighting the terribly sad history of thousands of mistreated liberals. It was unreal being inside the building that used to imprison so many innocent men, women and children and learning exactly what horrific ordeals they experienced in their fight for freedom. Highly recommend a visit.
reviews/17/title: A detailed journey through the fight against the Portuguese dictatorship.
reviews/18/text: I had just visited the the Castelo de São Jorge for the afternoon and spotted the sign for this museum. The small simple entrance opened up to three floors of fascinating Lisbon, Portuguese and colonial history. But this is not the story of glorious men, fatherland and empire that you will see almost everywhere else in Portugal. Instead these are the difficult and sensitive stories of women and men who were suppressed and silenced both in Portugal and overseas: The Three Marias, the African nationalists and the Anti-fascists. This museum is quite unlike any other and draws back in time when the building itself was a women's prison. For a very different look at the history that many former imperial powers avoid take a walk around here.
reviews/18/title: How to visit a difficult and sensitive heritage.
reviews/19/text: Worst museum I've ever been to. The texts at the exhibits are poorly translated to English, they all have difficult to follow sentences, are full of unexplained acronyms, and are mostly just a dry summary of years and names. The focus is not on the narrative or the story, it seems like this is a museum for robots. See the pictures attached for examples.
reviews/19/title: Extremely dry and hard to follow

reviews/0/text: If you like sand beaches with a high waves it is the best playa for you. Many bars, restaurants, you find here everything you need for a nice day at beach
reviews/1/text: With the expert help of the front desk staff at the Meraprime Gold Hotel in Lisbon, my wife and I took the ferry across the river and then caught the bus to Caparica, which is a fun beach town.  From there we walked to the beaches, which stretch as far as the eye can see.  Great day trip from Lisbon!
reviews/2/text:
We took a day trip from Lisbon to Costa de Caparica today and enjoyed one of the top three beaches I have experienced in my whole life  - on par with Siesta Key, Florida and  Nauset Beach, Massachusetts, USA, and   Mazunte, Oaxaca, MX.

We took the ferry to Trafaria, then Uber to Praia Riviera where we found fine sand, clear water, gentle waves, and terrific seafood restaurant with beach umbrellas.  We visited on a hot Sunday in July so seemed like every family in Lisbon was at the beach today, but never felt crowded or harried.

BE ADVISED:  NO beach train runs on the narrow gauge tracks anymore.  Both our guidebooks (Moon and Lonely Planet, Sept 2021 editions) described this summer season train service running along the beaches from town of Costa de Caparica to points south.  Sand has drifted over the tracks and none of our Uber drivers remembered the train ever running.
reviews/3/text: We rested on the Costa de Caparica for three days. This is a cozy and lovely place. House for rent within walking distance of the beach. Cozy promenade with many cafes and restaurants, there is everything you need on vacation and even more)
reviews/4/text: We stayed in Costa de Caparica for 4 days. I'm not sure if we had too high expectations but it was a disappointment. The beach itself was wonderful. It was clean, and swimming among the waves was loads of fun. But along the beach, every fifty meter or so, there were restaurants that I can only describe as large boxes. They really are an eyesore, just as the large charmless hotels are just off the beach. The town itself is even less charming. It's very centralized in the  sense that restaurants and shops are on a couple of streets. Most of the restaurants were fast food joints, and a lot of the others weren't even Portuguese. Those that were had very little choice. The atmosphere in town was hectic rather than laid-back. It's a shame because this town has so much potential.
reviews/5/text:
Amazing place, Airbnb walking distan CD e from the beach, you can do everything by foot or take the bus and the subway and soon you'll be in Lisbon
Perfect for some holidays, the beach is very clean and dog friendly
reviews/6/text:
Lisbon is great, my friend lives there so it made it easy to get around as she knew all the places to go & how to get there, it really helped that she had learned the language as I found that Portuguese is quite hard to understand ( sounded more like Russian to me)!
The best tip is to get a transport pass which you can use for the trams, buses, ferry and trains/metro.  Taxis are cheap but Uber are even cheaper - from the airport to Costa de Caparica it was between 16 & 20 euros depending on traffic over the bridge.  
The beach is lovely, will lots of surf shops and restaurants.  The temperature was good, even though the Portuguese think it is cold, it was a pleasant 17 in the day, falling to 8-14 at night which would be great back home.
There are lots of pastelerias with amazing cakes, sandwiches and croissants, my favourite were the brioche croissants or freshly made sandwiches with sweet potato crisps.  Go explore Lisbon, it's amazing sites, lively market & food halls, the sardine shops and museums.  Would definitely return as there is plenty to do both sides of the river.  Wear comfy shoes as you will do a lot of walking and some of the streets are quite steep especially if you head up to the castle walls area.
reviews/6/title: Weekend break at the Lisbon coast
reviews/7/text: This beach is just 10 min by car from Almada. it is a beautiful place to spend an afternoon walking by the ocean, watch the sunset, swim or eat seafood. The point that the river meets the ocean is incredible
reviews/8/text: This was one amazing experience to tour Lisbon & the Costa area beachfront, with the surrounding towns as well that we got to visit. Very rich history to learn about the Portuguese culture. I would definitely visit again 👌👌
reviews/9/text:
A very nice beach and not so crowded like Cascais or Estoril.
Plenty of room for everybody and quiet. For us a positive experience.
reviews/10/text:
You need to go in April when the beaches are not heavily populated.people are lovely my hotel right on the beach trip caparica..lovely people very clean rooms 
Highly recommended
reviews/10/title: The best vacation i ever had
reviews/11/text: Take a taxi or Uber from Lisbon to Praia Nova.  Get out at the roundabout, take the small train down the beach.  Round trip 8 euros.  Get off at the end.  Spend a few hours and eat lunch.  Great day!
reviews/12/text: Second visit within one year, already can’t wait to come back. High class friendly instructors who are amazing Helder Dicha Mendes and Pedro. I have learnt so much bodyboarding with Helder.. 🤙 Based at Michellino cafe/restaurant beach bar.. Anazing food especially the burgers 🍔 friendly staff always so helpful.. ❤️❤️❤️❤️ 💯 recommend 🤙
reviews/13/text: It is really one of my favorite places to stay in the Lisbon area! The boats to cross to lisbon are great and it's much more fun than crossing by bus or car by the big beautiful bridge... Almada is a "little" village compared to Lisbon, but it feels natural... I got the information lately that FINALLY the bus/tram/boat ticket system is now finally one and the same (your tickets will be valid on any of these transportation means)! For years, that was a disturbing mess to have different tickets for each different company... when in Costa da Caparica, take time to head south along the different beaches... you can only enjoy it...
reviews/13/title: Ideal location ALMOST in Lisbon but at the beach (surf etc.)
reviews/14/text: A pearl close to Lisbon. Wonderful beach, it is worth walking down to the ocean at dawn and watching the fishermen.
reviews/15/text: great to have a run across the beach and enjoy the cafes and pubs around,not  sure about the night out as never been
reviews/16/text: Great boardwalk and Ocean experience. Love the long beach boardwalk and the cafes along the way. It is great all times of the year.
reviews/17/text: Excellent area to enjoy a holiday away from the noise of the city.The beach is excellent and easily accessible .Excellent choice of food and the most important is that the locals are friendly and helpful.
reviews/18/text:
A small village close to Lisbon and great if you like seafood! lots of restaurants and only 15 minutes by car to downtown. 
A very calm and laidback place . close to golfcourses if you enjoy golf.
reviews/19/text: Be careful because it's always full of people and if you go by car it can be a nightmare to return to Lisbon. Anyways it's worth it because the beaches are amazing!!!

ranking: #180 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
