reviews/0/text: Not the best we’ve ever been to, but a perfectly pleasant way to spend an hour or so with lots of little hidden corners - the cactus garden and nymph garden being cases in point! It would be interesting to see it in a couple of months’ time, when I’m guessing it will be at its best. Lots of peacocks around, too!
reviews/1/text:
5€ entrance, everything is "under renovation", although I dont believe they are actually working on _anything_ there. The cactii area is a freaking joke. No one has done anything there for months.
Lots of peacocks and a few nice trees make it good, but there was basically only 1 tree with a color other than green in there.
They close at 17:00 in March.
reviews/1/title: Would be OK for free, but not for 5€
reviews/2/text: Lovely tropical botanical garden, even on a chilly Sunday morning in the middle of January. Lots of peacocks, ducks, geese, and the obligatory adorable cat. Very peaceful and calm - a nice break from the usual tourist craziness.
reviews/2/title: Lovely break from the usual tourist craziness
reviews/3/text: I'm into botanic gardens and enjoyed seeing strange trees. Many were labelled but some need labels. I saw some birds which I dob't see at home too.
reviews/4/text: Such a nice little gem placed in Belem area. I was slightly surprised that you have to get a ticket… but I would definitely say it’s a lovely place for a walk or picnic. I guess it’s much better during late spring and early summer when all of the flowers and plants are blooming. In October majority of plants were dropping leaves and flowers and some of the park areas were closed due to maintenance.
reviews/5/text: Lovely peaceful garden to visit and cool under the trees.  Plenty of birds and especially peacocks who are roaming around the garden at ease with the people visiting.
reviews/6/text: What a gem to stroll through and explore wonderful flowers and plants while enjoying the shade. Anyone not enjoying the garden either didn’t take the time to explore it in full or have no appreciation of nature. Slow down and smell the flowers.
reviews/7/text: Some nice trees, but very low on flowers.. I wouldn't recommend it strongly except that it's in the middle of Príncipe Real, which is a fabulous area, and it's not expensive.
reviews/7/title: Some nice trees, but very low on flowers
reviews/8/text:
The garden is very nice, manageable, but for plant fans a really nice place to breathe. From fawns in the trees, chickens with their babies or purring cats, you can also discover the animal world here in miniature. There are plenty of benches to enjoy the greenery again in the shade. 
The only unpleasant thing is the still present colonial history, which is still visible at some of the gates.
reviews/8/title: A nice place to get away from the hustle and bustle
reviews/9/text:
This botanical garden provides an oasis of peace to shelter from the hordes of tourists visiting Jeronimos monastery.
With a somewhat decadent air, it brings together a very rich collection of plant species and magical "rooms" that post you in an intimate dimension.
reviews/10/text: A rating of 2 is a bit generous of me. Except for an area consisting of lawn, agapanthus, and bromeliads - plants found in ordinary people's gardens in much of the world - the botanical garden is in terrible disrepair. Specimen plants have been squeezed out by weeds, ponds are full of algae and have no fish or working fountains, and the walkways, stairs, and buildings are crumbling. Explaining away the decaying infrastructure by calling them 'ruins' is specious and certainly does not excuse allowing weeds to choke the small percentage of truly tropical plants. I say 'doesn't excuse' because whoever is in charge chose to spend tens of thousands of euros on dozens of two to five meter tall 'Alice in Wonderland' characters made of cloth covered wire frames - money that could have been used to rehabilitate at least some of the garden. My rating of 2 instead of 1 reflects the break my wife and I enjoyed from the throngs of tourists at the nearby monuments and museums while in the garden.
reviews/11/text: We were so very lucky!  When we stopped by the garden they were having exhibits taken straight from Alice through the Looking Glass (Alice in Wonderland) all throughout the park!  No matter where you turned you unearthed another bit of the Lewis Carroll story, so very realistically demonstrated!  From the Queen of Hearts to the Cheshire Cat (who kept appearing and disappearing) to the Mad Hatter to the Jabberwocky!  All in all it was a pleasure walking through one of my childhood favorites!
reviews/11/title: A wonderful experience of Alice in Wonderland
reviews/12/text:
DREADFUL!  An absolute waste of time and money. Very poorly-maintained and stocked, very few plants and trees of interest, and incredibly rude, surly, unhelpful staff at the entrance. Although, if I had to work there and mug people for 4 Euros to get in, I'd probably be rude, surly and unhelpful too. 

The best thing about it was a grumpy peacock who took great delight in screaming at everybody that walked past him.
reviews/12/title: Don't waste your time and money.
reviews/13/text: The trees and green are nice in the center of the city.  It is peaceful and there are many benches on which to sit and contemplate nature.  The trees are from around the world which makes for a more interesting visit.
reviews/14/text: There wasn't a lot of curation - it was more just an enjoyable place to walk and wander - lots of shade on a sunny day and lots of birds, which we enjoyed a lot.  The peacocks were plentiful.  We found it to be fairly empty on a weekday afternoon and a nice respite from the crowds at nearby attractions.
reviews/15/text: Many areas  were not open and other areas poorly maintained. It’s a very Hap-hazard layout. We were not very impressed and not with the €4 entry fee. Needs an upgrade.
reviews/16/text: Hi everybody! Just to let you know that the garden is OPEN again! So you can go visit this great place! 😁
reviews/17/text: The gates were closed when we travelled to Belém to see the park on Christmas 26th. I didn't find any information from their website about the construction which would have been nice. So before we left we just peeked through the park bushies and found out Jardim Botanico Tropical amazing! :D
reviews/18/text: Very nice park to visit for reposant moments, with a lot of palms and exotic plants, and also annimals, a little lake, a real pleasure for familys with kids.
reviews/19/text: Even though i visited these gardens during off season in which flowers no longer bloom, I thoroughly appreciated the gardens!  The care in which these gardens receive is impressive.  The shrubs are groomed daily in various shapes and forms and are simply beautiful!  There are beautiful fountains and historical architectural steps that add to the beauty of these gardens.  Very enjoyable and relaxing gardens with ample benches to sit on and enjoy the surroundings.  I can only imagine how impressive and eye pleasing the gardens are when everything is in full bloom.  I thoroughly enjoyed the gardens!!!

address: Avenida Engenheiro Duarte Pacheco Amoreiras Shopping Center, Lisbon 1070-103 Portugal
description: Lisbon's highest viewpoint is waiting for you with a unique view over the portuguese capital and its most iconic landmarks. An exceptional experience on the top of the Amoreiras Shopping Center which is in itself one of the highlights of the city's landscape and shopping experience. Open everyday.
name: Amoreiras 360 Panoramic View
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Belém Lisbon Hop-On Hop-Off Bus Tour
ranking: #83 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #83 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Fabulous  view of Lisbon City from the top of the excellent shopping centre.  Well worth a visit, good value.
reviews/1/text:
Another attraction that without the Lisboa card we probably wouldn't have done, but on our manic last day we squeezed as many of them in as we could.  We took a taxi from the statue of Jesus back across the water to the shopping centre.  

The reception area was well signposted and we were shortly 174metres above sea level looking out over the city of Lisbon.  From the elevated viewpoint you can see many of the well known landmarks of the city.

Its certainly not a must do if you are limited by time but as a short diversion its certainly worth a visit if in the area.
reviews/2/text: This is located within the shopping centre but is well worth a visit. It’s only 5 euros, take a lift up to the 18th floor. Then approx 20 steps outside and you come out to amazing 360 views of Lisbon. Well worth it
reviews/3/text: I visited amoreiras 360 deck on a 2 night stay in Lisbon trip! The view is amazing, really easy access and a fair price €$5,00. I would have stayed longer if it had a dry bar with wine! Nonetheless, the sunset was mesmerizing and I would definitely do it again!
reviews/4/text: Fantastic views for €5 and the telescopes are free . Shuts at 12.30 pm last entry at 12pm then reopens after lunch.  You buy tickets from information desk and go up escalator to lift.
reviews/5/text:
This is a great way to watch the sunset in Lisbon. The viewpoint is located on the top level of a big shopping center. The entrance is 5 Euro per person. It gives you an un-interrupted 360 view of Lisbon, the river and the bridges. 
Highly recommended.
reviews/6/text:
Being there overseeing lisbon from that extra angle is a must, plus shopping inside the mall,
nice staff.
reviews/7/text:
I recently returned from Lisbon, and made an effort to get to Amoreiras Shopping Center this time around.  The rooftop observation deck was fantastic.  I've visited Portugal many times, and can't believe I hadn't made it here before, now that I know what a treat it is.  It was a cool windy day, but clear, and the 360-degree vista was well worth the 5 Euro entrance fee.  Having a prior reference of the landmarks from the street level view only, this was such an education, and so impressive.  I will do this again when I return to Portugal.  
Tip: be mindful of the closing and last-admit times.
reviews/8/text:
A perfect location for 5€ to chill out and end your day. Good atmosphere, security guards control that all rules are followed by visitors (no smoking, no alcohol, no eating). 
Beautiful sunset, also perfect for plane-spotters as the airport is located near the shopping centre. On some days, you can watch planes approaching the runway.
As someone who wanted to take pictures of the sunset, it was a shame that the views are partly restricted by antennas of the building and also the building itself, so I have to cut and edit them. Therefore, only 3 stars.
reviews/9/text: Incredible view of the city and is upon a very nice shopping centre as well and quite cheap compared to other city view in Europe
reviews/10/text: It costs 5 euros (or just 3 if you are old) to go up to the rooftop viewing area.  You can see all of Lisbon and much more: river, airport and Belem.  It feels quite safe as there is only a drop of a few feet down to the actual roof of the building.  The viewing area is smaller in area than the actual roof.  We were up there on a showery day, but it was great to watch the rain clouds and rainbows.
reviews/10/title: Amazing views from the top of a shopping centre.
reviews/11/text: Went on a day when the weather changed every five minutes. It is an open air deck so no windows or fences obstructing the view but one does get the full force of the wind. All that said I was rewarded with a rainbow and an amazing view of this beautiful city. One gets to also see airplanes closeup landing at the airport. The staff was very friendly and helpful and there was a quick access going up or down. Loved the experience and at €5 well worth the money. 👍👍
reviews/12/text:
At first I wasn't keen on visiting Amoreiras as it was suggested by a friend. I thought it wouldn't be anything different to the Madoura. How wrong was I as it was the best view ever that you can see of the whole of Lisbon.

You can literally see the airport runway, the April 25th bridge and a few other important landmark from the top of Amoreiras. 

There is a concrete slab that you can sit on or stand on to take pictures, there is also a single aluminium bench also for relaxation. The top of the Amoreiras is only a small area and we didn't have that many tourists at the time of visit, which made the viewing, relaxation and photographs a wonderful experience.

Amoreiras is surely the place you can't afford to miss, it's highly recommended.
reviews/13/text: The best view of Lisbon by far, you can even see the airport runway and planes coming in and taking off. I would say it's good value for money and well worth the small admission price. The staff member at the entrance was very friendly and welcoming, so overall top marks.
reviews/14/text:
Would have given this 5/5 but signage around the centre not great. When we did eventually find it we had to go back downstairs to buy tickets.

However once up the top it had such amazing views and photo opportunities. There are information boards to help you pick out the sites and several, free, telescopes.

Lots of seating so you could relax and chill whilst enjoying the views
reviews/15/text: Amazing view. Great location, nicely furnished..  However a bar is needed, is the perfect spot for drinking a spritz or a coffe
reviews/16/text: We visited this while shopping on the ground level. We paid a very reasonable admission and went to the top of what must’ve Lisbon’s tallest structure. The views were great- you really could see all around. We recommend this for first time visitors to get their bearings in Lisbon.
reviews/16/title: Great views of the city and planes
reviews/17/text: Fab views of lisbon and a great way to get your bearings of places in the city. Comfortable seating up there with teleascopes at all sides to use at no extra charge. only downside is there is no direct transport link to the shopping centre and nearest metro is at the bottom of a steep hill but plenty of taxis to get back into the centre of Lisbon
reviews/18/text:
The view from theta of building 2 of Amoreiras Shopping Center, is spectacular. On a clear day you get the expanse of the Tejo and the greater Lisbon area, from Montijo and the Vasco da Gama Bridge to The Cristo Rei Christ Statue, Belem Tower and more.The price is reasonable and the allow you to stay as long as you want. The Shopping center is fairly upscale and uncrowded.

Amoreiras is accessible be several local buses.
reviews/19/text:
Well worth the €8 for my son and I to see the whole of Lisbon and coastline from above.

We were staying nearby so luckily came across it on TripAdvisor or otherwise we would never have discovered the views.
reviews/19/title: Great panoramic views down to the coast
subcategory_ranking: #83 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Praca Sao Joao Bosco, Lisbon 1350-297 Portugal
name: Cemiterio dos Prazeres
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Lisbon's Best Sites-Private Tour-4hrs
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Tram 28's Final Festination: A Slef-Guided Audio Tour of Prazeres Cemetery
ranking: #29 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #29 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: It’s a beautiful cemetery and a nice, uncrowded site in an otherwise crowded Lisbon. I took tram 28 from here, hoping for a seat as it’s the first stop on the route, but it was still a very full tram. I stood in the back for a good view of the city roads.
reviews/0/title: Good place to get away from the crowds
reviews/1/text: Easy Uber ride or end of line 28. Nice to wander around. Lot of history there and pretty view of the city. Glad we checked it out
reviews/2/text: So, yeah, I totally wasn't expecting to be able to peek into the crypts and actually *see* all the coffins on the shelves... A little bit different, but the feral cats were sweet. I definitely recommend a visit, simply to gawk at the enormity of the place.
reviews/3/text: I found the Cemiterio lovely and poignant, but I'm doing research on end-of-life issues. Not recommended for the easily creeped out or those looking for a morbid thrill; these are real mausoleums of real people from real families. If you can be respectful and appreciate the beauty, go for it.
reviews/3/title: Beautiful, but keep in mind it's a cemetary
reviews/4/text:
Quiet place except the airplanes landing.
Tram 28 is going there - final station. Always a good crowd of people.
There is a kiosk - we did not try it.
reviews/4/title: Specialpkace - special culture / similar to milano
reviews/5/text: Peaceful and beautiful cemetery that’s at the terminal for the Tram line 28. Nice crypts and church on the grounds. Recommended
reviews/6/text: This cemetery is a huge and amazing place...row upon row of elaborate mausoleums, it seems endless...I visited on a dark and rainy day, nobody around, kind of spooky! If you go all to way to the back, there's a great view towards the big bridge
reviews/7/text: Really beautiful place to wander around. The cemetery is clean, safe, and well kept. You could easily spend one hour here walking around. Graves look like miniature houses here. The cemetery itself sits on the edge of the river, with fabulous views of the bridge at the end. Easy to access the cemetery is located at the terminus of the famous 28th tram. Just don’t forget that this is a cemetery and act with respect, its not Disneyland.
reviews/8/text: At the end of tram 28’s route, this cemetery is absolutely fascinating.  The mausoleums vary widely from the small and simple to the large and elaborate.  The fact that many have windows, so that you can see the caskets themselves, is something I’ve not seen before.  It’s worth an hour or two.
reviews/9/text: If you go to the end of the tram line 28, you come across this amazing cemetery. Do go and have a wander. Apparently founded after a cholera outbreak in 1830s, each family has a little 'house' where the coffins are stored. Creepy but fascinating.
reviews/10/text: I came across by accident but what an amazing place.  I don't usually frequent cemeteries but this is so ornate.  Some of the memorials are true works of art. A lot of wealth can be seen in the  sizes of the tombs.
reviews/11/text: This is a normal Cemetery not a tourist attraction. If you like Cemeteries you can visit, otherwise go past.
reviews/12/text:
In one of the most peaceful locations in the busy city, it was wonderful strolling through the walkways and paths admiring the marvellous memorials.

So many famous Portuguese have their final resting place here, all lovingly commemorated with remarkable mausoleums. 

A grand statue to  Sebastião de Magalhães Lima is prominent. An accomplished polymath, he was born in Rio de Janeiro in 1850 and passed away in Lisbon in 1928.
reviews/13/text:
Went on a rainy afternoon and hardly saw any other tourist. Walked around with my husband making sure that we didnt disresepect those who lay in peace. It’s quite beautiful. 

After our brief walk, we walked to the tram station outside and took the 25 to Time Out Market. Conveniently located and probably not your usual toursit spot but definitely a must see.
reviews/14/text: The best place in Lisbon to take time-out for a well-deserved rest. The hardest part is getting out again.
reviews/15/text: Very beautiful and peaceful place. Not an ordinary cemetery.  Well worth the visit. You can take a peek inside the magnificent tombs and see very old and surprising coffins as well as pictures and other artifacts. Not to mention numerous cats. Pro tip: grab a tram 28 after visiting. It departs right outside the cemetery gates and this rout takes you to Alfama through picturesque districts.  This route is the best for tourists thus it gets very crowded and here you have the 1st stop, so there's a good chance to sit and enjoy the whole route.
reviews/16/text: ...& this cemetery did not disappoint, but mostly I just want to share this picture of a gorgeously haunting memorial to fallen firefighters. Great place to wander around for a while & ask the big questions. Hahaha. CR
reviews/16/title: I actually *was a high school goth...
reviews/17/text:
We took a walk along the hills, the Bario Alto. Trams were super full of people and didn't even stop. But in this way it was possible to see more of the real local life , outside ultra tourist zones of Lisbon.
The cemetery is a clean, quiet place to walk in, with beautiful monuments and family mausoleums.
reviews/18/text: I'm not a high school Goth, but I have always enjoyed visiting cemeteries, especially in foreign countries. This cemetery is not only beautiful and bucolic, as are most cemeteries, but it offers something unique in the sense that many of the tombs are outfitted with glass doors, which allow you to peer inside and see the contents. Don't worry, it's less grisly than it sounds. You mostly see coffins and some old photos plus religious artifacts and icons. The pathways are wide and accommodating and it's a perfect size -- large enough to make it worth the visit but small enough to really do a deep dive if you so choose. An added bonus is on-site restrooms, nearby shopping and cafes, and a group of friendly cats that hang out near the groundskeepers office, begging for pets and treats. I greatly enjoyed this cemetery and highly recommend making the trip. It's safe and accessible off several transportation lines. Our Uber driver drove us out there and said he regularly makes dropoffs here.
reviews/18/title: A Must-Visit Destination for Cemetery Fans and History Buffs
reviews/19/text: Peaceful cemetery on top of the hill with amazing views of the city.  The markers are unique and beautiful and provide a wonderful meditative environment.
subcategory_ranking: #29 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Parque das Nacoes Parque das Nacoes, Lissabon, Lisbon District, Zentral-Portugal, Lisbon Portugal
address_obj/street2: Parque das Nacoes, Lissabon, Lisbon District, Zentral-Portugal
name: Vasco da Gama Shopping Center
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Lisbon All-in-One Hop-On Hop-Off Bus and Tram Tour with River Cruise
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Shopping Tour Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon (All City) Belém Cristo Rei Private Tour
ranking: #73 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #73 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Good shopping mall with three levels next to Oriente station. There’s also a food court with good meal options. I went shopping
reviews/1/text: It was nice to have "all in one place" in a mega mall. We went to see around. It has many interesting stuffs and stores for shopping. We had a nice coffee time there as well. This mall had done food stalls as well. You can have a relax time after get tired from shopping.
reviews/2/text: I like Vaso da Gama shopping centre because it has all types of shopping and food. It is a little far from the city centre but metro takes you right in front of the mall.
reviews/2/title: Excellent Mall for shopping and food
reviews/3/text:
I rarely write reviews about shopping malls.
However, this one in the modern northeastern suburb "Nations Park" is an exemption.
It's a very modern shopping mall, set in a likewise district built for the 1998 World expo.
We went there after the Lisboa Oceanario visit and cable car ride.
Plenty of shops with very competitive prices (Portugal is cheaper than other EU countries anyway) and an excellent food court with huge choices and bargain prices.
reviews/4/text: Great stores and amazing food court with real restaurants. Are able to buy anything you need as a tourist including a huge supermarket. Location is across from train station/subway.
reviews/5/text:
If you plan to visit Parque das Nacoes, come to visit Vasco de Gamma Mall too.

The mall can be accessed by metro red line, bus or train.  We came here on Thursday 3 weeks ago and it was very busy.  

There are over 150 stores and a food court.  The supermarket Continente is on the ground level.
reviews/6/text: It's a big multi-level shopping center with a lot of the stores that you find all over Europe and with some places to eat.  Linked up with the Oriente train station and the huge Parc dos Nacoes recreation area.
reviews/7/text:
Taking the metro or even the bus to the “Oriente” stop will get you to this mall.  If you have a car, there is an extensive garage to one end. 

We walked through the mall to get to “Parque das Nacoes” and went north along the promenade to get to Lisbon’s famous aquarium. 

One is struck immediately about how modern this mall looks.  There are three floors filled with 160 stores.  Some are from the USA and some are not.  If you want to reach an Apple Store, it is called here the “iStore.”  The reviews for it, though, are subpar. 

At one end is a huge food court.  There are all types of kiosks selling not only Portuguese food, but Chinese, vegetarian and there is even a KFC. At lunch time it is extremely crowded. You will also notice that many of these vendors have silverware and ceramic bowls for their patrons.  You come here to really enjoy your meal.

We did find the bathrooms to be inviting, large and clean.  Seeing the Vasco da Gama Mall was fun and exciting.  One can spend an hour or a half a day at this mall. 

If you found this review to be “helpful” in any way, please check “LIKE” to let me know.
reviews/7/title: A Few Tips About this Mall
reviews/8/text: Mall is handily located a couple of stops before the airport, so it's useful for any last-minute shopping you may need, to eat, or just to kill some time before checking-in. Most of the food outlets have meal-deals during the day for 4 to 5 Euros, less than half the price that you'd find at the airport.
reviews/8/title: Plenty of Eating and Shopping Choices
reviews/9/text:
Amazing place to shop before you go to airport 
The metro station inside it you can find everything inside it
reviews/10/text: Very nice and modern mall... it's located right in front of the railway station...at the moment only a limited amount of outlets open, due to the current covid-19 restrictions...free and fast WiFi available
reviews/11/text: nice mall. good prices. has shops for all budget. good to find primark and cna. wide range of food and drinks.very easy access. nice break overall.
reviews/12/text: Came into the city for the day and stopped in to do a bit of shopping and a coffee break. The mall is large and has a great assortment of shops. The mall has a lot of light and very comfortable.
reviews/13/text: I had a few hours in Lisbon and stopped at this mall.  The shops are very nice and a good variety. The mall is laid out well for strolling around yet not getting lost.  It is very convenient.
reviews/14/text:
Nobody spoke English nor were they very friendly. Wanted a haircut and a blow dry , didn’t feel confident that my hairdresser knew what I wanted or understood me. 
Construction going on in the roof making something that should be relaxing quite unpleasant.
Needless to say, I grabbed my things and walked out.
Also, €40 for a wash, cut, and dry... a bit steep.
reviews/14/title: Haircut @ Jean Louis David Hair Salon
reviews/15/text: Had a decent lunch in the food court here on the day we visited the aquarium. Shops not really to my taste but others may find them great - to be fair we weren’t really there to shop - not a priority for us on a short break. Toilets weren’t very clean or well maintained.
reviews/15/title: Nice to stroll around if in the area
reviews/16/text: This mall is directly across the street from Oriente train station. There are 4 level with everything you could imagine, a huge food court, supermarket, cinema, and 100 shops. If you are a mall shopper we would highly recommend.
reviews/17/text: Even though this is a big shopping mall, I wasn’t really impressed by the stores. Didn’t find many interesting stuff to buy.
reviews/18/text:
Stunning shopping center and well matched with the modern context of Parque das Nações. Designed by the architect Santiago Calatrava who also designed the Orient railway station. Vasco da Gama Shopping Center is very well located and has underground connection as well as connected by a over-bridge with the Oriente metro and train station from where trains depart to various cities in Portugal. This Modern, sophisticated and welcoming shopping center, has numerous modern shops which are offering a wide range of products and services. It has 170 stores, food court with 33 restaurants, 6 cinema screens, a health club and has 2,700 parking spaces,

The mall has a large food court, 2 terraces floors with great views of the Nations Park and the Tagus River.There is a large food hall offering Portuguese, Italian, Middle Eastern, American fast food and Oriental cuisine. In the mall's 2nd floor food court, the USA fast food chains seem to be very popular. Additionally, there are also outdoor resturants and coffee shops. The mall has enough seating areas just to take rest.

NOS multiplex movie theater and the continente supermarket are also located inside the shopping center.

Great for family outings both indoors and outdoors. A great place to spend time in, shop, dine or go to the cinema.
reviews/19/text: We enjoyed strolling through this large and bright shopping mall adjacent to the Parque das Nacoes and Oriente Station. It includes a large grocery store and large indoor and outdoor dining places and seating areas.
reviews/19/title: Exciting Design in a Busy Location across the Street from Oriente Station
subcategory_ranking: #73 of 798 things to do in Lisbon

address: Calcada da Quintinha 6, Lisbon 1070-225 Portugal
description: Built between 1731 and 1799, the Águas Livres Aqueduct was a vast system of collection and transportation of water, through gravity, which comprises a total of 58 kilometers of existing pipelines between the springs, located 15 kilometers to the northwest of Lisbon and the water standposts in the capital. In its path, the crossing of the Alcantara valley, stands out along its 941 meters long and with arches that reach the 65 meters of height. The route is open to visitors between Campolide and the Parque Florestal de Monsanto. It has been classified as a National Monument since 1910.
name: Aqueduto das Aguas Livres
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: The Essence of the City - Lisbon Compact
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Lisbon Small Group Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Lisbon Layover
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Lisbon See-it-All Private Tour
ranking: #66 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #66 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: We arrived before 17h and it was already closed. The security guy was very rude and said it was past time according to his watch 😅 surreal
reviews/1/text:
The aqueduct itself is amazing. Hard to believe that this marvel of engineering withstood the Lisbon earthquake of 1755 that devastated so much else of the city. Also astounding to see how little water this massive structure actually carried!

As for visiting it...we were a bit disappointed to discover that, contrary to what the website suggests, there is no water museum here; that's apparently on the other side of the city. And the 4€ admission price (not 3€ as stated on the site) basically just allows you to walk halfway across the thing, pass through it, then turn around and come back. It does not include admission to the museum. Consider saving your money and just admiring it from below.
reviews/1/title: Impressive monument, but not a great deal
reviews/2/text:
Impressive aqueduct in the middle of Lisbon. Drive under it to appreciate.
Adds to the beauty of this lovely city
reviews/3/text: This is quite an impressive sight, a massive aquaduct that dates back all the way to the 18th century, it seems to go on forever
reviews/4/text: Construction began in 1731 and was completed in 1834.  The Aguas Livres aqueduct was an extensive system for water abstraction and transport  by gravity. The 1755 Lisbon earthquake struck the city, but the aqueduct remained intact. Classified as a national monument since 1910, it is considered a remarkable piece of water engineering. The most famous part is the 35 arches above the valley, the highest of which is 65 meters high. It is not very visited as it is a bit far from the historical center. Interesting architecture, especially the opportunity to see the interior where the water was flowing. Impressive structure.
reviews/5/text: Although we had been to Lisbon many times we had never seen the aqueduct until this year, taking the bus from Sete Rios. Beautiful aqueduct. Will have to walk across it some year.
reviews/6/text: This was a great sight to see from afar as that is the only way to see it in full as being up close one cannot get the scale of it
reviews/7/text: A lovely aqua duct, c18th architecture, and stands so proud on the skyline, well worth a visit, if your in the area.
reviews/8/text: The story of water delivery to Lisbon is very interesting, andby visiting aqueduto das aquas livres you get a good impression of how this was and the details of the system also in the city. When entering you get a guide which gives you also the loction of other spots in the city to visit, for instance where the water is stored and distributed. This was interesting. However, what dissapointed me was the view. This might be obvious, but by walking on the aqueduto, you do NOT get a good view of the aqueduto itsself.
reviews/8/title: interesting but not the best view
reviews/9/text: Impressive architecture - hard to believe it is C18 - looks like it was built in C20.  Great views.  Take about 30 minutes to walk out across the bride and back.  Afterwards followed the track of the water to the Reservatório da Mãe d'Água das Amoreiras which is also impressive from the outside but didn't go in as we arrived at 12.30.
reviews/10/text:
We took the bus 711 from town-center (Praça do Mercado) to Armoreira and from there walked about 5-10 minutes to the entrance. 
Compared to the crowds at the other sites this was pretty much deserted, just a handful fellow tourists. So it's a leisurely stroll across the aqueduct and then back. You have a view of Lisbon in the distance. We enjoyed it a lot and marveled at all the planes every couple minutes directly overhead. 
The structure itself is impressive, what we enjoyed most however was the atmosphere of peace and quiet infused with history.
reviews/11/text: A leisurely walk with fantastic views. The staff was fantastic and actually took us inside and explained how everything worked. A beautiful structure that has stood the test of time. A pity it is not functional anymore.
reviews/12/text: Early 18th century aqueduct that carried drinking water to the city. Small museum. Check opening hours before you go. Curves round so there are photo opportunities. A walk of maybe a 3 km round trip.
reviews/13/text: The walk along the aquaduct was awe inspiring, with great views across the city.  The archways supporting the aquaduct are immense, don't miss the opportunity to see for yourselves
reviews/14/text: Enjoy the view from the tallest arch of the world, with 65meters in hight! (Keep in mind that there is only one entrance from the one side of the bridge) The view is amazing and there are many options for mountain walks at both sides of the bridge.
reviews/14/title: Visit one of the most intereasting Guinness-Record holder places of Portugal!
reviews/15/text:
This is a hidden gem as it gives you amazing views across the valley and you can see down to the river and the bridge even.  

Opening times on trip advisor are wrong ...
reviews/16/text: The Aqueduto das Aguas Livres  is a spectacular building worth to visit. Considering the length and the heights, this is a great architectural achievement. And a nice view into the valley …
reviews/17/text:
Not surprising, given that it's still a tremendous sight to see the sweeping arches at various points in the city.

Our first sighting was in a taxi from the airport; we had best views as we approached, passsed under and then receeded. Very impressive.

A commemorative arch on Rua das Amoreiras  to mark the arrival of water in 1748 is beautiful. From here are excellent vistas of the towering arches.
reviews/17/title: Once regarded the most spectacular sight in the city
reviews/18/text:
I visited this historic yAquaduct built in the city of lisbon in 18 th Century. Said to be 18 kms long to bring water to Lisbon built by King John V. The project was paid for by special sales taxes imposed on wine, Olive Oil, beef and other products. It has arches about 65 m in height across the Alcantra valley. I walked across it on the pathway from a garden to the other end where there is a beautiful garden however the access Gates to the Garden were locked from the Aquaduct . So you have to walk back to Musea de Aqua the entrance where there is a small garden- fantastic views of the locality and the super highway and bridge etc.
In the middle there is a cross over from one path to other side path and in the middle you can see how the water was transported!!
Quite a hectic walk with windy conditions.
The Guards at the gate selling entrance tickets are v welcoming and you can purchase souvenirs there, and use the Toilets. You can drink water at the Fresh water fountain too .
Takes about one hour to see the place fully, walk from one end to another and come back.
Amazing sights and good photography spot.!
reviews/19/text: Everything you could expect of an aqueduct. Great views. Even lets you sample the water! And at one point you can look down the inside where the water is.

And that's kind of the same thing.'' We believe that providing the best tailor made experiences is about creating a momentum for good memories, the best memories! And thats why, based on our experience we have carefully crafted tour itineraries that you'll love to live.

address: Vasco da Gama Garden, Lisbon Portugal
name: Sala Thai
ranking: #201 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
ranking_subcategory: #201 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Attractive Thai building/Pavilion sitting in Belem gardens, why is it here and what is the significance of it, an information board would be helpful.
reviews/1/text: This Thai building seemed out of place in the midst of the park across from the San Jeronimo monastery. It's pretty, but it needs a little upkeep.
reviews/2/text: The Pavilhão Sala Thai is inside Belém's garden. It's curious to see a Thai building in Portugal. It was donated by the Thai Governement. If you've been in Thailand, it has nothing special, it's quite small. But seing it in Lisbon makes it interesting.
reviews/3/text: This is a hidden gem in an otherwise ordinary Portuguese garden. Very beautiful and we were glad that we had stumbled across it.
reviews/4/text:
Someone below comments that the Building is ugly, I wonder where they get that notion from. My Wife is Thai, and was very interested in seeing this building in a Lisbon Park - totally unexpected. Yes it was a surprise to see, but the attention to detail in the building is very good - even has both the Portuguese and Thai flags engraved.

Yes there isn't much to see, but even still, it is a stunning building.
reviews/5/text: Not much to see. Its just a house in a park, and it is beautiful but nothing special and maybe a bit odd to put it there.
reviews/6/text: It's an interesting Thai pavilion, but nothing else. As a symbolic gesture to the country it is nice. I won't call it a "tourist attraction" tho. May as well travel to Thailand and see some palaces ;)
reviews/7/text: This is a small pavilion, very pretty and well-maintained. If you've been to Thailand, it is really not worth going out of your way for. However, if you're in the area, worth a stroll to maybe take a photo in front. There's an enclosed children's playground just next to it as well, in case you have little ones who need a break.
reviews/7/title: Worth a peek if you're in the neighbourhood
reviews/8/text: This is one of those structures that seems so strikingly out of place and wrong that it's just... right.  A little hard to find but immensely interesting, in the midst of a great park.  Go take a look!
reviews/9/text: Recognising 500 years of bilateral relations between Thailand and Portugal this is a great monument and worth visiting in the park.
reviews/10/text: It is placed on the edge of a park, totally out of nowhere. Maybe I just don't get it but in my opinion, placing buildings that totally don't fit isn't a great idea. Especially in place as homogeneous (architecturally) as Belem.
reviews/10/title: A strange building disrupting the scenery
reviews/11/text: Take a walk in the park and visit this unique structure in a beautiful park setting. There is a play ground for children 50 feet away. 3 minute walk from the Trolley.
reviews/11/title: Great picture backround in the park
reviews/12/text: I happened across this little treasure while walking through the park (and eating my cream tart, of course!). Nothing to do really, but interesting to see.
reviews/12/title: Neat to see, but don't go out of your way
reviews/13/text: Not that easy to find if you don't know what you are looking for. But the golden building will reflect the sunshine if you keep your eyes open :) If you are in the Belém area go and take some photos, but don't travel there just for this sight...
reviews/14/text:
An unexpected structure to see in Belem is the Thai shrine located in Jardim de Vasco da Gama. 

This is a classic Siamese style pavilion, typical in appearance of what you can see throughout much of Thailand but on a small scale. Apparently, based on the information plague in front of the pavilion, this was a tributary gift to Portugal from the Thai government. The Thai Pavilion was inaugurated by Her Royal Highness, the Princess Maha Sirindhorn in 2012, and represents a token of friendship and recognition of 500 years of diplomatic relations between the two countries. 

It is interesting to see oriental buildings like this in places like this in Portugal, which is just as likely to be just as much an object or curiosity for locals as it is for visitors. You can conveniently see the Thai Pavilion in just a few minutes if you intend to walk the parks along Rua De Belem and Avenida Da India.
reviews/14/title: Tributary Thai Pavilion in Jardim de Vasco da Gama
reviews/15/text:
When walking through the Praco do Imperio square, outside the Jermino Monastery we came across this beautiful Thai shrine.  Local residents have meeting here, and it is also used to protect them from the sun and rain.

It is 22ft gold pavilion was a gift from Thailand given in 2011 to celebrate the 500th anniversary of Portugese explorers arriving in Asia.

The gold looking shrine is built of teak timber and shipped to Lisbon.  The daughter of the King of Thailand was the guest of honour at the opening ceremony.
reviews/15/title: Unexpected shrine from Thailand in city park
reviews/16/text: Édifice offert par le royaume de Thaïlande à l’occasion des 500 ans de relations diplomatiques entre ce pays et le Portugal. Très belle construction qui s’intègre finalement très bien dans ce lieu.
reviews/17/text: Pagoda instala en los jardines Vasco de Gama en el año 2.012. Se trata de un regalo de Thailandia a Portugal en base a sus excelentes relaciones durante siglos. Fue transportado en barco hasta Belém y montado allí mismo. Todas las maderas están ensambladas y no hay ningún clavo ni piezas de hierro. Bello de observar su construcción y colorido.
reviews/18/text:
EL templete Tailandes esta ubicado en el parque , es algo no esperado es una linda atracción por su colorido y sorpresa
Es una donacion de este siglo a modo de reconocimiento por la union de estos dos paises
Lindo para ver, no mucho mas para decir
reviews/19/text: Se trata de un pequeño templete donado por el Reino de Tailandia a Portugal en conmemoración del 500 aniversario del establecimiento de relaciones entre ambos países. Está hecho de madera dorada y de colores muy vistosos. Esta situado en los jardines de Vasco de Gama.

ranking_subcategory: #68 of 798 things to do in Lisbon
reviews/0/text: Rua Augusta runs from the Arch da Rua Augusta to the Independence Palace thru both Rossio and Baixa neighborhoods. Lined with an abundant of restaurants and stores. Great for people watching .
reviews/1/text:
On a rainy and wet day this pedestrian shoppingstreet can be very dangerous because the pavement (calçada portuguesa) made of basalt and limestone, can be very! very! slippery..... and you might risk to fall.

If the sun shines, other risky surprises might wait for you: pickpockets, agressive restaurant owners/employees who want you to come in their tourist traps.

But.... worth a walk from main square/praça do comercio to Rossio.
reviews/2/text: Good walk to see shops, restaurants and people watch. Right after the Arch. Beginning of Rick Steves stroll that ends up at the Train Station
reviews/3/text: Go early in the morning and enjoy walk down to triumphant arch and Praca Commercio beyond. Can be mega busy so depart your hotel early. Restaurants are very touristy ok if you want to see pizza on the menu. Do research and eat elsewhere. But it is a marvellous view through arch right down to The Tagus
reviews/3/title: Tourist Trap But Splendid Very Early Morning
reviews/4/text:
I spent time on and around Rua Augusta throughout my three days in Lisbon, but particularly memorable and unique was my experience strolling the street at sunrise, super early in the morning before the onslaught of tourists. Although all the boutiques and restaurants were closed, the peace and quiet I felt was outstanding. Crowds are fine, of course, but if you can wake yourself up early like I did, I highly recommend it.

The street, fully pedestrianized and adorned with that iconic Portuguese tile, is historic, safe, and reasonably clean. Some of the best shopping and dining can be found here. At the end of the path, folks can admire the “Arc de Triomphe” (Lisbon edition!) that forms a gorgeous frame of the water and the Praca do Comercio. Everything is laid out so symmetrically and neatly.

Come come come!
reviews/5/text:
Rua Augusta is a pedestrian street leading from the Triumphal Arch of Praca de Comercio to Rossio square
Two things are notable here - the Triumphal arch (which actually doesn't belong to this street) and the Calcada Portuguesa pavement pattern (which you can also see anywhere else in Lisbon).
Apart from this, it's a classic European pedestrian street with shops, restaurants and bars - suggest to avoid them (tourist places with inflated prices).
What bothered me most are pushy weed and other stuff dealers. A guy even took my camera out of my backpack, but luckily civilian dressed police caught him immediately.
reviews/5/title: Classic pedestrian street - watch your belongings
reviews/6/text: We walked here with the kids who also loved it. It was ambient, lively, had a really lovely atmosphere to it. There were shops, people walking, people eating.. and many shaded parts
reviews/7/text: It is a grand entrance to the lower city.  Walk through the gate and you feel a bit special.  There are hotels along the way, some shopping and places to eat.  Do not eat here as the restaurants are traps, but it is a good walk.
reviews/8/text: The main shopping area in Lisbon!  Always busy but has a nice atmosphere.  High street and boutique shops, souvenirs, coffee shops, restaurants and more.  Love the buskers.  Wear good shoes as some of the paving and uphill roads are tough in the heat.  Very touristy but good fun.
reviews/9/text: The main shopping street in Lisbon, leading down to the beautiful Praca do Comercio. Bustling, spacious and fun with lots of shops and cafes.
reviews/10/text: Rua Augusta is a great street in the city centre of Lisbon to stroll along and check out the various shops and restaurants. There are plenty of restaurants too which have outdoor seating. The only slight irritant as with most streets in Lisbon is the continuous amount of guys offering drugs for sale no matter what time of day or whatever type of person you look like.
reviews/11/text: It's a touristic street where you can find the Casa Portuguesa do Pastel de Bacalhau or the Custard Tarts of Manteigaria. Located between the Rossio Square and Terreiro do Paço
reviews/11/title: The main pedestrian street in Lisboa
reviews/12/text: Very nice street with many cafes, shops and restaurants. It is a busy street with many tourists. There is a beautiful view on the arch and the statue on the square.
reviews/13/text: This is a busy area of Lisbon and the framing of the street with the monuments is amazing. Visit both day and night to absorb different atmospheres.
reviews/14/text: It was nice to walk through this road although it does get very busy. The buildings are stunning and some looked amazing with  their Christmas lights. There are lots of bars, restaurants and shops. Also plenty of street performers.
reviews/14/title: Very pretty but full of tourists
reviews/15/text:
Rua Augusta is a wide and open, mostly commerical promenade, stretching from Praca Rossio to Praca do Commercio and the river. It's about a 10 minute walk. A large part of it is lined with shops and restaurants but what I liked most was the traditional paving and the triumphal arch.
The pedestrian area is lined with Portuguese calçada, the traditional mosaic squares of limestone and black basalt. These tightly laid, black & white squared cobblestones are so striking. I just loved this about Lisbon. 
There are other more striking examples in Rossio Square and Largo de Camoes but because Rua Augusta is long and straight and stretches out in front of you, you get the full effect of the geometric, diamond patterning all the way down the middle and the borders of on the sides.
The other wow factor is the triumphal arch. As you get closer towards the river, the gleaming white triumphal arch looms in the distance. This is the magnificent gateway to the Praca do Commercio. It’s a very impressive sight.
There are lots of street performers which is fun if you have kids with you. The guys with the soccer balls are pretty amazing.
Shopping-wise, you’ll find lots of clothing, high-street brands like Zara, H&M, Pull and Bear and souvenirs. Whilst I could happily leave the shops alone on this trip, one did catch my eye. Typographia is a home-grown Lisbon company, selling T-shirts with in-house, original designs. We picked up a few and they were great souvenir gifts.
reviews/15/title: Pedestrian Shopping Area with Traditional Mosaic Paving & Triumphal Arch
reviews/16/text: Rua Augusta runs from Praça do Comércio, from the Triumphal Arch up to Praça do Rossio.  It is a narrow pedestrian street, full of shops, including Zara, Mango,Pull & Bear and cafés.  It is not the most expensive street in the city, that is reserved for Avenida da Liberdade, but it's an ideal place to buy some less expensive souvenirs, sit and relax for a time and enjoy the excellent Portuguese coffee and pastries.
reviews/16/title: Pedestrian Street In The Heart Of the City
reviews/17/text: It is always nice to walk in this kind of streets. Full of shops, bars and restaurants. It directly leads to the big square and the Tajo River. Impossible to visit Lisbon and not come here.
reviews/18/text: Rua Augusta in Lisbon is the most famous street of the Baixa district, if not all of Lisbon. Rua Augusta is the main promenade of Lisbon, one of the most representative streets of  Lisbon. A place where expensive shops meet as well as small traditional shops selling handicrafts.  Rua Augusta is also crossed by the famous yellow tram number 28. Lisbon's main pedestrian street is over 550 meters long. It is a street closed to car traffic. Like the whole Baixa district, this street was also  rebuilt after the tragic earthquake of 1755 practically from scratch. Great place to walk and eat in the heart of Lisbon.
reviews/18/title: Pedestrian street with shops and restaurants in the center of Lisbon
reviews/19/text: I loved this part of the city, close to the ocean and yet still one of the main shopping streets with lots of specialist shops and such wonderful architecture and ambience. One could spend so much time here going in and out of the little shops and trying all the different restaurants, but for me it is better to just walk and watch.

address: Avenida Eusebio da Silva Ferreira Estadio do Sport Lisboa e Benfica, Lisbon 1500-313 Portugal
address_obj/street2: Estadio do Sport Lisboa e Benfica
description: Benfica Museum – Cosme Damião assembles the great themes of the history of Sport Lisboa e Benfica, of the city of Lisbon, and of the world. Visiting the Museum allows visitors to get to know and remember the trophies, the facts, and the names that helped Sport Lisboa e Benfica become a world-class sports club. Founded in 2013, this cultural site took the name of one of the most important figures in the history of Sport Lisboa e Benfica: Cosme Damião, known as the founding father of the Club. Across an area of about four hundred square metres, and three floors, the Museum displays around a thousand objects in 29 theme areas presenting high standards of interactivity and technology while telling the history of a country’s passion. Benfica Museum – Cosme Damião also offers a great diversity of programmes, which provides new and enriching experiences for everyone who wishes to participate.
name: Museu Benfica - Cosme Damiao

address: Largo Sao Domingos de Benfica 1 Fronteira Palace, Lisbon 1500-554 Portugal
description: Seventeenth Century Palace placed in an ancient Quinta de Recreio (recreation farm) which includes a formal garden, an informal garden and woods. The exterior and interiors of the Palace are decorated with the largest and best collection of Portuguese seventeenth-century "azulejos" (decorative tiles) still in their original location known today. The gardens are decorated with fountains, statues and other constructions from the seventeenth century, which are refreshing and make the walk through the premises a continuous delight. Although this is an inhabited Palace still today, visitors are welcome to take guided tours of the inside and enjoy visiting some of the most beautiful rooms, the Library, the terrace with "azulejo" panels representing the Liberal Arts, and the Chapel. The fact that this is an inhabited living space is part of its very special atmosphere. Visitors can enjoy a souvenir shop managed by the Association of the Friends of the Fronteira Palace.
name: Palacio dos Marqueses de Fronteira
